Remarks:  

1. Stress,strain,force,fatigue and ERP item codes can be found in Item Codes,1045.For stressor strain item codes that have dual meanings, such as von Mises or maximum shear, the option specified in the Case Control Section will be used; i.e., STRESS(VONM) or STRESS(MAXS).  

2． $\mathrm{RTYPE}=^{\ast}\mathrm{CSTRESS}^{,}$ ,“CSTRAIN",“CFAILURE",and “CSTRAT” are used only with the PCOMP/PCOMPG entry.“CSTRESS" and “CSTRAIN" item codes are described under Table 1 (Element Stress/Strain Item Codes) in Item Codes, 1045.“CFAILURE" and "CSTRAT" item codes are described under Table 2 (Element Force Item Codes) in Item Codes,1045. Only force item codes that refer to failure indices of direct stress and interlaminar shear stress are valid.  

The CFAILURE and CSTRAT response types requires the following specifications on the applicable entries:  

·Failure theory in the FT field on PCOMP/PCOMPG entry.   
· Allowable bonding shear stressin the SB field on PCOMP/PCOMPG entry.   
· Stress limits in the ST, SC, and SS fields on all MATi entries.   
When the PCOMPG is invoked, there is no default for the ATTB field.   
3. ATTB can be used for responses of weight, composite laminae, dynamics, real and complex eigenvalues, WMPID and stability derivatives. For eigenvector responses, such as DISP, the ATTB identifies the mode of interest. For other responses, this field must be blank.   
4. All grids associated with a DRESPl entry are considered to be in the same region for screening purposes. Only up to NSTR displacement constraints (see DSCREEN entry) per group per load case will be retained in the design optimization phase.  

5. DRESP1 identification numbers must be unique with respect to DRESP2 identification numbers.  

6. If I $\mathrm{^{\circ}T Y P E}=\mathrm{^{\circ}E L E M^{\circ}}$ , the ATTi correspond to element identification numbers.  

7. If $\mathrm{RTYPE}=^{\mathrm{*}}\mathrm{DISP}^{\mathrm{*}}$ ，“SPCFORCE”,“GPFORCE",“TDISP",“TVELO”,“TACCL" or“TSPCF", multiple component numbers (any unique combination of the digits 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks) may be specified on a single entry. Multiple response components may not be used on any other response types.  

8.If $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{^{\circ}F R D I S P^{\circ}}$ ,“FRVELO”,“FRACCL", or“FRSPCF"only one component number may be specified in the ATTA field. Numbers 1 through 6 correspond to real (or magnitude) components and 7 through 12 imaginary (or phase) components. If more than one component for the same grid is desired, then a separate entry is required.   
9. Real/imaginary representation is the default for complex response types. Magnitude/phase representation must be requested by the corresponding Case Control command; e.g., DISP(PHASE) $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ ALL for FRDISP type responses.   
10. REGION is used for constraint screening. The NSTR field on DSCREEN entries gives the maximum number of constraints retained for each region per load case. IF RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ “WEIGHT",“VOLUME",“LAMA”,“EIGN",“FREQ",“CEIG",“TOTSE", "RMSDISP”,“RMSVELO",“RMSACCL",no REGION identification number should be specified. If the region field is left blank for a grid response, one region is created for each DRESPi ID. If the region field is left blank for an element response, one region is created for each property ID invoked. Usually, the default value is appropriate. If the REGION field is not blank, all the responses on this entry as well as all responses on other DRESPl entries that have the same RTYPE and REGION identification number will be grouped into the same region.   
11. REGION is valid only among the same type of responses. Responses of different types will never be grouped into the same region, even if they are assigned the same REGION identification number by the user.   
12.If RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ "WEIGHT",“VOLUME",or“TOTSE” field ${\mathrm{ATTi}}={^{\circ}\mathrm{ALL}}{^{\circ}}$ implies total weight/volume/total strain energy of allsuperelements except external superelements, O implies residual only and i implies SEID $\lvert=\stackrel{\cdot}{1}$ . Default $\mathrel{\mathop:}=\mathop{\cdots}^{\infty}$ ALL". RTYPE $\c=$ “TOTSE" is not supported for shape optimization.   
13．RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ "STABDER"identifies a stability derivative response. ATTB is the restraint flag for the stability derivative. $\mathrm{ATTB}=0$ means unrestrained, and $\mathrm{\ATTB}=1$ means restrained. For example, ATTA $=4000$ 。 $\mathrm{\ATTB}=0$ , and $\mathrm{ATT}1=3$ reference the unrestrained $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{z}}$ derivative for the AESTAT (or AESURF) entry $\mathrm{ID}=4000$ ，   
14.RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ "FLUTTER" identifies a set of damping responses. The set is specified by ATTi: ATT1 $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ Identification number of a SET1 entry that specifies a set of modes. ${\mathrm{ATT}}2=$ Identification number of an FLFACT entry that specifies a list of densities. ATT3 $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ Identification number of an FLFACT entry that specifies a list of Mach numbers. ATT4 $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ Identification number of an FLFACT entry that specifies a list of velocities. If the flutteranalys is type PKNL, it is necessary to put PKNL in the PTYPEfield of this entry.   
15.For R $\mathrm{TYPE}=^{\mathrm{{\sc}^{c}F R X X X X X}}$ ”,“PSDXXXX”，“PRES” and “ERP” a real value for ATTB specifies a frequency value in cycles per unit time. If a real ATTB value is specified, then the responses are evaluated at the closest excitation frequency. The default for ATTB is allexcitation frequencies. See Remark 20. for additional ATTB options. The OFREQ Case Control command has no efect on the selection of the frequencies.   
16.For $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{^{\circ}T D I S P^{\circ}}$ ，“TVELO”,“TACCL",“TSPCF”,“TFORC”,and“TSTRE”,ATTB specifies a time value. If ATTB is specified, then the responses are evaluated at the closest time selected by the OTIME command. The default for ATTB is all time steps selected by the OTIME command.   
17. Intermediate station responses on CBAR elements due to PLOAD1 and/or CBARAO entries may not be defined on the DRESPl entry.   
18. $\mathrm{RTYPE}=^{\mathrm{{\mathfrak{c}}}}\mathrm{EIGN}^{\mathfrak{n}}$ refers to normal modes response in terms of eigenvalue (radian/time) $^{**2}$ while $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{^{\ast}F R E Q^{\ast}}$ refers to normal modes response in terms of natural frequency or units of cycles per unit time.   
19.For $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{LAMA}$ , EIGN or FREQ,the response approximation used for optimization can be individually selected using the ATTB field when. $\mathrm{APRCOD}=1$ is being used. For RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ LAMA, ATTB $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ blank or 1 selects direct linearization, ATTB $=2=$ inverse linearization. For $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{EIGEN}$ or FREQ, ATTB $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ blank $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ Rayleigh Quotient Approximation, $\mathbf{\Phi}=1\mathbf{\Phi}=\mathbf{\Phi}$ direct linearization, $=2=$ inverse approximation. The default Rayleigh Quotient Approximation should be preferred in most cases.   
20.Character input for ATTB is available for RTYPE of“FRXXXX",“PSDXXXX",“TXXXX”,“PRES" and“ERP". The character input represents a mathematical function and the options for character input are SUM, AVG, SSQ, RSS, MAX and MIN.The expression of mathematical function is shown as follows:  

$$
\operatorname{SUM}(\mathrm{X}_{1},\mathrm{X}_{2},...,\mathrm{Xn})\ =\ \sum_{\mathrm{i}=1}\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{i}}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{\boldmath~\cal~\cal~A~}\mathrm{\boldmath~\cal~A~}\mathrm{\boldmath~\cal~A~}(\mathrm{\boldmath~X~}_{1},\mathrm{\boldmath~X~}_{2},...,\mathrm{\boldmath~X~n~})=\mathrm{\boldmath~\sum~}\mathrm{\boldmath~X~}_{\mathrm{i}}/\mathrm{\boldmath~n~}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r c l}{{}}&{{}}&{{{\mathrm{SSQ(X_{1},X_{2},...,X n)~=~\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_{i}^{2}}}}}\\ {{}}&{{}}&{{}}\\ {{}}&{{}}&{{{\mathrm{RSS(X_{1},X_{2},...,X n)~=~\displaystyle\sqrt{{\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_{i}^{2}}}}}}}\end{array}
$$  

$\mathrm{MAX}(\mathrm{X}_{1},\mathrm{X}_{2},...,\mathrm{X}\mathrm{n})~=~\mathrm{N}$ Maximum value among $\mathrm{{X}_{i}(i=1}$ to n)  

$\mathrm{MIN}(\mathrm{X}_{1},\mathrm{X}_{2},...,\mathrm{Xn})\ =$ Minimum value among $\mathrm{{X}_{i}(i=1}$ to n)  

where $X_{\mathrm{i}}$ is the response for a forcing frequency or time step. For example  

DRESP1,10,DX1,FRSTRE,ELEM,,3,AVG,10  

yields a response which is equal to the average stress for element 10 acrossallforcing frequencies.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>CAUTION!</td><td>1. If the ID of a DRESP1 with ATTB character input is referenced by a DRESP2 using the "DRESP2" flag, the results of the mathematical function are used to evaluate the DRESP2. 2. If the ID of a DRESP1 with ATTB character input is referenced by a DRESP2 using the "DRESP1" flag, the individual values of the DRESP1 are used to compute individual DRESP2 values and the mathematical function is not used by the DRESP2.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

21. Element strain energy item codes can be found under Table 7-13 in Item Codes,1045. Only element strain energy and element strain energy density can be referenced on a DRESP1 entry. $\mathrm{RTYPE}{=}^{\mathfrak{P}}\mathrm{ESE}^{\mathfrak{P}}$ is not supported for shape optimization.  

22.For RTYPE $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\lambda}}=$ RMSDISP, RMSVELO, or RMSACCL the ATTB specifies the appropriate RANDP ID.  

23.Input other than 1 or 7 of ATTA field, acoustic pressure component,for PRES response type will be reset to 1 (if less than 7) or 7 (if greater than 6 and less than 13).  

24. Design response weight is obtained from Grid Point Weight Generator for a reference point GRDPNT (see parameter GRDPNT). If GRDPNT is either not defined, equal to zero, or not a defined grid point, the reference point is taken as the origin of the basic coordinate system. Fields ATTA and ATTB refer to the row and column numbers of the rigid body weight matrix, which is partitioned as follows:  

$$
[\mathrm{W}]=\left|\begin{array}{c c}{\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{x}}\mathrm{W}_{12}\mathrm{W}_{13}\mathrm{W}_{14}\mathrm{W}_{15}\mathrm{W}_{16}}\\ {\mathrm{W}_{21}\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{y}}\mathrm{W}_{23}\mathrm{W}_{24}\mathrm{W}_{25}\mathrm{W}_{26}}\\ {\mathrm{W}_{31}\mathrm{W}_{32}\mathrm{W}_{z}\mathrm{W}_{34}\mathrm{W}_{35}\mathrm{W}_{36}}\\ {\mathrm{W}_{41}\mathrm{W}_{42}\mathrm{W}_{43}\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{x}}\mathrm{W}_{45}\mathrm{W}_{46}}\\ {\mathrm{W}_{51}\mathrm{W}_{52}\mathrm{W}_{53}\mathrm{W}_{54}\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{y}}\mathrm{W}_{56}}\\ {\mathrm{W}_{61}\mathrm{W}_{62}\mathrm{W}_{63}\mathrm{W}_{64}\mathrm{W}_{65}\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{z}}\Bigg]_{6\times6}}\end{array}\right|
$$  

The default values of ATTA and ATTB are 3, which specifies weight in the Z direction. Field ATT1 $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}^{\infty}\mathbf{ALL}\mathbf{\Sigma}^{\mathbf{\prime}}$ implies total weight of allsuperelements except external superelements. SEIDi refers to a superelement identification number. $\mathrm{SEIDi}=^{\ast}0^{\mathfrak{N}}$ refers to the residual superelement. The default of ATT1 is blank which is equivalent to “ALL".  

25.For $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{GPFORCE}$ , the PTYPE field is used to designate the GRID ID at which the force is defined. Output that is produced using PARAM NOELOF $>0$ is not supported for the DRESP1 entry.  

26.For $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{GPFORCP}$ the PTYPE field is blank. The grid point force is for the sum of all elements from the GRID ID listed in ATTA to the GRID (orient ID) listed in ATTi. This response corresponds to that produced with PARAM NOELP $>0$ . It is not necessary to set PARAM NOELP $>0$ to compute the GPFORCP response.  

27.For E $\ensuremath{\mathrm{\Sigma}}\ensuremath{\mathrm{TYPE}}=\ensuremath{\mathrm{PSDXXXX}}$ , the PTYPE field specifies the RANDPS ID.  

28.RTYPE $\scriptstyle,=$ COMP (compliance of structures $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{P}^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{u}$ ) and FRMASS (massfraction of topology designed elements) entries are used for topology optimization or combined topology, sizing/shape optimization.  

29.RTYPE $\begin{array}{r}{{\bf\nabla}_{\bf\cdot}={\bf\nabla}}\end{array}$ FRMASS can be used for topology and topometry optimization. For topology, FRMASS, is the mass divided by the masscalculated if all topology design variables are 1.0.FRMASS is calculated for designed elements only. $\mathrm{FRMASS}=1.0$ if all design variables are 1.0. For topometry, the initial FRMASS is defined as 1.0 for the initial design specified on the TOMVAR entries. For non-volume elements like CELAS, an artificial mass $=1.0$ is assumed for each element.  

30. Response type ABSTRESS is for element type code of 238 (CBAR) and 239 (CBEAM) only.  

31. If a PSDxxxx or RMSxxxx response is being applied with RANDPS Bulk Data entries that include multiple subcases, the DESSUB or DESOBJ Case Control command that invokes the PSDxxxx or RMSxxxx response must be in the first subcase used by the RANDPS entry.  

32. Response types, ESE, TOTSE, GPFORCE and GPFORCP are not supported for shape optimization.  

33. For RTYPE $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\lambda}}=$ EIGN or FREQ, PTYPE field can be utilized to identify the source of the mode. Valid options are ‘STRUC' or ‘FLUID'. The default is ‘STRUC'.  

34.For RTYPE $\v{S}_{\v{r}}=\v{U}_{\mathbf{\tilde{\tau}}}$ ACPWR, PTYPE field can be utilized to identify the panel name. The default is °total' which covers the whole interface between structural and fluid field.  

35.For RTYPE $\begin{array}{r}{{\bf\nabla}_{\bf\Pi}=}\end{array}$ AFxxxx, PTYPE field can be utilized to specified the ID of Acoustic Field Point Mesh. AFPM.  

36. For monitor point responses (RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ STMONP1, STMOND1, MONPNT3 AEMONP1 or AEMOND1) the ATTA field specifies the components to be extracted. These can be any subset of the integers 1 through 6 that appear on the monitor quantity with the NAME provided in the PTYPE field. All of these responses can be invoked in a static aeroelastic (ANALYSIS $\dot{\mathbf{\eta}}=\mathbf{\eta}$ SAERO) subcase. STMOND1 and MONPNT3 can be invoked from a static (ANALYSIS $\dot{\mathbf{\eta}}=\mathbf{\eta}$ STAT) subcase. The responses are not available in a dynamic response or normal modes subcase. The response types have the following meaning:  

a. STMONP1 - A structural MONPNT1   
b. STMOND1 - A structural MONDSP1   
C. MONPNT3-AMONPNT3   
d. AEMONP1 - An aerodynamic MONPNT1   
e. AEMOND1 - An aerodynamic MONDSP1  

For all but the STMONPl, the response is the elastic monitor point value.For the STMONP1, it is the elastic“minus" inertial “plus" elastic applied load value.  

37. For RTYPE-FRMASS, if the PID in the ATTi field is not blank, the PTYPE field must specify the type of property the PID references.   
38.RTYPE $\v{x}_{\mathrm{{,}}}=$ DIVERG is for subcases with ANALYSIS $\dot{\bf\Phi}=\dot{\bf\Phi}$ DIVERG (aeroelastic static divergence). Only a single Mach number can be specified for this RTYPE.   
39.For RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ FATIGUE (pseudo-static fatigue), PTYPE must be set to ELEM or PSOLID, PSHELL, PBAR, PBEAM, or PWELD.For RTYPE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ FRFTG (frequency response fatigue), PTYPE must be set to ELEM or PSOLID o r PSHELL. ATTB is the FID of a FATIGUE case control and must be the same FID for all RTYPEs of type FATIGUE or FRFTG. RTYPEs of type FATIGUE and FRFTG cannot be mixed; either all are RTYPE $\begin{array}{r}{{\bf\nabla}_{\bf\Pi}=\frac{\frac{1}{2}}{\bf\nabla}}\end{array}$ FATIGUE or all are RTYPE $\v{M}_{\v{r}}=$ FRFTG.   
40.Ifa FATIGUE case control referencesa SET ID,then ATTB must reference one of the IDsreferenced by the SET. Design optimization using fatigue responses is currently limited to one fatigue analysis, that is,one loading sequence.Multiple fatigue responses referencing different loading sequences, i.e., FATIGUE case control IDs, will result in an error.   
41. For the ERP response,the PTYPE field must be ERPPNL.   
42.If the ATTl field is blank for the ERP response, all panels are invoked.   
43.Fatigue Item Codes can be found in Fatigue Item Codes,1104.Item codes that are available as design responses are 4-9 and 12 for the element centroid or first node/layer/location and the comparable items for ensuing nodes/layers/locations. The use of NODA on the FTGPARM entry is not supported.   
44.For the WMPID (weight as afunction of material and property ID),the following conventions apply: a. ATTA is required, ATTB and ATTi are optional. b. ATTB specifies the superelement with ATTB $_{\cdot=0}$ indicating the residual, ${>}0$ indicates superelement ATTB and ATTB $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ ALL or blank means all superelements) c.The ATTi fields designate the property ID's of interest. If ATTi is specified, the associated property type (e.g., PSHELL) must be specified by the PTYPE input of field 5 on the DRESP1 entry. d.If there is no ATTi, all material with MID $\begin{array}{r}{{\bf\Pi}^{\prime}=\frac{\bf\Pi}{\bf\Pi}}\end{array}$ ATTA will be used to generate the response. e.If there are multiple ATTi, a single scalar weight is calculated that is the sum of the all the properties f. Materials that are supported with this entry are: MAT1,MAT2, MAT3, MAT8, MAT9 and MAT10 g. Properties that are supported are: PSHELL, PROD, PBEAM, PTUBE, PSHEAR, PBAR, PSOLID, PBEND,PCOMP, PCOMPG, PBARL, PBEAML, PBRSECT and PBMSECT.   
45. Certain restrictions apply for RTYPE $\c=$ WMPID   
a. The density of the material referenced on the ATTA field cannot also be designed using a DVMRELx entry   
b. The property referenced on the ATTI field cannot also be invoked by a TOMVAR entry.   
c. The WMPID response is supported for topology optimization or for shape sizing optimizatior. but not for both topology and shape sizing optimization.

Remarks:  

1. DRESP2 entries may only reference DESVAR, DTABLE,DRESP1, DNODE, DVPREL1, DVCREL1, DVMREL1, DVPREL2, DVCREL2, DVMREL2 and DVLREL1 entries. They may also reference other DRESP2 entries. However, a DRESP2 entry cannot reference itself directly or recursively.   
2. a) Ifthe referenced DRESPl entries span subcases,the DRSPAN Case Control command is required to identify DRESP1 IDs for each subcase. DRESP2 entries that span subcases must be invoked above the subcase level by DESGLB on DESOBJ commands. b) Referenced DRESP entries that span superelements are supported automatically. c) Referenced DRESP2 entries cannot span subcases or superelements.   
3. DRESP2 entries must have unique identification numbers with respect to DRESPl entries.   
4.The“DESVAR",“DTABLE"”，"DRESP1",“DNODE”,“DVPREL1”,“DVCREL1" and “DVMREL1",“DVPREL2”,“DVCREL2",“DVMREL2”,“DRESP2” and DVLREL1 flags in field 2 must appear in the order given above. Any of these words, along with the identification numbers associated with them, may be omitted if they are not involved in this DRESP2 relationship. However, at least one of these ten types of arguments must exist.   
5. The REGION field follows the same rules as for the DRESPl entries. DRESPl and DRESP2 responses will never be contained in the same region, even if they are assigned the same REGION identification number. The default is to put allresponses referenced by one DRESP2 entry in the same region.  

6. The variables identified by DVIDi, LABLj, NRk, the Gm, CMPM pairs, DPIPi, DCICm, DMIMn, DPI2Po, DCI2Cp, DMI2Mq, and NRRu are assigned (in that order) to the variable names $(\mathrm{x}1,\mathrm{x}2$ x3, etc.) specified in the left-hand side of the first equation on the DEQATN entry referenced by EQID. In the example below,  

DESVARs 101 and 3 are assigned to arguments A and B.   
DTABLEs PI and YM are assigned to arguments C and D.   
Grid 14, Component 1 is assigned to argument R.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>DRESP2</td><td>1</td><td>LBUCK</td><td>5</td><td>3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DESVAR</td><td>101</td><td>3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DTABLE</td><td>PI</td><td>YM</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DNODE</td><td>14</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DEQATN</td><td>5</td><td colspan="6">F1(A, B, C, D,R)=A+B*C-(D**3+10.0)+sin(C*R)</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

7.(Gm, Cm) can refer to any grid component and is no longer limited to a designed grid component  

8. The FUNC attributes can be used in place of the EQID and supports the functions shown in the following table:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Function</td><td>Description</td></tr><tr><td>SUM</td><td>Sum of the arguments</td></tr><tr><td>SFMAX</td><td>Maximization of stiffness and frequency. See remark 14</td></tr><tr><td>AVG</td><td>Average of the arguments</td></tr><tr><td>SSQ</td><td>Sum of the squares of the arguments</td></tr><tr><td>RSS</td><td>Square root of the sum of the squares of the arguments</td></tr><tr><td>MAX</td><td> The maximum value of the argument list</td></tr><tr><td>MIN</td><td>The minimum value of the argument list</td></tr><tr><td>BETA</td><td>Minimize the maximum response. See Remark 10.</td></tr><tr><td>MATCH</td><td>Match analysis results with user specified values. See Remark 11.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

When EQID has character input, the DEQATN entry is no longer needed. The functions are applied to all arguments on the DRESP2 regardless of the type.See Remark 20. of the DRESPl entry for an explanation of these functions.  

9. The number of arguments of a DEQATN can be more than the number of values defined on the DRESP2 if the DRESPls referenced have RTYPE with ‘FR' or‘PSD' prefix. Arguments are still positional. The extra arguments in the DEQATN must appear at the end of the argument list. The discrepancy is resolved internal with the forcing frequency(ies) associated with DRESP1s. An example is shown as follows:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>DRESP1</td><td>10</td><td>FDISP1</td><td>FRDISP</td><td></td><td></td><td>1</td><td>10.</td><td>1001</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DRESP1</td><td>20</td><td>FDISP2</td><td>FRDISP</td><td></td><td></td><td>1</td><td>20.</td><td>1001</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>DRESP2</td><td>30</td><td>AVGFD</td><td>100</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DRESP1</td><td>10</td><td>20</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DEQATN</td><td>100</td><td colspan="7">AVG(D1,D2,F1,F2) = (D1/F1+D2/F2)*0.5</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

In the above example, the DEQATN has two more additional terms than have been defined on the DRESP2. The first additional term is the forcing frequency (in hertz) of the first DRESP1 ID on the DRESP2. The second additional term is the forcing frequency of second DRESP1 ID in the list. When all DRESPls involved have the same frequency, the user is not required to name all the additional terms in the argument list of DEQATN.  

10.FUNC $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ BETA facilitates a design task where the objective is to minimize the maximum response. Only DRESP1 entries can be invoked by DRESP2 and the DRESP's cannot span subcases. The BETA function creates the following design task:  

Minimize Φ= CXβ Subject to $\bf\delta g_{\alpha}=\frac{\gamma\mathrm{X_{\beta}-\mathrm{r_{j}}}}{\mathrm{C_{\beta}}}\geq0$ where $\gamma$ is determined from  

$$
\mathrm{C}_{2}\ =\ (\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{jmax}}-\gamma\mathrm{X}_{\upbeta})/\mathrm{C}_{3}
$$  

User input parameters $\mathrm{C}_{1},\mathrm{C}_{2},\mathrm{C}_{3}$ therefore have the following meaning:  

$\mathrm{C}_{1}$ (Default $=1.0\dot{}$ ) weights the spawned design variable, $X_{\upbeta}$ , to create the objective. Since $X_{\upbeta}$ starts at 1.0, $\mathrm{C}_{1}$ is the initial objective.  

$\mathbf{C}_{2}$ sets the initial value of the maximum constraint created by this process. The default values of 0.005 is equal to DOPTPRM parameter GMAX. $\mathrm{C}_{3}$ (Default $=10.0\dot{}\dot{}$ ）is an offset value to avoid dividing by zero when creating constraints.  

11.1 $\mathrm{FUNC}=\mathrm{MATCH}$ creates a response from the difference between analysis results, ${\bf r}_{\mathrm{j}}$ , that are associated with DRESPls and target values, ${\bf r}_{\mathrm{j}}^{\mathrm{T}}$ , that are input using DTABLE data. Only DRESP1 entries and DTABLE entries can be invoked by the DRESP2 entry.  

When METH ${\mathrm{IOD}}={\mathrm{LS}},$ a least square minimization is performed where the response is  

$$
{\bf r}_{2}=\sum_{\mathrm{~j~=~1~}}^{\mathrm{~m~}}\left(\frac{{\bf r_{j}}-{\bf r_{j}^{\mathrm{T}}}}{{\bf r_{j}^{\mathrm{T}}}}\right)^{2}
$$  

When METHOI $)={\mathrm{BETA}}$ , the design task becomes one of minimizing an objective that is the maximum normalized difference between the analysis and target values  

$$
\frac{\bf{r_{j}}-\bf{r_{j}^{\mathrm{{T}}}}}{\left|\bf{r_{j}^{\mathrm{{T}}}}\right|}
$$  

in the same manner as outlined in Remark 10.  

12.With FUNO $\dot{\mathbf{\Omega}}=\mathbf{\Omega}$ MATCH, if the DTABLE LABLj invokes an integer VALUi on the DTABLE entry, the integer points to a TABLEDi entry that provides tabular input as a function of frequency or time. This is used in conjunction with a single DRESPl NRk that provides a response acrossa range of frequencies or times (i.e., RTYPE $\v{r}_{\mathbf{r}}=$ FRxxxx, PSDxxxx, ACxxxx or Txxxx).When the TABLEDi option is invoked, the response can only be constrained, it cannot be the objective. This further implies that FUNC $\dot{\mathbf{\Omega}}=\mathbf{\Omega}$ MATCH,METHOD $\mid=$ BETA is not supported with TABLEDi.   
13.If the mathematical function from a DRESPl that has character input in the ATTB field (see remark   
20 of the DRESP1) is to be used in the DRESP2 evaluation, the DRESPl must be referenced under the“DRESP2"flag, not the“DRESP1"flag. If the“DRESP1"flag is used in this situation, it will result in a DRESP2 being evaluated for each of the individual values that contribute to the mathematical function.   
14.The functions are applied to allDRESPl arguments on the DRESP2: Maximization of stiffness and frequency FUNC $\dot{\mathbf{\Omega}}=\mathbf{\Omega}$ SFMAX, that refers multiple DRESP1 IDs where the fundamental frequency ID must be placed at last one.In addition, the ANALYSIS $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ MODES must be placed at thelast subcase in Case Control Section. This is typically used in topology, topometry and topography optimization.

(Character)</td></tr><tr><td>DMI2Mi</td><td>DVMREL2 entry identification number (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>“DRESP2"</td><td>Flag indicating other DRESP2 entry identification number. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>NRRk</td><td>DRESP2 entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>“DVLREL1"</td><td>Flag indicating DVLREL1 identification number (character)</td></tr><tr><td>DLILi</td><td>DVLREL1 entry identification number (integer)</td></tr><tr><td>“USRDATA"</td><td>Flag indicating user input data (Character). See Remark 8.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. DRESP3 entries may reference DESVAR, DTABLE, DRESP1, DNODE, DVPREL1, DVCREL1, DVMREL1, DVPREL2, DVCREL2, DVMREL2, DRESP2 and DVLRELlentries.However, a DRESP3 entry cannot reference another DRESP3 entry.   
2. The group name must be referenced by an FMS CONNECT entry.   
3.Multiple types of external responses can be defined in one group.Each type name identifies a specific external response evaluated in the user-supplied routines. See Building and Using the Sample Programs MSC Nastran Utilities Guide for a discussion of how to incorporate external responses.   
4. a) Referenced DRESP2 entries cannot span subcases or superelements. b) If referenced DRESPl entries span subcases, the DRSPAN Case Control command is required to identify the DRESP1 IDs for each subcase. DRESP3 entries that span subcases must be invoked above the subcase level by DESGLB or DESOBJ commands. c) Referenced DRESP1 entries that span superelements are supported automatically.   
5. DRESP3 entries must have unique identification numbers with respect to DRESP2 and DRESP1 entries.   
6.The“DESVAR",“DTABLE",“DNODE”,“DVPREL1”,“DVCREL1" and“DVMREL1", “DVPREL2",DVCREL2",“DVMREL2”,“DRESP2",“DVLREL1" and “USRDATA" keywords on the continuation entries must appear in the order given above.Any of these words, along with the subsequent data associated with them, may be omitted if they are not involved in this DRESP3 relationship. However, at least one of these types of arguments must exist.   
7. The REGION field follows the same rules as for the DRESPl entries. DRESPl and DRESP3 responses will never be contained in the same region, even if they are assigned the same REGION identification number. The default is to put all responses referenced by one DRESP3 entry in the same region.  

8. The data in the USRDATA field is character string based. It provides a convenient way to pass constants to the external response server routines. The maximum number of characters allowed is 32000.  

Defines screening data for constraint deletion.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DSCREEN</td><td>RTYPE</td><td>TRS</td><td>NSTR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DSCREEN</td><td>STRESS</td><td>-0.7</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>RTYPE</td><td>Response type for which the screening criteria apply. See Remark 3. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>TRS</td><td>Truncation threshold. (Real; Default = -0.5)</td></tr><tr><td>NSTR</td><td>Maximum number of constraints to be retained per region per load case. See Remark 3. (Integer > 0; Default = 20)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks: 1. Grid responses associated with one particular load case are grouped by the specification of DRESP1 entries. From each group, a maximum of NSTR constraints are retained per load case. 2.Element responses are grouped by the property; i.e.,allelement responses for one particular load case belonging to the set of PIDs specified under ATTi on a DRESPi entry are regarded as belonging to the same region. In superelement sensitivity analysis,if the property (PID) is defined in more than one superelement, then separate regions are defined. A particular stress constraint specification may be applied to many elements in a region generating many stress constraints, but only up to NSTR constraints per load case will be retained. 3. For aeroelastic responses, that is $\mathrm{\sfRTMPE}=\mathrm{\mathop{TRIM}^{\mathrm{\prime\prime}}}$ ,“STABDER", and “FLUTTER", the NSTR limit is applied to all DRESP1 IDs that are the same RTYPE and have the same REGION specified. 4. For responses that are not related to grids or elements, that is $\mathrm{RTYPE}=\mathrm{^{\circ}W E I G H T^{\circ}}$ ,“VOLUME", “EIGN",“FREQ",“LAMA", CEIG", FRMASS, COMP, and TOTSE",NSTR is not used. TRS is still applicable. 5. The RTYPE field is set to EQUA if constraints that are associated with DRESP2 entries are to be screened. The RTYPE field is set to DRESP3 if constraints that are associated with DRESP3 entries are to be screened. If the REGION field on the DRESP2 or DRESP3 is blank, one region is established for each DRESP2/DRESP3 entry. 6. If a certain type of constraint exists but no corresponding DSCREEN entry is specified, all the screening criteria used for this type of constraint will be furnished by the default values. 7. Constraints can be retained only if they are greater than TRS. See the Remarks under the DCONSTR, 1706 entry for a definition of constraint value. 8. Constraint screening is applied to each superelement.  

Defines a table of real constants that are used in equations (see DEQATN entry).  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DTABLE</td><td>LABL1</td><td>VALU1</td><td>LABL2</td><td>VALU2</td><td>LABL3</td><td>VALU3</td><td>LABL4</td><td>VALU4</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>LABL5</td><td>VALU5</td><td>LABL6</td><td>VALU6</td><td>LABL7</td><td>VALU7</td><td>LABL8</td><td>VALU8</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DTABLE</td><td>PI</td><td>3.142</td><td>H</td><td>10.1</td><td>E</td><td>1.0E6</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>G</td><td>5.5E5</td><td>B</td><td>100.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>LABLi</td><td>Label for the constant. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>VALUi</td><td>Value of the constant or TABLEDx ID. (Real or Integer, respectively)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Multiple DTABLE entries may be specified in the Bulk Data Section.   
2. LABLi are referenced by the LABj on the DRESP2, DRESP3, DVCREL2, DVMREL2, or DVPREL2 entries.   
3. Trailing blank fields are permitted at the end of each line of LABLi/VALUi pairs, but intermediate blanks are not.(See the example above for permitted trailing blanks.)   
4. For PART SE,if LABLi is referenced on SEDRSP2 and/or SEDRSP3, DTABLE entries must be placed in a PART SE where companion design model entries, such as DESVAR, DRESPl and etc are available.   
5. If the VALUi is an integer, this points to the ID of a TABLEDx Bulk Data entry that lists the constants as a function of frequency or time. See Remark 12. on the DRESP2 entry.   
6. LABLi must be unique across all DTABLE and DTABLE2 entries.  

Defines real constants from a field of property, material or connections bulk data entries which then can be invoked by a DVxREL2, DRESP2, or DRESP3 entry.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DTABLE2</td><td>LABL1</td><td>PNAME1</td><td>PID1</td><td>FNAME1</td><td>LABL2</td><td>PNAME2</td><td>PID2</td><td>FNAME2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>LABL3</td><td>PNAME3</td><td>PID3</td><td>FNAME3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DTABLE2</td><td>PTHK10</td><td>PSHELLL</td><td>10</td><td>T</td><td>MATIE</td><td>MT1</td><td>38 E</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>CBARX1</td><td>CBAR</td><td>3888</td><td>X1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>LABLi</td><td>Label for the constant. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>PNAMEi</td><td>Property, material or connection bulk data entry name. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>PIDi</td><td>ID of PNAMEi entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>FNAMEi</td><td>Field name of PNAMEi. (Character)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. LABLi on DTABLE2 and DTABLE must be unique.   
2. LABLi on DTABLE2 can be referenced under DTABLE flag of DVxREL2 (where $\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{P}}$ ,M or C)/DRESP2/DRESP3.   
3. Values for the FNAMEifield ofthe PNAMEi Bulk Data entry with the ID of PIDi are taken fro analysis model before updating of analysis values with the designed value.If the updated value is desired, use the DVxREL2 flag on DRESP2 or DRESP3 entries instead.   
4. FNAMEi must be the same as the character string that appears on the PNAMEi Bulk Data entry.   
5. DTABLE2 must be utillized along with ‘NASTRAN SYSTEM(444) $\scriptstyle=1^{\prime}$ in input file or $\operatorname{sys444=1}^{\circ}$ during job submittal.  

Defines table data blocks.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>NAME</td><td>“0”</td><td>T1</td><td>T2</td><td>T3</td><td>T4</td><td>T5</td><td>T6</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>V01</td><td>V02</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>NAME</td><td>IREC</td><td>V1</td><td>V2</td><td>V3</td><td>V4</td><td>V5</td><td>V6</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>V7</td><td>V8</td><td>V9</td><td>V10</td><td>-etc.-</td><td>“ENDREC”</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example: (The first logical entry is the header entry.)  

<html><body><table><tr><td>DTI</td><td>XXX</td><td>0</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>4096</td><td></td><td>1</td><td>0</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1.2</td><td>2.3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>XXX</td><td>1</td><td>2.0</td><td>-6</td><td>ABC</td><td>6.000</td><td>-1</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>4</td><td>-6.2</td><td>2.9</td><td>1</td><td>DEF</td><td>-1</td><td>ENDREC</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td> Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NAME</td><td>Any character string that will be used in the DMAP sequence to reference the data block. See Remark 1. (Character; the first character must be alphabetic.)</td></tr><tr><td>Ti</td><td>Trailer values. (Integer ≥ 0; Default = 32767)</td></tr><tr><td>IREC</td><td>Record number. (Integer > 1)</td></tr><tr><td>VOi, Vi</td><td>Value. (Integer, Real, Character or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>“ENDREC”</td><td>Flags the end of the string of values (VOi or Vi) that constitute record IREC. (Character)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The user defines the data block and therefore must write a DMAP (or ALTER a solution sequence), which includes the DTIIN modules, in order to use the DTI feature. See the MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer's Guide. Allof the rules governing the use of data blocks in DMAP sequences apply.   
2. All fields following ENDREC must be blank.   
3. The entry using $\mathrm{IREC}=0$ is called the header entry and is an optional entry. The values T1 through T6 go to a special record called the trailer. Other values on the optional continuation go to the header record. If the header entry or the trailer is not specified, T1 through $\mathrm{T}6=32767$ . On this entry, “ENDREC" may be used only if there is at least one continuation.   
4.In addition to the optional header entry, there must be onelogical entry for each record in the table. Null records require no entries.  

5.“ENDREC" is used to input blank values at the end of a record. If"ENDREC" is not specified, the   
string for a record ends with the last nonblank field.   
6. The maximum number of DMI and DTI data blocks is 1000.   
7.If Ti is not an integer, a machine-dependent error willbe issued that may be difficult to interpret.   
8. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.

Remarks:  

1. This table is recognized only in SOLs 101,103,105,106,108,109,111,112,114,115,144,153, and for stress quantities only. One or more of the user parameters S1,S1G,or SlM must be specified with a value greater then or equal to zero in order to request sorting and/or filtering. See user parameter S1 in Parameters, 783. In order to sort force or strain quantities,a DMAP Alter is required.   
2.If the Ci value is-1,the element type willbe suppressed on the output file. An example of this feature could be as follows: If an element type is to be sorted on two different values and output twice, this can be accomplished by two call to the STRSORT module with two unique DTI tables. However, other element types will be printed twice. This additional print can be suppressed by setting their sort codes to $^{-1}$ ·  

3.Table 13 lists the elements curently that are sortable. In addition,the element type identification number, the default stress output quantity, and the associated stresscode identification numbers are provided. If this entry is not specified,then the stresses are sorted based on the default quantity given in Table 13.  

The following should be noted:  

a.The element type identification number is used internally by the program to differentiate element types.   
b. The stres code identification number is merely the word number in the standard printed output for the stress quantity of interest. For example, the thirteenth word of stress output for the CHEXA element is the octahedral shear stress. For this element type, the element identification number and the grid point ID each count as a separate word. Stress codes for the elements are tabulated in Item Codes, 1045.   
c. By default, stress sorting for the membrane and plate elements will be performed on the Hencky-von Mises stress. For maximum shear stress, the STRESS (MAXS) Case Control command should be specified.

Defines a superelement tree that determines the superelement processing order.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SETREE</td><td>“1”</td><td>SEUP1</td><td>SEDOWN1</td><td>SEUP2</td><td>SEDOWN2</td><td>SEUP3</td><td>SEDOWN3</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>SEUP4</td><td>SEDOWN4</td><td>SEUP5</td><td>SEDOWN5</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SETREE 1</td><td>1</td><td>14</td><td>2</td><td>14</td><td>3</td><td>14</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>14</td><td>14</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SEUPi</td><td>Identification number of the superelement upstream from SEDOWNi. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>SEDOWNi</td><td>Identification number of the superelement into which SEUPi is assembled. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. SETREE entries or the DTI,SETREE entry are required for multi-level superelement configurations   
2. If an DTI,SETREE entry is provided, then SETREE entries are not required.   
3. If both SETREE entries and a DTI,SETREE entry exist, then the DTI,SETREE entry will be ignored.   
4.Ifasuperelement is not referenced on the DTI,SETREE or SETREE entry, then the manner in which it is handled depends on the type of that superelement. Ifit is a PART superelement, then the residual will be regarded as its downstream superelement and the undefined superelement will therefore be placed immediately above the residual in the tree. If it is a Main Bulk Data superelement, then it will also be handled like an undefined PART superelement as above ifall of its exterior points belong to the residual. However,ifone or more of its exterior points do not belong to the residual, then the program willterminate with a user fatal error complaining that one of more of the superelements are not in the same path.   
5. If this entry is not present, the superelement tree and the processing order are determined automatically.   
6. A superelement identification may appear only once in a SEUPi field.   
7. On restart, if a superelement identification does not appear in a SEUPifield, its matrices will not be assembled, even though they may be present in the database.   
8. See the MSC Nastran Superelements and Modules User's Guide for a description of user-designated trees.  

9.This entry is stored in the database automaticaly. Once stored, the Bulk Data entry may be removed from the input file.

Correlates spectra lines specified on TABLED1 entries with damping values  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SPECSEL</td><td>RECNO</td><td></td><td>TYPE</td><td>TIDl</td><td>DAMP1</td><td>TID2</td><td>DAMP2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TID3</td><td>DAMP3</td><td>TID4</td><td>DAMP4</td><td>TID5</td><td>DAMP5</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SPECSEL</td><td>1</td><td></td><td>A</td><td>1</td><td>.02</td><td>2</td><td>.04</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>3</td><td>.06</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SPECSEL</td><td>3</td><td></td><td>V</td><td>4</td><td>.01</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>RECNO</td><td>Spectrum number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>Type of spectrum. (Character: “A" for acceleration, “V" for velocity, or“D” for displacement.)</td></tr><tr><td>TIDi</td><td>TABLED1 entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>DAMPi</td><td>Damping value assigned to TIDi. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The RECNO is the number of the spectrum defined by this entry. It is referenced on DLOAD Bulk Data entries.   
2. The TIDi, DAMPi pairs list the TABLEDl entry, which defines a line of the spectrum and the damping value assigned to it. The damping value is in the units of fraction of critical damping.   
3.This entry is placed in the database automatically.Once stored, the Bulk Data entry may be removed from the input file.  

Correlates output requests with frequency and damping ranges.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SPSEL</td><td>RECNO</td><td>DAMPL</td><td>FREQL</td><td>G1 G2</td><td>G3</td><td>G4</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>G5</td><td>G6</td><td>G7</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SPSEL</td><td>1</td><td>2 1</td><td></td><td>11 12</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>SPSEL</td><td>2</td><td>4 3</td><td>1</td><td>7</td><td>11 12</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>13</td><td>14</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>DAMPL</td><td>Identification number of the FREQ, FREQ1, or FREQ2 Bulk Data entry that specifies the list of damping values. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>FREQL</td><td>Identification number of the FREQi Bulk Data entry that specifies the list of frequencies. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Gi</td><td>Grid point number where response spectra will be calculated. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>RECNO</td><td>Record number of spectra to be generated. (Sequential integer beginning with 1.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. This table is used in SOLs 109 and 112.   
2. Damping values are in the units of fraction of critical damping.   
3.Output of response spectra requires the use of the XYPLOT...SPECTRA(RECNO)/Gi... command, where Gi is restricted to the grid points listed on the (RECNO) record of this entry.   
4.The SPSEL table is stored in the database automatically in SOLs 109 and 112. Once stored, the Bull Data entry may be removed from the input file.   
5.There must be case control output requestfor displacements and velocities of the points to be output. For example you could use case control commands:  

$\mathrm{DISP(PLOT)}=\mathrm{ALL}$ $\mathrm{VELO(PLOT)}=\mathrm{ALL}$  

Defines units necessary for conversion during the analysis for the Nastran/ADAMS interface ora Nastran fatigue analysis.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DTI</td><td>UNITS</td><td>1</td><td>MASS</td><td>FORCE</td><td>LENGTH</td><td>TIME</td><td>STRESS</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>DTI</td><td>UNITS</td><td>1</td><td>KG</td><td>N</td><td>M</td><td>S</td><td>MPA</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The DTI,UNITS Bulk Data entry is required for a ADAMSMNF FLEXBODY $\mathbf{\bar{\Psi}}=\mathbf{\Psi}$ YES run. See the ADAMSMNF\* (Case), 222 case control entry.ADAMS is not a unitless code (as is Nastran). Units must be specified. A DTI Bulk Data entry provides ‘UNITS' (a unique identifier) input as the above example illustrates. Once identified, the units willapply to allsuperelements in the model. Acceptable character input strings are listed in the table below. MASS, FORCE, LENGTH, and TIME are required for ADAMS interface.  

2. MSC Nastran is a unitless code and it is the user's responsibility to ensure compatible units.During a fatigue analysis, stress is converted to SI units of MPa because the fatigue material property stress parameters as defined on the MATFTG entry are internally converted to standard SI units of MPa. The stresses from the analysis must match.Thus it is necessary for the user to use DTI,UNITS to define the stress units to ensure proper conversion. The default units are MPa and this entry is only necessary if stresses are not in MPa.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Mass</td><td>Force</td><td>Length</td><td>Time</td><td>Stress*</td></tr><tr><td>KG - kilogram</td><td>N- newton</td><td>KM - kilometer</td><td>H - hour</td><td>MPA - megapascal</td></tr><tr><td>LBM - pound- mass</td><td>LBF - pounds-force</td><td>M- meter</td><td>MIN - minute</td><td> PA - pascal </td></tr><tr><td> SLUG - slug</td><td>KGF - kilograms- force</td><td>CM - centimeter</td><td>S - second</td><td>PSI - pound per square inch</td></tr><tr><td>GRAM - gram</td><td>OZF - ounce-force</td><td>MM - millimeter</td><td>MS - millisecond</td><td>KSI - kilo pound per square inch</td></tr><tr><td>OZM - ounce- mass</td><td>DYNE - dyne</td><td>MI - mile</td><td>US - microsecond</td><td>PSF - pound per square foot</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Mass</td><td>Force</td><td>Length</td><td>Time </td><td>Stress*</td></tr><tr><td>KLBM - kilo pound-mass(1000 lbm)</td><td>KN - kilonewton</td><td>FT - foot</td><td>NANOSEC - nanosecond</td><td>KSF - kilo pound per square foot</td></tr><tr><td>MGG - megagram</td><td>KLBF - kilo pound- force (1000 lbf)</td><td>IN- inch</td><td>D - day</td><td>DYNECM2 - dyne per square centimeter</td></tr><tr><td> SLINCH - 12 slugs MN - millinewton</td><td></td><td>UM - micrometer</td><td></td><td>BAR - bar</td></tr><tr><td>UG - microgram</td><td>UN - micronewton</td><td> NM - nanometer</td><td></td><td>ATM - physical atmosphere</td></tr><tr><td> NG - nanogram</td><td> NN - nanonewton</td><td>ANG - angstrom</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>USTON - US ton</td><td></td><td>YD - yard</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td> MIL - milli-inch</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>UIN - micro-inch</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

\* For fatigue analysis of spot welds, only MPA, PA, PSI, KSI, PSF, and KSF are supported. For random vibration fatigue analysis using SOL 108 or 11l, only MPA, PA, PSI, and KSI are supported.  

Associates a design variable identification number to a linear combination of boundary shape vectors from a particular auxiliary model.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DVBSHAP</td><td>DVID</td><td>AUXMOD</td><td>COL1</td><td>SF1</td><td>COL2</td><td>SF2</td><td>COL3</td><td>SF3</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DVBSHAP</td><td>4</td><td>1</td><td>1</td><td>1.6</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>DVID</td><td>Design variable identification number of a DESVAR entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>AUXMOD</td><td>Auxiliary model identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COLi</td><td>Load sequence identification number from AUXMODEL Case Control command. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>SFi</td><td>Scaling factor for load sequence identification number. (Real; Default = 1.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:

Defines the relation between a connectivity property and design variables.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DVCREL1</td><td>ID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>EID</td><td>CPNAME</td><td>CPMIN</td><td>CPMAX</td><td>C0</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DVID1</td><td>COEF1</td><td>DVID2</td><td>COEF2</td><td>DVID3</td><td>COEF3</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DVCREL1</td><td>5</td><td>CQUAD4</td><td>1</td><td>ZOFFS</td><td></td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Unique identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>Name of an element connectivity entry, such as “CBAR",“CQUAD4", etc. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>EID</td><td>Element Identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CPNAME</td><td>Name of connectivity property, such as “X1",“X2", “X3",“ZOFFS", etc. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>CPMIN</td><td>Minimum value allowed for this property. If CPNAME references a connectivity property that can only be positive, then the default value of CPMIN is 1.0E-15. Otherwise, it is - 1.0E35. See Remark 4. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>CPMAX</td><td>Maximum value allowed for this property. See Remark 4. (Real; Default =1.0E+20)</td></tr><tr><td>C0</td><td>Constant term of relation. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>DVIDi</td><td>DESVAR entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COEFi</td><td>Coefficient of linear relation or keyword = “PVAL". (Ifi = 1, Real or Character; if i > 1, Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The relationship between the connectivity property and design variables is given by:  

$$
\mathrm{CP_{j}=C_{0}+\sum_{i}C O E F_{i}\cdot X_{D V I D_{i}}}
$$  

2. The continuation entry is required.  

3.The fifth field of the entry, CPNAME, only accepts string characters.These string values must be the same as those given in the connectivity entry descriptions in this Guide. For example, if the plate offset is to be designed (CQUAD4, CTRIA3, etc), ZOFFS (case insensitive) must be specified on the CPNAME field.  

4. The default values for CPMIN and CPMAX are not applied when the linear property is a function of a single design variable and $\mathrm{C0=0}$ . It is expected that the limits applied on the associated DESVAR entry will keep the designed property within meaningful bounds.   
5.When "PVAL"is used for the COEF1 field, this is a flag to indicate that the COEFl value is to be obtained from the connectivity bulk data entry. If a DVCRELl entry references more than one design variable with the PVAL option, a User Fatal Message will be issued.   
6. If the user inputs CQUAD4/CTRIA3 entries and then uses $\mathrm{QRMETH}=5$ to convert them to CQUADR/CTRIAR entries, the design of items on these entries using the DVCRELl entry should refer to the converted type (i.e., CQUADR/CTRIAR). Similarly, if QRMETH $_{.=2}$ or 3 is used, the DVCREL1 entry should refer to CQUAD4/CTRIA3 types.  

Defines the relation between a connectivity property and design variables with a user-supplied equation.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DVCREL2</td><td>ID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>EID</td><td>CPNAME</td><td>CPMIN</td><td>CPMAX</td><td>EQID</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>“DESVAR”</td><td>DVID1</td><td>DVID2</td><td>DVID3</td><td>DVID4</td><td>DVID5</td><td>DVID6</td><td>DVID7</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>DVID8</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>“DTABLE”</td><td>LABL1</td><td>LABL2</td><td>LABL3</td><td>LABL4</td><td>LABL5</td><td>LABL6</td><td>LABL7</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>LABL8</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DVCREL2 1 DESVAR</td><td>CBAR 100 1001</td><td>X1</td><td>0.05</td><td>1.0</td><td>100</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>DTABLE</td><td>X10</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Unique identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>Name of an element connectivity entry, such as “CBAR",“CQUAD4", etc. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>EID</td><td>Element Identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CPNAME</td><td> Name of connectivity property, such as“X1",“X2”,“X3",“ZOFFS", etc. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>CPMIN</td><td>Minimum value allowed for this property. If CPNAME references a connectivity property that can only be positive, then the default value of CPMIN is 1.0E-15. Otherwise, it is -1.0E35. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>CPMAX</td><td> Maximum value allowed for this property. (Real; Default =1.0E+20)</td></tr><tr><td>EQID</td><td>DEQATN entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>“DESVAR"</td><td>DESVAR flag. Indicates that the IDs of DESVAR entries follow. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>DVIDi</td><td>DESVAR entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>“DTABLE”</td><td>DTABLE flag. Indicates that the LABLs for the constants in a DTABLE or DTABLE2 entry follow. This field may be omitted if there are no constants involved in this relation. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>LABLi</td><td> Label for a constant on the DTABLE or DTABLE2 entry. (Character)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The variable identified by DVIDi and LABLi correspond to variable names $(\mathrm{x}1,\mathrm{x}2$ ,etc.) listed in the left-hand side of the first equation on the DEQATN entry identified by EQID. The variable names x1 through $\mathrm{_{xN}}$ (where $\mathbf{N}=\mathbf{m}+\mathbf{n}$ ) are assigned in the order DVID1, DVID2, .., DVIDm, LABL1, LABL2, .., LABLn.   
2.If both“DESVAR” and “DTABLE" are specified in field 2,“DESVAR" must appear first.   
3.The fifth field of the entry, CPNAME,only accepts string characters.These string values must be the same as those given in the connectivity entry descriptions in this Guide. For example, if the plate offset is to be designed (CQUAD4, CTRIA3, etc.), ZOFFS (case insensitive) must be specified on the CPNAME field.   
4. If the user inputs CQUAD4/CTRIA3 entries and then uses $\mathrm{QRMETH}=5$ to convert them to CQUADR/CTRIAR entries, the design of items on these entries using the DVCREL2 entry should refer to the converted type (i.e., CQUADR/CTRIAR). Similarly, if QRMETH $:=2$ or 3 is used, the DVCREL2 entry should refer to CQUAD4/CTRIA3 types.  

Defines the relationship between design variables and grid point locations.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>DVGRID</td><td>DVID</td><td>GID</td><td>CID</td><td>COEFF</td><td>N1</td><td>N2</td><td>N3</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DVGRID</td><td>3</td><td>108</td><td>5</td><td>0.2</td><td>0.5</td><td>0.3</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>DVID</td><td>DESVAR entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>GID</td><td>Grid point (GRID) or geometric point (POINT) identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td>Coordinate system identification number. (Integer ≥ O; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COEFF</td><td>Multiplier of the vector defined by Ni. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>Ni</td><td>Components of the vector measured in the coordinate system defined by CID. (Real; at least one Ni ≠ 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. A CID of zero or blank (the default) references the basic coordinate system.  

2. Multiple references to the same grid ID and design variable result in vectorial addition of the participation vectors defined by CID, COEFF, and Ni. There is no restriction on the number of DVGRID entries that may reference a given grid (GID) or design variable (DVID).  

3. The coordinate update equation is given as  

$$
\{{\bf g}\}_{\mathrm{i}}-\{{\bf g}\}_{\mathrm{i}}^{0}=\sum_{\mathrm{j}}{\bf C O E F F_{\mathrm{j}}(X_{\mathrm{DVIDj}}-X_{\mathrm{DVIDj}}^{0})\{N\}_{\mathrm{j}}}
$$  

where $\{{\bf g}\}_{\mathrm{i}}$ is the location of the $i\mathrm{-}t\mathrm{}b$ grid, $\left[\bf g_{x}\bf g_{y}\bf g_{z}\right]^{\mathrm{T}}$  

The vector $\{\bf N\}=\left[\bf N_{x}\bf N_{y}\bf N_{z}\right]^{\mathrm{T}}$ is determined from CID and Ni. Note that it is a change in a design variable from its initial value $\boldsymbol{\mathrm{X}}^{0}$ , and not the absolute value of the design variable itself, that represents a change in a grid point location, $\{\mathbf{g}\}_{\mathrm{i}}-\{\mathbf{g}\}_{\mathrm{i}}^{0}$ ·  

4.The DVGRID entry defines the participation coeffcients (basis vectors) of each design variable for each of the coordinates affected by the design process in the relationship  

$$
\{\Delta\mathbf{g}\}_{\mathrm{i}}=\sum_{\mathrm{j}}\{\mathbf{T}\}_{\mathrm{ij}}\cdot\Delta\mathbf{X}_{\mathrm{j}}
$$  

5. DVGRID entries that reference grid points on MPCs or RSSCON entries produce incorrect sensitivities. Often the sensitivities are 0.O which may result in a warning message indicating zero gradients which may be folowed by UFM 6499. Other rigid elements produce correct results.  

# Defines the linear relation between analysis model loading and design variables in SOL 200 with Analysis $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ STATICS  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DVLREL1</td><td>ID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>SID</td><td>LNAME</td><td>LMIN</td><td>LMAX</td><td>C0</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ATT1</td><td>ATT2</td><td>ATT3</td><td>ATT4</td><td>ATT5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DVID</td><td>COEF</td><td>DVID2</td><td>COEF2</td><td>DVID3</td><td>Etc</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example: Design the N1 FORCE at GRID 10O to be equal to DESVAR $\mathrel{\mathop:}10$  

<html><body><table><tr><td>DVLREL1</td><td>10</td><td>FORCE</td><td>300</td><td>N1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>100</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>10</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Unique identification number (Integer>0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>Name of Load, such as FORCE, see Remark 2. for supported types (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set ID (Integer>0)</td></tr><tr><td>LNAME</td><td>Load Name, such as F or N1 on the FORCE entry. See Remark 2. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>LMIN</td><td>Minimum value for the load. See Remark 5. (Real, default=-1.0e35)</td></tr><tr><td>LMAX</td><td>Maximum value for the load (Real, Default=1.0e20)</td></tr><tr><td>C0</td><td>Constant term of relation (Real, Default=0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>ATTi</td><td>Attributes of the designed load, see Remark 2. (Integer>0 or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>DVIDi</td><td>DESVAR entry identification number. (Integer>0)</td></tr><tr><td>COEFi</td><td>Coefficient of linear relation or keyword="PVAL", See Remark 3. (If i=1, Real or Character; if i>1, Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The relationship between the analysis model load and the design variables is given by:  

$$
\mathrm{L_{i}=C_{0}+\sum C O E F F_{i}X_{D V I D}}_{i}
$$  

2. Supported TYPEs and their ATTi meaning are given in the following table:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Load Type</td><td>LNAME (character)</td><td>ATT1 (integer)</td><td>ATT2 (integer)</td><td>ATT3 (integer)</td><td>ATT4 (integer)</td><td>ATT5 (integer)</td></tr><tr><td>FORCE</td><td>F, N1, N2 or N3</td><td>G</td><td>CID (see remark 6)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>LOAD</td><td>Sor Si</td><td>0ifLNAME is S, Li otherwise</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>MOMENT</td><td>M, N1, N2 or N3</td><td>G</td><td>CID (see remark 6)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

3.When"PVAL" is used for the COEFl field,this is aflag to indicate that the COEFl value is to be obtained from the load bulk data entry.Ifa DVLRELl entry references more than one design variable with the PVAL option, a User Fatal Message will be issued.   
4.If there are multipleloads that satisfy thedesignation of the request (for example two FORCE entries with identical SID, GRID and CID values), it is a user input error.   
5. The default values of LMIN and LMAX are not applied when the linear property is a function of a single design variable and $\scriptstyle\sum0=0$ . It is expected that the limits applied on the DESVAR entry wilkeep the designed property within reasonable bounds   
6.Input of these data is optional. It most cases, leaving it offwill result ina singleload that qualifies with the remaining attributes. If there are multiple instances that qualify, it is a user input error.   
7. The use of this entry is limited to statics and buckling analyses in SOL 200.  

Defines the relation between a material property and design variables  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DVMREL1</td><td>ID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>MID</td><td>MPNAME</td><td>MPMIN</td><td>MPMAX</td><td>C0</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DVID1</td><td>COEF1</td><td>DVID2</td><td>COEF2</td><td>DVID3</td><td>COEF3</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DVMREL1 5</td><td>MAT1</td><td>1</td><td>RHO</td><td>0.05</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Unique identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>Name of a material property entry, such as“MAT1", “MAT2", etc. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material Identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MPNAME</td><td>Name of material property, such as “E" or “RHO". (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>MPMIN</td><td>Minimum value allowed for this property. If MPNAME references a material property that can only be positive, then the default value for MPMIN is 1.0E-15. Otherwise, it is -1.0E35. See Remark 4. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>MPMAX</td><td>Maximum value allowed for this property. See Remark 4. (Real; Default = 1.0E+20)</td></tr><tr><td>C0</td><td>Constant term of relation. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>DVIDi</td><td>DESVAR entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COEFi</td><td>Coefficient of linear relation or keyword = “PVAL". (If i = 1, Real or Character; if i > 1, Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The relationship between the material property and design variables is given by:  

$$
\mathbf{MP}_{\mathrm{i}}=\mathbf{C}_{0}+\sum_{\mathrm{i}}\mathbf{COEF}_{\mathrm{i}}\cdot\mathbf{X}_{\mathrm{DVID}_{\mathrm{i}}}
$$  

2. The continuation entry is required.  

3.The fifth fieldof the entry, MPNAME,onlyaccepts stringcharacters.It must be the same as the name that appears in the Bulk Data Entries, 1117 for various material properties. For example, if the isotropic material density is to be designed, RHO (case insensitive) must be specified on the MPNAME field.  

4. The default value for MPMIN and MPMAX are not applied when the linear property is a function of a single design variable and $\mathrm{C0=0.0}$ . It is expected that the limits applied to the DESVAR entry will keep the designed property within reasonable bounds.   
5. When"PVAL" is used for the COEFl field,this is a flag to indicate that the COEFl value is to be obtained from the material bulk data entry. If a DVMRELl entry references more than one design variable with the PVAL option, a User Fatal Message will be issued.  

Defines the relation between a material property and design variables with a user-supplied equation.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DVMREL2</td><td>ID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>MID</td><td>MPNAME</td><td>MPMIN</td><td>MPMAX</td><td>EQID</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DESVAR</td><td>DVID1</td><td>DVID2</td><td>DVID3</td><td>DVID4</td><td>DVID5</td><td>DVID6</td><td>DVID7</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>DVID8</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DTABLE</td><td>LABL1</td><td>LABL2</td><td>LABL3</td><td>LABL4</td><td>LABL5</td><td>LABL6</td><td>LABL7</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>LABL8</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DVMREL2</td><td>5 DESVAR</td><td>MAT1 1 1 2</td><td>E</td><td>0.05</td><td>1.0</td><td>100</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DTABLE</td><td>E0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>

(Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td> Name of a material property entry, such as “MAT1", “MAT2", etc. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material Identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MPNAME</td><td>Name of material property, such as “E” or“RHO". (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>MPMIN</td><td>Minimum value allowed for this property. If MPNAME references a material property that can only be positive, then the default value for MPMIN is 1.0E-15. Otherwise, it is -1.0E35. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>MPMAX</td><td> Maximum value allowed for this property. (Real; Default = 1.0E+20)</td></tr><tr><td>EQID</td><td>DEQATN entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>DESVAR</td><td>DESVAR flag. Indicates that the IDs of DESVAR entries follow. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>DVIDi</td><td>DESVAR entry identification number. Remarks:  

1. The variables identified by DVIDi and LABLi correspond to variable names $(\mathrm{x}1,\mathrm{x}2$ etc.) listed in the left-hand side of the first equation on the DEQATN entry identified by EQID. The variable names x1 through $\mathrm{_{xN}}$ (where $\mathbf{N}=\mathbf{m}+\mathbf{n}$ ) are assigned in the order DVID1, DVID2, ..., DVIDm, LABL1, LABL2., ..., LABLn.   
2.If both“DESVAR” and “DTABLE" are specified in field 2,“DESVAR” must appear first.   
3.The fifth field ofthe entry, MPNAME, onlyaccepts string characters.It must be the same as the name that appears in the Bulk Data Entries,1117 for various material properties. For example, if the isotropic material density is to be designed, RHO (case insensitive) must be specified on the MPNAME field.  

Defines the relation between an analysis model property and design variables  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DVPREL1</td><td>ID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>PID</td><td>PNAME/ FID</td><td>PMIN</td><td>PMAX</td><td>Co</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>DVID1</td><td>COEF1</td><td>DVID2</td><td>COEF2</td><td>DVID3</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DVPREL1</td><td>12</td><td>PBAR</td><td>612</td><td>6</td><td>0.2</td><td>3.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>4</td><td>0.25</td><td>20</td><td>20.0</td><td>5</td><td>0.3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Unique identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>Name of a property entry, such as “PBAR",“PBEAM", etc. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Property entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PNAME/FID</td><td>Property name, such as “T", “A", or field position of the property entry, or word position in the element property table of the analysis model. Property names that begin with an integer such as 12I/T**3 may only be referred to by field position. (Character or Integer ≠ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PMIN</td><td>Minimum value alowed for this property. If PMIN references a property that can only be positive, then the default value for PMIN is 1.0E-15. Otherwise, it is - 1.0E35. See Remark 6. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>PMAX</td><td>Maximum value allowed for this property. (Real; Default = 1.0E+20)</td></tr><tr><td>C0</td><td>Constant term of relation. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>DVIDi</td><td>DESVAR entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COEFi</td><td>Coefficient of linear relation or keyword = “PVAL". See Remark 7. (If i = 1, Real or Character; if i > 1, Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The relationship between the analysis model property and design variables is given by  

$$
\mathrm{P_{j}=C_{0}+\sum_{i}C O E F_{i}\cdot X_{D V I D_{i}}}
$$  

2. The continuation entry is required.  

3.TYPE $\mathbf{\sigma}_{\cdot}=\mathbf{\sigma}$ "PBEND" is not supported. TYPE $\c=$ “PBEAML” supports only PNAME and not FID.  

4. FID may be either a positive or a negative number. If $\mathrm{FID}>0$ , it identifies the field position on a property entry. If $\mathrm{FID}<0$ , it identifies the word position of an entry in the element property table. For example, to specify the area of a PBAR, either PNAME $\scriptstyle\cdot=\mathrm{A}$ 。 $\mathrm{FID}=+4$ or $\mathrm{FID}=-3$ can be used. In general, use of PNAME is recommended. For Type "PBUSH", PNAME is recommended, if FID is used it must be $<0$ ·  

5. Designing PBEAML or PBEAM requires specification of both property name and station. Table 14 shows several examples.  

Table 14   


<html><body><table><tr><td>PTYPE</td><td>Property Name</td><td>END A</td><td>END B</td><td>i-th Station</td></tr><tr><td>PBEAML</td><td>DIM1</td><td>DIM1 or DIM1(A)</td><td>DIM1(B)</td><td>DIM1(i)</td></tr><tr><td>PBEAM</td><td>A</td><td>A or A(A)</td><td>A(B)</td><td>A(i)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Only stations that are input on a PBEAM or PBEAML entry can be referenced by a DVPREL1. For example, referencing an END B property name on a DVPREL1 entry when the referenced PBEAM does not explicitly specify the END B station, is not allowed.  

6. The default values of PMIN and PMAX are not applied when the linear property is a function of a single design variable and $\scriptstyle\sum0=0$ . It is expected that the limits applied on the DESVAR entry will keep the designed property within reasonable bounds.  

7. When "PVAL" is used for the COEFl field, this is a flag to indicate that the COEFl value is to be obtained from the property bulk data entry. If a DVPRELl entry references more than one design variable with the PVAL option, a User Fatal Message will be issued.  

8. With GPLY for TYPE field and GPLYID for PID field, a ply identified with GPLYID across all PCOMPG entries in the model can be designed. Internally, a DVPRELl willbe spawned for each PCOMPG has a ply ID of GPLYID. For TYPE $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\lambda}}=$ GPLY, the relationship between the analysis model property and design variables is given by.  

$$
\mathrm{\DeltaP_{i}~=~\mathrm{{CO}+(\mathrm{{T0}_{i}\ o r\mathrm{{THETA0}_{i})\cdot\sum_{j}(\mathrm{{COEF}_{j}\cdot\mathrm{{X}_{D V I D_{j}})}}}}}}
$$  

Where $\mathrm{\DeltaT0}$ and THETAO are value of thickness and theta angle on the original PCOMPG. Note that non-zero $\mathrm{C0}$ is not recommended for TYPE $\v{r}_{\mathbf{\lambda}}=$ GPLY or PCOMPG. For THETA0 with original value equal to 0.0, THETA0 is taken as 1.0 and it is recommended to have XINIT of DVID set to 0.0.

<html><body><table><tr><td>DVSHAP</td><td>2</td><td>1</td><td>2.0</td><td>4</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>DVID</td><td>Design variable identification number on the DESVAR entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COLi</td><td>Column number of the displacement matrix. See Remark 2. (1 ≤ Integer ≤ maximum column number in the displacement matrix.)</td></tr><tr><td>SFi</td><td>Scaling factor applied to the COLi-th column of the displacement matrix. (Real; Default = 1.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. DVID must be defined on a DESVAR entry.   
2. COLi must be a valid column number in the displacement matrix.   
3. Multiple references to the same DVID and/or COLi will result in a linear combination of displacement vectors. In the example above, the shape basis vector is a linear combination of the fourth column and twice the second column.   
4. The displacement matrix must have been created by SOL 101 or 200 with analysis $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ statics and be available on a database, which is attached via the DBLOCATE FMS statement shown below: ASSIGN DISPMAT $\mathbf{\mu}=\mathbf{\prime}$ physical filename of MASTER DBset ‘ DBLOCATE DATABLK $\c=$ (UG/UGD,GEOM1/GEOM1D,GEOM2/GEOM2D）， LOGICAL $\c=$ DISPMAT
