<html><body><table><tr><td> Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NAMES</td><td>User defined name identifying the submodel. (Character; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>GRIDSET</td><td>Identification number of a SET1 entry that has a list of Grid Point Force grids to include in defining the subsystem. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>ELEMSET</td><td>Identification number of a SET1 entry that has a list of elements to include in the system (Integer > O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>XFLAG</td><td>Exclusion flag. Exclude the indicated Grid Point Force types.</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="6"></td><td>Default</td><td>Blank (no type excluded)</td></tr><tr><td>S</td><td>SPC forces</td></tr><tr><td>M</td><td>MPC forces</td></tr><tr><td>A, L, or P</td><td>Applied loads</td></tr><tr><td>D</td><td>DMIG's (and any other type not described above)</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">Label An optional string of up to 64 characters (fields 2 through 9) that identifies the</td></tr></table></body></html>  

subsystem.  

Remarks:  

1. Only those Grid Point Forces which have both an included grid point and element (or Grid Poini Force type) will be taken into account.  

2. If ELEMSET is blank, no contributions are made from the set of elements atached to the grid.  

3. Fictitious grids or elements do not produce error or warning messages.  

4. The XFLAG data can be any combination of the letters S,M,A,L,P and D (e.g., MAD).  

5. The continuation is optional.  

Defines a finite element edge and associates it with a curve.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FEEDGE</td><td>EDGEID</td><td>GRID1</td><td>GRID2</td><td>CIDBC</td><td>GEOMIN</td><td>ID1</td><td>ID2</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FEEDGE</td><td>101</td><td>123</td><td>547</td><td>GMCURV</td><td>12</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="3">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>EDGEID</td><td>Unique identification number.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>GRIDi</td><td>Identification number of end GRIDs defining this edge.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>CIDBC</td><td>Identification number of the coordinate system in which constraints specified on GMBC and GMSPC entries are defined. See Remark 1.</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>GEOMIN</td><td>Type of entry referenced by IDi; “GMCURV" or“POINT". Character See Remark 2.</td><td></td><td>POINT</td></tr><tr><td>IDi</td><td>Identification number ofa POINT or GMCURV entry. See Integer ≥ 0 Remarks 2., 3., and 4.</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. If CIDBC is not blank then it overrides the CIDBC specified on the GMSURF or FEFACE entries for this particular edge. A fatal message willbe issued when more than one CIDBC is associated with any entity.  

2. The Bulk Data entries referenced by ID1 and ID2 depends on the GEOMIN field:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>GEOMIN</td><td>ID1</td><td>ID2</td></tr><tr><td>POINT</td><td>POINT</td><td>POINT</td></tr><tr><td>GMCURV</td><td>GMCURV</td><td> not applicable</td></tr></table></body></html>  

3.When GEOMIN $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ “GMCURV"  

$\cdot$ FEEDGE associates the finite element model and the geometric information. $\cdot\cdot$ GRID1 and GRID2 are the end points of the edge, and the edge is on the CURVID curve. A localy parametric cubic curve is fit to the geometric curve such that the two have the same tangent at GRIDi (C1 continuous).  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/c61d46d814482964774b0961b0d9f4e0a7bae4f7ee62748f9a185cf97eeace07.jpg)  
Figure 9-91 Specifying Geometry Using GEOMIN $\scriptstyle|=$ GMCURVMethod  

4. When GEOMIN $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ “POINT”  

The edge passes through the points defined on the POINT entries referenced by IDl and ID2. ●The shape of the edge is selected as follows:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>ID1</td><td>ID2</td><td>Shape of theFEEDGE</td></tr><tr><td>Blank or 0</td><td>Blank or 0</td><td>Linear</td></tr><tr><td>>0</td><td>Blank or 0</td><td>Quadratic</td></tr><tr><td>>0</td><td>>0</td><td>Cubic</td></tr><tr><td>Blank or 0</td><td>>0</td><td>Not allowed</td></tr></table></body></html>  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/63e383c2606bd491b6333a3a7f5e9042de1c8b57f2f1f8f7955f091cd0645a17.jpg)  
Figure 9-92 Specifying Geometry Using GEOMIN $\vDash$ POINTMethod  

5. A local coordinate system can be associated with an edge using the GMCORD entry. 6. The hierarchy set to resolve the conflicts arising in the Global System input data is described under Remark 10 of the GMBC, 2072 entry description.  

Defines geometric information that willbe used in elements, surface definition, load definition, and boundary condition definition.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FEFACE</td><td>FACEID</td><td>GRID1</td><td>GRID2</td><td>GRID3</td><td>GRID4</td><td>CIDBC</td><td>SURFID</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FEFACE</td><td>101</td><td>123</td><td>547</td><td>243</td><td>295</td><td>12</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="3">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>FACEID</td><td>Unique identification number. See Remark 1.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>GRIDi</td><td>Identification number of end GRIDs defining a triangular or quadrilateral face. See Remark 2.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>CIDBC</td><td>Identification number of the coordinate system in which constraints specified on GMBC and GMSPC entries are defined. See Remark 3.</td><td> Integer ≥ 0</td><td>Remark 3.</td></tr><tr><td>SURFID</td><td>Alternate method used to specify the geometry of the Integer ≥ 0 edges of the face. See Remarks 4. and 5.</td><td></td><td>0</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. An FEFACE entry is required if any of the following situations exist:  

· The geometry of the surface defined by SURFID is to be used by a finite element; · CIDBC is specified for a face or surface; or ● If loads or constraints or enforced boundary conditions are applied to a surface.  

2.The shape(geometry)of the face is defined by the shape of the edges. The points defined by GRID must be specified in either a clockwise or counterclockwise order.  

3. If CIDBC is not blank, then it overrides the CIDBC specified on the GMSURF entry for this particular face. A fatal message will be issued when more than one CIDBC is associated with any entity.  

4. When SURFID is blank or O,the edges will be considered linear unless there is an FEEDGE entry for the given edge.  

5. When SURFID $>0$  

FEFACE associates the finite element model and the geometric information specified on the GMSURF entry.  

GRIDi defines a finite element face (clockwise or counter clockwise in order) that is on the SURFID surface.   
For the edges of this face, which are not defined by an FEEDGE entry, locally parametric cubic curves are fit to the geometric surface such that the two have the same tangent at GRIDi (C1 continuous).  

6.Whenever a given edge of a face is common to two or more surfaces (i.e., lies on the intersecting curve),then the user must supply GMCURV and FEEDGE entries in order to resolve the conflict in the input geometry. A fatal message is issued if an edge is not uniquely defined.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/623e9c51734feb6d02e3f6d1735ec959b9093310b8f62036a8012762337dff07.jpg)  
Figure 9-93 Face Edge Common to Two Surfaces  

7. The hierarchy set to resolve the conflicts arising in the Global System input data is described undei Remark 10 of the GMBC, 2072 entry description.  

Defines the pressure within a closed volume. Intended for the use in (partially) filled containers, where dynamic fluid effects are negligible, e.g. top loading and hot filling. Used in SOL 700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FFCONTR</td><td>FFID</td><td>SID</td><td>FVOL</td><td>PATM</td><td>TEMPTAB</td><td>DENSTAB</td><td>TACTIVE</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FFCONTR</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>1.50E-03</td><td>0.1E6</td><td>10</td><td>20</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>FFID</td><td>Unique FFCONTR identification number. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Number of a BSURF, BCBOX, BCPROP, BCMATL or BCSEG entry defining the closed surface. (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>FVOL</td><td>Fluid volume in the container. (Real ≥ 0.0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>PATM</td><td>Atmospheric pressure. Used for determination of the constant C for p : V = C . (Real > 0.0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>TEMPTAB</td><td>A reference to a TABLED1 ID that specifies how temperature of the container changes in time. (Integer ≥ 0; Blank)</td></tr><tr><td>DENSTAB</td><td>A reference to a TABLED1 ID that specifies how density of the container changes with temperature. (Integer ≥ O; Blank)</td></tr><tr><td>TACTIVE</td><td>Time at which the pressure computation of the bottle is started. Until this time the pressure inside the bottle equals the ambient pressure. The volume of the bottle at TACTIVE will be used for the initial pressure computation of the gas in the bottle.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. If TEMPTAB is not set, the gas above the fluid is assumed to be an ideal, iso-thermal gas: $p\cdot V=C$ ， where $C$ is a constant. If TEMPTAB is set, the temperature is applied to both the fluid as well as the gas. Then the gas satisfies $p\cdot V/T=C$ ,where $T$ is the temperature of the fluid.   
2. The fluid is assumed incompressible.   
3.The pressure is based on the uniform pressure gasbag algorithm, where the pressure is uniform in the volume, but variable in time.   
4.Output for the fluid-filled container is available through a SURFOUT definition. The available variables are: PRESSURE, VOLUME, TEMPTURE, VOLGAS, VOLFLUID, GAUGEPRES and RHOFLUID.   
5. The normals of the surface referenced by SID are reversed automatically if required.  

6. Modeling guidelines are described in the“Getting Started” Section.  

7. If DENSTAB is set then volume of the fluid changes according to  

$$
V^{F l u i d}=\frac{\uprho(T_{0})V_{0}^{F l u i d}}{\uprho(T)}
$$  

Here To and VFluid are initial values for temperature and fluid volume, $\uprho$ is the fluid density and T denotes the current temperature. If TEMPTAB is not set the DENSTAB entry will not be used.  

8.At time $\c=$ TACTIVE the gas is assumed to be in contact with the ambient pressure for the last time. This means that at Time $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ TACTIVE the pressure in the bottle equals the ambient pressure. After TACTIVE the botte has been closed and there is no longer contact between ambient and gas inside the bottle.Any change in volume of the bottle or temperature or fluid will result in change of pressure of the gas inside the bottle.  

Used to specify density ratios, Mach numbers, reduced frequencies, and velocities for flutter analysis.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FLFACT</td><td>SID</td><td>F1</td><td>F2</td><td>F3 F4</td><td>F5</td><td>F6</td><td>F7</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>F8</td><td>F9</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FLFACT</td><td>97</td><td>.3</td><td>.7</td><td>3.5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Alternate Format and Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FLFACT</td><td>SID</td><td>F1</td><td>“THRU”</td><td>FNF</td><td>NF</td><td>FMID</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>FLFACT</td><td>201</td><td>.200</td><td>THRU</td><td>.100</td><td>11</td><td>.133333</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Unique Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Fi</td><td>Aerodynamic factor. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>FNF</td><td>Final aerodynamic factor. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>NF</td><td>Number of aerodynamic factors. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>FMID</td><td>Intermediate aerodynamic factors. See Remark 4. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Only the factors selected by a FLUTTER entry will be used.   
2. Embedded blank fields are not allowed in the first format above.   
3.Thefactors must be specified in the order in which they are to be used within the looping of flutte analysis.   
4. FMID must lie between $F1$ and $F N F$ ; otherwise, FMID will be set to $(F1+F N F)/2$ . Then $F i={\frac{F1(F N F-F M I D)(N F-i)+F N F(F M I D-F1)(i-1)}{(F N F-F M I D)(N F-i)+(F M I D-F1)(i-1)}}$ where $i\ =1,2,...,N F$ The use of FMID (middle factor selection) allows unequal spacing of the factors.  

$F M I D=\frac{2\cdot F1\cdot F N F}{F1+F N F}$ FI+FNFgivesequalvaluestoincremntsofthereciprocal of $F i$ ， 5. If method $={\mathrm{PK}}$ and this entry specifies velocities, then the velocities must be non-zero. Input of negative values produces eigenvector results at a velocity equal to the positive value of the input. Input of positive values provide eigenvalues results without eigenvectors.  

Defines the properties of a material for the boundaries of an Eulerian mesh. Used in SOL 700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7 8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>FLOW</td><td>LID</td><td>BCID</td><td>MESH</td><td>DIR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>XMIN</td><td>XMAX</td><td>YMIN</td><td>YMAX</td><td>ZMIN ZMAX</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TYPE1</td><td>VALUE1</td><td>TYPE2</td><td>VALUE2 TYPE3</td><td>VALUE3</td><td>TYPE4</td><td>VALUE4</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TYPE5</td><td>VALUE5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FLOW 120</td><td>122</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>XVEL</td><td>100.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>LID</td><td colspan="2">Number of a set of flow boundary conditions. (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>BCID</td><td colspan="2">Number of a set of segments, specified by BCSEG entries, where the flow boundary is located. See Remark 5. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MESH</td><td colspan="2">Denotes the ID of the Euler mesh to which the boundary condition has to be applied.</td></tr><tr><td>DIR</td><td colspan="2">See Remark 6. (Integer ≥ 0) Allowed values are: NEGX, POSX, NEGY, POSY, NEGZ and POSZ. See Remark 7.</td></tr><tr><td>XMIN-ZMAX</td><td colspan="2">(Character) Defines a square by specifying the ranges of the x,y,z coordinates. For a square in for example the x-plane it is required that either XMIN = XMAX or that XMAX is left</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="7">TYPEi</td><td colspan="2">blank. See Remark 8. (Real) The flow boundary property being defined. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td>Material</td><td>The MATDEUL ID number.</td></tr><tr><td>XVEL</td><td>The material velocity in the x-direction.</td></tr><tr><td>YVEL</td><td>The material velocity in the y-direction.</td></tr><tr><td>ZVEL</td><td>The material velocity in the z-direction.</td></tr><tr><td>PRESSURE</td><td>The pressure of the material at the boundary.</td></tr><tr><td>DENSITY</td><td>The density of the material at inflow.</td></tr><tr><td>SIE</td><td>The specific internal energy at inflow</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="2">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="5">VALUEi</td><td>FLOW</td><td>The type of flow boundary required.</td></tr><tr><td>HYDSTAT</td><td> A Hydrostatic pressure profile using a HYDSTAT entry.</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">The value for the property defined. (Real; Integer or Character; Required) For TYPEi set to FLOW, the value is a character entry being either IN, OUT, BOTH or SYM defining that the flow boundary is defined as an inflow, outflow, possibly an in-</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">or outflow or symmetry boundary. The default is BOTH. VALUEi is required data only if one or more of the TYPEi entries are defined. The TYPEi entries are not required. Thus, a flow boundary by default allows for in- or outflow of the material adjacent to the boundary.</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">For TYPE = HYDSTAT, the value is an integer entry denoting the HYDSTAT entry to be used.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. LID must be referenced by a TLOAD1 entry.   
2. Any material properties not specifically defined have the same value as the element with the flow boundary condition.   
3. TLOAD entries referencing FLOW entries must have the TID field blank or zero.   
4.In the case of material flow into a multi-material Euler mesh, the density and specific energy have to be set.On the other hand when material flows out of a multi-material Euler mesh it is assumed that each of the materials present in the outflow Euler element contributes to the out flow of mass. The materials are transported in proportion to their relative volume fractions.   
5. BCID is optional. If used, allother inputs are ignored. If not used, the flow boundary can be defined by either using DIR or by using XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, etc.   
6. The MESH-ID is only used when multiple Euler domains have been defined and when BCID is blank. If multiple Euler domains have been defined but if the MESH-ID is blank all Euler domains will be considered in assigning the boundary condition.   
7.DIR is optional. It willonly be used when BCID is blank. When DIR is used XMIN, XMAX, YMIN etc. are ignored.   
8. XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, etc.are only used when both BCID and DIR are blank. If neither the MIN nor MAX value has been set the default value is respectively $-1\mathrm{E}\substack{+20}$ and $1\mathrm{E}{+}20$ for the MIN and MAX value. If the MIN value has been set the default value of the MAX value is the Min value.   
9. Prescribing both pressure and velocity may lead to the instabilities.   
10.For $\mathrm{TYPE}=\mathrm{HYDSTAT}$ the pressure is set using HYDSTAT, the velocity equals the element velocity.In case of inflow the density follows from the hydrostatic pressure by using the equation of state.  

# Cyclic Flow Boundary Condition  

Defines the properties of a material for the boundaries of a Eulerian mesh.  

Inflow values can be taken from another boundary condition. This allows cyclic or periodic boundary conditions. Likewise, the outflow of material goes into the other boundary condition.  

FLOWCentries have to be defined in pairs.The FID on one entry has to be equal to FID2 of the other entry. For example  

FLOWC,10,30,20   
FLOWC,20,40,10  

For FLOWC boundaries, mass flow summaries can be created as time history. Used in SOL700 only  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>８</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>FLOWC</td><td>FID</td><td>BCID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>MESH</td><td>DIR</td><td>FID2</td><td></td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>XMIN</td><td>XMAX</td><td>YMIN</td><td>YMAX</td><td>ZMIN</td><td>ZMAX</td><td></td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>METHOD</td><td>TID</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FLOWC</td><td>1</td><td>122</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>2</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Field </td><td>Contents</td></tr><tr><td>FID</td><td>Unique number of a FLOWC entry. (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>BCID</td><td>Number of a set of segments specified by the BCSEG entries where the flow boundary is located. See Remark 3. (Integer > 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td colspan="2"></td></tr><tr><td>Field </td><td>Contents</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">TYPE</td><td>Flow boundary types. See Remarks 2.and 3. (Character; Required) IN: Only inflow is allowed. The inflow velocity and pressure can be optionally specified</td></tr><tr><td>If not given, the values in the adjacent Euler element will be used. The same holds for the density and sie.</td></tr><tr><td>OUT: Only outflow is allowed. The inflow velocity and pressure can be optionally specified. If not given, the values in the adjacent Euler element willbe used. The outflow boundary will always use material mixture as present in the adjacent Euler element.</td></tr><tr><td>BOTH: Material is allowed to flow in or out. In or outflow is based on the direction o the velocity in the adjacent Euler element. Only pressure can be optionally defined. If not given the pressure in the adjacent Euler element will be taken.</td></tr><tr><td>MESH</td><td>Denotes the ID of the Euler mesh to which the boundary condition has to be applied. See Remark 4. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>DIR</td><td>Allowed values are: NEGX, POSX, NEGY, POSY, NEGZ and POSZ. See Remark 5. (Character; no default)</td></tr><tr><td>FID2</td><td>Referenced FLOWC id from which inflow and outflow values will be taken from. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>XMIN-ZMAX</td><td>Defines a square by specifying the ranges of the x,y,z coordinates. For a square in for example the x-plane it is required that either XMIN = XMAX or that XMAX is left blank. See Remark 6. (Real))</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">METHOD</td><td>Method describing how material properties and pressure are mapped going from one boundary to the other. (Integer > O; Default=1)</td></tr><tr><td>1. Map both velocity, material flow properties, and pressure loads one-to-one.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Map velocity, material flow one-to-one. Pressure is given by element pressures. 3. Inflow is taken as the average of outflow properties. This applies to both velocity</td></tr><tr><td> and material properties. Pressure is given by element pressures.</td></tr><tr><td>TID</td><td>TABLED1 ID that specifies a time dependent scale factor by which the amount of inflow is multiplied. This will not conserve total mass. (Integer > O. Default = not used)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. LID must be referenced by a TLOAD1 entry.   
2. TLOAD entries referencing FLOW entries must have the TID field blank or zero.   
3.BCID is optional. If used, allother inputs are ignored. If not used, the flow boundary can be defined by either using DIR or by using XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, etc.   
4. The MESH-ID is only used when multiple Euler domains have been defined and when BCID is blank. If multiple Euler domains have been defined but if the MESH-ID is blank all Euler domains will be considered in assigning the boundary condition.  

). VIK is optional. It will only De used wnen BUID is Dlank. Wnen DIK Is usea XMlIN, XIMAX, YIMIIN etc. are ignored.  

6. XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, etc.are only used when both BCID and DIR are blank. If neither the MIN nor MAX value has been set the default value is respectively $-1\mathrm{E}\mathopen{}\mathclose\bgroup\left(20$ and $1\mathrm{E}{+}20$ for the MIN and MAX value.If the MIN value has been set the default value of the MAX value is the Min value.   
7. FLOWC can be used to specify flow boundaries for CHEXA's and also for Euler element created by the MESH,BOX option.   
8. FLOWC is only supported by the multi-material Euler solver.   
9. To enable using the outflow values of FID2 as the inflow values for FID, the boundary faces of FID and FID2 are mapped onto each other.For this mapping, only translations and rotations around coordinate axes are permitted.   
10.Consider a cubic Euler mesh and that material flows from the left to the right.At the right side, the boundary condition is imposed FLOWC,4,30,5 and at the left side FLOWC,5,40,4 These definitions cause all material that flows out of the right side boundary into the left side boundary.Moreover, the Euler element pressures on the right side are put on the Euler elements of the left boundary condition. In practice, it may be useful to skip the coupling between the two boundaries with regard to pressure. This can be done by setting METHOD equal to 2. With these definitions, material from boundary 4 stillflows into boundary 5 but pressure boundaries are transmitting.   
11.TID is useful if several objects have identical outflow that is used as inflow by another object. Then only one object has to be modeled. To account for the other objects when defining inflow, the scale factor can be used. It can also be used to turn offin and outflow. When TID is set, either METHOD $^{\dag=2}$ or METHOD $^{-3}$ are recommended and METHOD $^{\prime=1}$ should not be used.   
12.It is alowed that the definition of the FLOWC entry overlaps with FLOW definitions. In that case, the FLOWC definition overrules the other ones  

Definition of default Eulerian flow boundary condition. Used in SOL 700 only.

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7 8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FLOWDEF</td><td>FID</td><td></td><td>TYPEM</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TYPE1</td><td>VALUE1</td><td>TYPE2</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>

1.If this entry is not specified, a default wall boundary condition is applied to all Eulerian free faces.   
2. For $\mathrm{TYPE}=\mathrm{HYDSTAT}$ the pressure is set using HYDSTAT, the velocity equals the element velocity. In case of inflow the density follows from the hydrostatic pressure by using the equation of state. Remarks:  

1. LID must be referenced by a TLOADl entry.   
2. TLOAD entries referencing FLOW entries must have the TID field blank or zero.  

3.BCID is optional.If used, allother inputs are ignored. If not used, theflow boundary can be defined by either using DIR or by using XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, etc.   
4. The MESH-ID is only used when multiple Euler domains have been defined and when BCID is blank.If multiple Euler domains have been defined but if the MESH-ID is blank all Euler domains will be considered in assigning the boundary condition.   
5. DIR is optional. It will only be used when BCID is blank. When DIR is used XMIN, XMAX, YMIN etc. are ignored.   
6. XMIN, XMAX, YMIN,etc.are only used when both BCID and DIR are blank. If neither the MIN nor MAX value has been set the default value is respectively $-1\mathrm{E}+20$ and $1\mathrm{E}{+}20$ for the MIN and MAX value. If the MIN value has been set the default value of the MAX value is the Min value.   
7. Any material properties not specifically defined have the same value as the element that with the boundary conditions.   
8.In the case of material flow into a multi-material Euler mesh,the material number, the density and specific energy have to be set.On the other hand when material flows out of a multi-material Euler mesh it is assumed that each of the materials present in the outflow Euler element contributes to the out flow of mass. The materials are transported in proportion to their relative volume fractions   
9.The boundary condition initiates/determines a wave in compressible materialike gas and water. This can be either an outgoing or an ingoing wave. For stability it is important that the waves created are compatible with the flow type near the boundary. Relevant flow types are subsonic inflow, subsonic outflow,supersonic inflow and supersonic outflow. For example for subsonic inflow prescribing both pressure and velocity would initiate outgoing waves. Outgoing waves for an inflow boundary condition is known to be instable.However,for supersonic inflow one can specify both pressure and velocities there are no outgoing waves at a supersonic inflow boundary.  

Defines a flow boundary on an Eulerian mesh specified by a user subroutine. Use in SOL700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FLOWUDS</td><td>LID</td><td>GROUP</td><td>UNAME</td><td>BCID</td><td>MESH</td><td>DIR</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>XMIN</td><td>XMAX</td><td>YMIN</td><td>YMAX</td><td>ZMIN</td><td>ZMAX</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>

CONNECT SERVICE myflow 'sCA.MDSolver.Obj.Uds.Dytran.Flow In Bulk Data:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FLOWUDS</td><td>12</td><td>MYFLOW</td><td>EXFLOW</td><td>300</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>LID</td><td>Unique output number. (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>GROUP</td><td>The group name used for the FMS section CONNECT SERVICE statement. (Character; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>UNAME</td><td>User subroutine name associated with the entry. (Character; default=EXFLOW)</td></tr><tr><td>BCID</td><td>Number of a set of segments, specified by BCSEG entries, where the flow boundary is located. See Remark 6. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MESH</td><td>Denotes the ID of the Euler mesh to which the boundary condition has to be applied See Remark 7. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>DIR</td><td>Allowed values are: NEGX, POSX, NEGY, POSY, NEGZ and POSZ. See Remark 8. (Character)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>XMIN-ZMAX Defines a square by specifying the ranges of the x,y,z coordinates.For a square in for example the x-plane it is required that either XMIN = XMAX or that XMAX is left blank. See Remark 9. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Only can be used for SOL 700.  

2. UNAME can be:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Subroutine Name</td><td> Function </td></tr><tr><td>EXFLOW</td><td>Standard user defined flow boundary on the Euler mesh</td></tr></table></body></html>  

3. For multi material models EXFLOW allows for the definition of any material to flow into the Eulerian mesh. The outflow can only be of materials present in the mesh.   
4. TLOAD1 entries referencing FLOWUDS entries must have the TID field blank or zero.   
5. BCID is optional. If used, allother inputs are ignored.If not used, the flow boundary can be defined by either using DIR or by using XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, etc.   
6. The MESH-ID is only used when multiple Euler domains have been defined and when BCID is blank. If multiple Euler domains have been defined but if the MESH-ID is blank all Euler domains will be considered in assigning the boundary condition.   
7. DIR is optional. It willonly be used when BCID is blank. When DIR is used XMIN, XMAX, YMIN etc. are ignored.   
8. XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, etc.are only used when both BCID and DIR are blank. If neither the MIN nor MAX value has been set the default value is respectively $-1\mathrm{E}\substack{+20}$ and $1\mathrm{E}{+}20$ for the MIN and MAX value. If the MIN value has been set the default value of the MAX value is the MIN value.  

Defines the relationship between the axisymmetric fluid and a structural boundary having symmetric constraints.The purpose is to allow fluid boundary matrices to conform to structural symmetry definitions.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>FLSYM</td><td>M</td><td>S1</td><td>S2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FLSYM</td><td>12</td><td>S</td><td>A</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>M</td><td>Number of symmetric sections of structural boundary around the circumference of the fluid being modeled by the set of structural elements. (Even Integers ≥ 2)</td></tr><tr><td>S1,S2</td><td>Description of boundary constraints used on the structure at the first and second planes of symmetry. (Character: “S" means symmetric, “A" means antisymmetric.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. This entry is allowed only if an AXIF entry is also present.   
2. Only one FLSYM entry is allowed.   
3. This entry is not required if there are no planes of symmetry.   
4. First plane of symmetry is assumed to be at $\phi=0$ . Second plane of symmetry is assumed to be at $\Phi\:=\:360^{\circ}/M$ ，   
5. Symmetric and antisymmetric constraints for the structure must, in addition, be provided by the user.   
6. The solution is performed for those harmonic indices listed on the AXIF entry that are compatible with the symmetry conditions.   
7. For example, if FLSYM is used to model a quarter section of structure at the boundary, $\mathrm{M}=4$ . If the boundary constraints are $^{\mathrm{{e}}}\mathrm{{S}}\mathrm{{S}}^{\mathrm{{,}\mathrm{{,}}}}$ , the compatible cosine harmonics are 0, 2, 4,..., etc. If $^{\mathrm{s}}\mathrm{SA}^{\mathrm{*}}$ is used, the compatible cosine harmonics are 1, 3, 5, ..., etc.  

Defines data needed to perform flutter analysis.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FLUTTER</td><td>SID</td><td>METHOD</td><td>DENS</td><td>MACH</td><td>RFREQ</td><td>IMETH</td><td>NVALUE/ OMAX</td><td>EPS</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FLUTTER</td><td>19</td><td>K</td><td>119</td><td>219</td><td>319</td><td>S</td><td>5</td><td>1.-4</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0) Flutter analysis method. (Character: “K"for K method, “PK" for PK method,“PKNL"</td></tr><tr><td>METHOD</td><td>for PK method with no looping, “PKS" for PK sweep method, “PKNLS" for PK sweep method with no looping,“KE" for the K method restricted for efficiency.) See Remark 9.</td></tr><tr><td>DENS</td><td>Identification number of an FLFACT entry specifying density ratios to be used in flutter analysis. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>MACH</td><td>Identification number of an FLFACT entry specifying Mach numbers (m） to be used in flutter analysis. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>RFREQ (or VEL)</td><td>Identification number of an FLFACT entry specifying reduced frequencies (k) to be used in flutter analysis; for the“PKx" methods, the velocities FLFACT entry is specified in this field. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>IMETH</td><td>Choice of interpolation method for aerodynamic matrix interpolation. See Remark 6. (Character: “L”= linear, “S” = surface; “TCUB"= termwise cubic; Default =“L".)</td></tr><tr><td>NVALUE</td><td>Number of eigenvalues beginning with the first eigenvalue for output and plots. (Integer > O; Default is the number of modal degrees-of-freedom (uh).)</td></tr><tr><td>OMAX</td><td>For the PKS and PKNLS methods, OMAX specifies the maximum frequency, in Hz., to be used in he flutter sweep. (Real > 0.0; Default = maximum normal mode</td></tr><tr><td>EPS</td><td>eigenfrequency) Convergence parameter for k. Used in the PK and PKNL methods only. See Remark 4. (Real > 0.0; Default = 10-3 .) See Remark 9. for the meaning of EPS when the PKS or PKNLS methods are being used.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The FLUTTER entry must be selected with the Case Control command FMETHOD $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ SID. 2. The density is given by DENS $\cdot\cdot$ RHOREF , where RHOREF is the reference value specified on the AERO entry and DENS is the density ratio specified on the FLFACT entry.  

3.The reduced frequency is given by $k=(R E F C\cdot\upomega/2\cdot V)$ , where REFC is given on the AERO entry, @ is the circular frequency, and $V$ is the velocity. If $k=0.0$ , as specified on the FLFACT entry, then only the K method may be specified and the Inverse Power method of eigenvalue extraction (INV on the EIGC entry) must be used. Aeroelastic divergence analysis is more appropriately performed using one of the “PKx” methods.  

4. For the PK and PKNL methods, an eigenvalue is accepted when:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}&{\left|k-k_{e s t i m a t e}\right|<E P S}&{\mathrm{for~}k_{e s t i m a t e}<1.0}\\ &{\left|k-k_{e s t i m a t e}\right|<E P S\cdot k_{e s t i m a t}\mathrm{for~}k_{e s t i m a t e}\geq1.0}\end{array}
$$  

5.When one of the“PKx"methods is selected, physical displacements willonly be generated for the velocities on the FLFACT that are specified as negative values of the requested velocity. Also, structural damping as specified on the GE field of MATi entries is ignored.   
6.If $\mathrm{IMETH}=^{\mathrm{{\sc_{C}}}}\mathrm{L}^{\mathrm{{\scriptsize{,}}}}$ , a linear interpolation is performed on reduced frequencies at the Mach numbers specified on the FLFACT entry using the MKAEROi entry Mach number that is closest to the FLFACT entry Mach number. For $\mathrm{IMETH}=^{\ast}{\mathrm{S}}^{\ast}$ , a surface interpolation is performed across Mach numbers and reduced frequencies. For $\mathrm{IMETH}=\mathrm{^{\circ}T C U B^{\prime\prime}}$ a termwise cubic interpolation on reduced frequency is used. $\mathrm{IMETH}=^{\ast}{\mathrm{S}}^{\ast}$ is only available for the $\"\mathrm{K}^{\prime\prime}$ and “KE” flutter methods. $\mathrm{IMETH}=\mathrm{^{\infty}T C U B^{\mathrm{^{\circ}}}}$ is only available for the“PKx” methods. For the“PKx" methods, $\mathrm{IMETH}=^{\mathrm{{\sc.}}}{\mathrm{S}}^{\mathrm{{\sc,}}}$ or $^{\mathfrak{e}}\mathrm{L}^{\mathfrak{p}}$ or blank provides linear interpolation while“TCUB" provides a termwise cubic interpolation.   
7. For the° $\mathrm{\ddot{K}}^{\mathrm{\'}}$ ‘， $\mathrm{\backslashKE^{\prime\prime}}$ ,“PK”, and $\mathrm{^{*}P K S^{\mathrm{*}}}$ methods, all combinations of the FLFACT entry are analyzed. For the“PKNL" and “PKNLS" methods, only ordered pairs are analyzed; i.e., $(\mathsf{p}_{1},M_{1},V_{1})$ ， $(\uprho_{2},M_{2},V_{2})...(\uprho_{n},M_{n},V_{n})$ . For the PKNL and PKNLS methods, equal number of densities, Mach numbers and velocities must be specified.   
8． $\"\mathrm{K}\"\$ and $^{\mathrm{\tiny{s}}}\mathrm{KE}^{\mathrm{\tiny{3}}}$ methods are not supported for design sensitivity and optimization.   
9.The PKS and PKNLS methods determine flutter eigenvalues by performing a sweep of equally spaced reduced frequencies ranging from $k_{e s t}=0.0$ through $k_{e s t}=\pi$ · REFC $\cdot\cdot$ OMAX/Velocity . The number of intervals is calculated using $\mathrm{NINT}=\mathrm{INT}(1.0/\mathrm{EPS})$  

10.  

The PK method uses only real matrix terms for computing the flutter solution. This means any imaginary terms in any of the matrices, M, B, or K are ignored with the PK method and the imaginary part of the aerodynamic matrix is added as a real matrix to the viscous damping matrix B.   
For the KE method, the B matrix is ignored while complex stiffnessforms of structural damping are supported. Modal viscous damping (TABDMP1 input) wil be included when the KDAMP parameter is set to -1.   
.The K method supports allforms of damping.  

11．METHOD $\mathrm{\Omega_{=K}}$ requires a CMETHOD in Case Control pointing to an EIGC Bulk Data entry. It is recommended that the number of roots requested on the EIGC entry be twice the number of normal modes used in the modal flutter analysis.  

Defines a static concentrated force at a grid point by specifying a vector.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FORCE</td><td>SID</td><td>G</td><td>CID</td><td>F</td><td>N1</td><td>N2</td><td>N3</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FORCE</td><td>2</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>2.9</td><td>0.0</td><td>1.0</td><td>0.0</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>Grid point identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td>Coordinate system identification number. (Integer ≥ O; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>F</td><td>Scale factor. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>Ni</td><td>Components of a vector measured in coordinate system defined by CID. (Real; at least one Ni ≠ 0.0.unless F is zero)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The static force applied to grid point G is given by  

$$
\stackrel{\triangledown}{\vec{f}}=\boldsymbol{\mathrm{F}}\stackrel{\triangledown}{N}
$$  

where $\vec{N}$ is the vector defined in fields 6, 7 and 8. The magnitudeof $\stackrel{,}{f}$ is equal to F times the magnitude of $\vec{N}$ ·  

2. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command.  

In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.  

3. A CID of zero or blank (the default) references the basic coordinate system.  

4. For scalar points see SLOAD.  

5.For $\mathrm{TYPE}{=}12$ or $\mathrm{TYPE}{=}13$ on the TLOAD1, G is the ID of a rigid body: the MID of a rigid material MATRIG or the EID of a RBE2.The MID ofa rigid material and the EID of RBE2 must be different when both of a RBE2 and a rigid material are used with these TYPEs. SOL 7O0 only.  

6. For axisymmetric elements, the point loads to be entered on the card should be obtained by integrating over l radian of the circumference.  

Defines a concentrated force at a grid point by specification of a magnitude and two grid points that determine the direction.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FORCE1</td><td>SID</td><td>G</td><td>F</td><td>G1</td><td>G2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FORCE1</td><td>6</td><td>13</td><td>-2.93</td><td>16</td><td>13</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>Grid point identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>F</td><td>Magnitude of the force. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>G1,G2</td><td>Grid point identification numbers. (Integer > O; G1 and G2 may not be coincident.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The force applied to grid point G is given by $\stackrel{\triangledown}{\vec{f}}={\bf F}\stackrel{\triangledown}{\vec{n}}$ where $\vec{\boldsymbol{n}}$ is a unit vector parallel to a vector from Gl to G2.  

2. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command.  

In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.  

3.Thefollower force effects due toloads from this entry are included in the stiffnessinallinear solution sequences that calculate a differential stiffness. The solution sequences are SOLs 103, 105,107 to 112, 115 and 116 (see also the parameter FOLLowK, 829). In addition,follower force effects are included in the force balance in the nonlinear static and nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences, SOLs 106, 129, 153, 159, 400, if geometric nonlinear effects are turned on with PARAM,LGDISP,1. The follower force stiffness is included in the nonlinear static solution sequences (SOLs 106, 153 and 400) but not in the nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences (SOLs 129 and 159).  

4. For axisymmetric elements, the point loads to be entered on the card should be obtained by integrating over 1 radian of the circumference.  

Defines a concentrated force at agrid point by specification of a magnitude and four grid points that determine the direction.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8 9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FORCE2</td><td>SID</td><td>G</td><td>F</td><td>G1</td><td>G2</td><td>G3</td><td>G4</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FORCE2</td><td>6</td><td>13</td><td>-2.93</td><td>16</td><td>13</td><td>17</td><td>13</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>Grid point identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>F</td><td>Magnitude of the force. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>Gi</td><td>Grid point identification numbers. (Integer > 0; G1 and G2 may not be coincident; G3 and G4 cannot be coincident.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The direction of the force is parall to the crossproduct of vectors from Gl to G2 and G3 to G4.   
2. In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command. In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.   
3.The follower forceeffects due to loads from this entry are included in the stiffnessin allinear solution sequences that calculate a differential stiffness.The solution sequences are SOLs 103, 105,107 to   
112,115 and 116 (see also the parameter FOLLowK, 829). In addition,follower force effects are included in the force balance in the nonlinear static and nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences, SOLs 106, 129, 153, 159, and 400 if geometric nonlinear effects are turned on with PARAM,LGDISP,1. The follower force stiffness is included in the nonlinear static solution sequences (SOLs 106, 153 and 400) but not in the nonlinear transient dynamic solution sequences (SOLs 129 and 159).   
4. For axisymmetric elements, the point loads to be entered on the card should be obtained by integrating over 1 radian of the circumference.  

Defines a static concentrated force on a conical shell ring.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8 9</td><td></td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FORCEAX</td><td>SID</td><td>RID</td><td>HID</td><td>S</td><td>FR</td><td>FP</td><td>FZ</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FORCEAX</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>2.0</td><td>0.1</td><td>0.2</td><td>0.3</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>RID</td><td>RINGAX entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>HID</td><td>Harmonic identification number or a sequence of harmonics. See Remark 5. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>S</td><td>Scale factor for the force. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>FR,FP FZ</td><td>Force components in r, Φ,z directions. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. FORCEAX is allowed only if an AXIC entry is also present.   
2. Axisymmetric shell loads must be selected with the Case Control command $\mathrm{LOAD}=\mathrm{SID}$   
3. A separate entry is needed for the definition of the force associated with each harmonic.   
4. See Conical ShellElement (RINGAX) (Ch.3) in the MSC Nastran Reference Guide for further discussion.   
5. If a sequence of harmonics is to be placed in HID, the form is as follows: $^{\ast}\mathrm{Sn}1\mathrm{Tn}2^{\dprime}$ where nl is the start of the sequence and $\mathrm{n}2$ is the end of the sequence (e.g.,for harmonics O through 10, the field would contain $^{\mathrm{e}}{\cal S}0\mathrm{T}10^{\mathrm{}\mathrm{>}},$ ）  

Defines enforced motion at grid points specified by a user subroutine. Used in SOL700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>FORCUDS</td><td>LID</td><td>GROUP</td><td>UNAME</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>G1</td><td>G2</td><td>THRU</td><td>G3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example: In FMS Section of the MSC Nastran input stream:  

CONNECT SERVICE extvel 'sCA.MDSolver.Obj.Uds.Dytran.Loads In Bulk Data:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FORCUD</td><td>1</td><td>EXTVEL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>LID</td><td>Number of a set of loads.(Integer>O;required)</td></tr><tr><td>GROUP</td><td>The group name used for the FMS section CONNECT SERVICE statement. (Character; required)</td></tr><tr><td>UNAME</td><td>User subroutine name associated with the entry. (Character; default=EXTVEL)</td></tr><tr><td>Gi</td><td>Numbers of the grid points that are constrained. If the word THRU appears between two numbers, allthe numbers in the range are included in the list. BY indicates the increment to be used within this range. (Integer or character; required.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. LID must be referenced by a TLOADl entry.   
2. FORCUDS can only be used to specify enforced velocities for grid points. The TYPE field on the TLOAD1 entry must be set to two. The TID on the TLOAD1 entry must be set to zero or blank (no time variation).   
3. The GROUP name must be unique from all other GROUP names if more than one FORCUDS is used. Therefore each FORCUDS must have its own group name in a FMS section CONNECT SERVICE statement.   
4. The constraint name is passed to the subroutine and can be used to identify the constraint.   
5. A THRU specification, including the start and finish points in the range, must be on one line.   
6.If the THRU specification is used, allthe points in the sequence do not have to exist. Those that do not exist are ignored. The first point in the THRU specification must be a valid grid point. BY can be used to exclude grid points.  

7.None of the fields in the list ofgrid points can beblank or zero, since this designation marks the end of the list.  

8. Any number of continuation lines can be used to define the list of grid points.  

9.UNAME can be:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Subroutine Name</td><td> Function</td></tr><tr><td>EXTVEL</td><td>user defined velocities on grid points</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Defines the location of points on the surface ofa fluid for recovery ofsurface displacements ina gravity field.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FREEPT</td><td>IDF</td><td>IDP1</td><td>PHI1</td><td>IDP2</td><td>PHI2</td><td>IDP3</td><td>PHI3</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FREEPT</td><td>3</td><td>301</td><td>22.5</td><td>302</td><td>90.0</td><td>303</td><td>370.0</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>IDF</td><td>RINGFL entry identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>IDPi</td><td>Free surface point identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PHIi</td><td>Azimuthal position on fluid point (RINGFL entry) in the fluid coordinate system. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. FREEPT is allowed only if an AXIF entry is also present.   
2. Allfreesurface point identification numbers must be unique with respect to other scalar, structural,   
and fluid points.   
3. The free surface points are used for the identification of output data only.   
4. Three points may be defined on a single entry.   
5. The referenced fluid point (IDF) must be included in a free surface list (FSLIST entry).   
6. Output requests for velocity and acceleration can be made at these points.  

Defines a set of frequencies to be used in the solution of frequency response problems.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>FREQ</td><td>SID</td><td>F1</td><td>F2</td><td>F3</td><td>F4</td><td>F5</td><td>F6</td><td>F7</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>F8</td><td>F9</td><td>F10</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FREQ</td><td>3</td><td>2.98</td><td>3.05</td><td>17.9</td><td>21.3</td><td>25.6</td><td>28.8</td><td>31.2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>29.2</td><td>22.4</td><td>19.3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Fi</td><td>Frequency value in units of cycles per unit time. (Real ≥ 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Frequency sets must be selected with the Case Control command FREQUENCY $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ SID.  

2. All FREQi entries with the same frequency set identification numbers willbe used. Duplicate frequencies will be ignored. $f_{N}$ and $f_{N-1}$ are considered duplicated if  

$$
\left|f_{N}-f_{N-1}\right|<\mathrm{DFREQ}\cdot\left|f_{M A X}-f_{M I N}\right|,
$$  

where DFREQis a user parameter, with adefaultof ${{10}^{-5}}$ ． $f_{M A X}$ and $f_{M I N}$ are the maximum and minimum excitation frequencies of the combined FREQi entries.  

3. In modal analysis, solutions for modal DOFs from rigid body modes at zero excitation frequencies may be discarded. Solutions for nonzero modes are retained.  

4. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.  

Defines a set of frequencies to be used in the solution offrequency response problems by specification of a starting frequency, frequency increment, and the number of increments desired.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FREQ1</td><td>SID</td><td>F1</td><td>DF</td><td>NDF</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FREQ1</td><td>6</td><td>2.9</td><td>0.5</td><td>13</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>F1</td><td>First frequency in set. (Real ≥ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>DF</td><td>Frequency increment. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>NDF</td><td>Number of frequency increments. (Integer > O; Default = 1)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. FREQ1 entries must be selected with the Case Control command FREQUENCY $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ SID.   
2. The units for Fl and DF are cycles per unit time.   
3. The frequencies defined by this entry are given by $f_{i}=F1+D F\cdot(i{-}1)$ where $\dot{\mathbf{i}}=1$ to $(\mathrm{NDF+1},$ ）  

4. All FREQi entries with the same frequency set identification numbers will be used. Duplicate frequencies will be ignored. $f_{N}$ and $f_{N-1}$ are considered duplicated if  

$$
\left|f_{N}{-}f_{N-1}\right|{<}\mathrm{DFREQ}\cdot\left|f_{M A X}{-}f_{M I N}\right|,
$$  

where DFREQisa user parameter, with adefaultof ${10}^{-5}$ ， $f_{M A X}$ and $f_{M I N}$ are the maximum and minimum excitation frequencies of the combined FREQi entries.  

5. In modal analysis, solutions for modal DOFs from rigid body modes at zero excitation frequencies may be discarded. Solutions for nonzero modes are retained.  

6. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.  

Defines a set of frequencies to be used in the solution of frequency response problems by specification of a starting frequency, final frequency, and the number of logarithmic increments desired.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>FREQ2</td><td>SID</td><td>F1</td><td>F2</td><td>NF</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FREQ2</td><td>6</td><td>1.0</td><td>8.0</td><td>6</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>F1</td><td>First frequency. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>F2</td><td>Last frequency. (Real > 0.0, F2 > F1)</td></tr><tr><td>NF</td><td>Number of logarithmic intervals. (Integer > 0; Default = 1)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. FREQ2 entries must be selected with the Case Control command FREQUENCY $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ SID.  

2. The units for Fl and F2 are cycles per unit time.  

3. The frequencies defined by this entry are given by  

$$
f_{i}=F1\cdot e^{(i-1)d}
$$  

In the example above,the list of frequencies will be 1.0, 1.4142, 2.0, 2.8284, 4.0,5.6569 and 8.0 cycles per unit time.  

4. All FREQi entries with the same frequency set identification numbers will be used. Duplicate frequencies will be ignored. $f_{N}$ and $f_{N-1}$ are considered duplicated if  

$$
\left|f_{N}{-}f_{N-1}\right|<\mathrm{DFREQ}\cdot\left|f_{M A X}{-}f_{M I N}\right|\ ,
$$  

where DFREQis a user parameter, witha default of ${{10}^{-5}}$ ： $f_{M A X}$ and $f_{M I N}$ are the maximum and minimum excitation frequencies of the combined FREQi entries.  

5. In modal analysis, solutions for modal DOFs from rigid body modes at zero excitation frequencies may be discarded. Solutions for nonzero modes are retained.  

6. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>F1</td><td>Lower bound of modal frequency range in cycles per unit time. (Real ≥ 0.0 for TYPE = LINEAR and Real = 0.0 for TYPE = LOG)</td></tr><tr><td>F2</td><td>Upper bound of modal frequency range in cycles per unit time. (Real > O.0; F2 ≥ F1; Default = F1)</td></tr><tr><td>TYPE</td><td>LINEAR or LOG. Specifies linear or logarithmic interpolation between frequencies. (Character; Default = “LINEAR")</td></tr><tr><td>NEF</td><td>Number of excitation frequencies within each subrange including the end points. The first subrange is between F1 and the first modal frequency within the bounds. The second subrange is between first and second modal frequencies between the bounds. The last subrange is between the last modal frequency within the bounds and F2. (Integer > 1; Default = 10)</td></tr><tr><td>CLUSTER</td><td>Specifies clustering of the excitation frequency near the end points of the range. See Remark 6. (Real > 0.0; Default = 1.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1.FREQ3 applies only to modal frequency-response solutions (SOLs 111,146,and 200) and is ignored in direct frequency response solutions.   
2. FREQ3 entries must be selected with the Case Control command FREQUENCY = SID.   
3.In the example above, there willbe 10 frequencies in the interval between each set of modes within the bounds 20 and 2000, plus 10 frequencies between 20 and the lowest mode in the range, plus 10 frequencies between the highest mode in the range and 2000.   
4. Since the forcing frequencies are near structural resonances,it is important that some amount of damping be specified.  

5.All FREQi entries with the same set identification numbers will be used. Duplicate frequencies will be ignored. $f_{N}$ and $f_{N-1}$ are considered duplicated if  

$$
\left|f_{N}-f_{N-1}\right|<\mathrm{DFREQ}\cdot\left|f_{M A X}-f_{M I N}\right|
$$  

where DFREQisauser parameter,withadefaultof ${{10}^{-5}}.f_{M A X}$ an $f_{M I N}$ are the maximum and minimum excitation frequencies of the combined FREQi entries.  

6. CLUSTER is used to obtain better resolution near the modal frequencies where the response varies the most. CLUSTER $>1.0$ provides closer spacing of excitation frequency towards the ends of the frequency range, while values of less than 1.0 provide closer spacing towards the center of the frequency range. For example, if the frequency range is between 10 and 20 ${\mathrm{NEF}}=11$ ， $\mathrm{TYPE}=\mathrm{^{\circ}L I N E A R^{\circ}}$ ; then, the excitation frequencies for various values of CLUSTER would be as shown in Table 17.  

$$
\hat{f}_{k}=\frac{1}{2}(\hat{f}_{1}+\hat{f}_{2})+\frac{1}{2}(\hat{f}_{2}-\hat{f}_{1})|\xi|^{1/\mathrm{CLUSTER}}\cdot\mathrm{SIGN}(\xi)
$$  

where  

$\begin{array}{r l r}{\upxi}&{{}=}&{-1+2(k-1)/(\mathrm{NEF}-1)}\end{array}$ is a parametric coordinate between $^{-1}$ and 1   
$\mathrm{~\bf~k~}=\mathrm{~\bf~\Omega~}$ varies from 1 to NEF ( $k=1$ ,2,..., NEF)   
${\hat{\boldsymbol f}}_{1}~=~$ is the lower limit of the frequency subrange   
${\hat{f}}_{2}=$ is the upper limit of the subrange   
${\hat{\boldsymbol f}}_{k}\ =$ is the k-th excitation frequency   
$\begin{array}{r l}{{\hat{\boldsymbol{f}}}}&{{}=}\end{array}$ is the frequency, or the logarithm of the frequency, depending on the value specified for TYPE

<html><body><table><tr><td>FREQ4</td><td>6</td><td>20.0</td><td>2000.0</td><td>0.30</td><td>21</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>F1</td><td> Lower bound of frequency range in cycles per unit time. (Real ≥ 0.0; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>F2</td><td>Upper bound of frequency range in cycles per unit time. (Real > 0.0; F2 > F1; Default = 1.0E20)</td></tr><tr><td>FSPD</td><td>Frequency spread, +/- the fractional amount specified for each mode which occurs in the frequency range F1 to F2. (1.0 > Real > 0.0; Default = 0.10)</td></tr><tr><td>NFM</td><td>Number of evenly spaced frequencies per “spread" mode. (Integer > 0; Default = 3; If NFM is even, NFM + 1 will be used.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. FREQ4 applies only to modal frequency-response solutions (SOLs 111, 146, and 200 and is ignorec in direct frequency-response solutions.   
2. FREQ4 entries must be selected with the Case Control command FREQUENCY $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ SID.   
3. There will be NFM excitation frequencies between $(1-F S P D)\cdot f_{N}$ and $(1+F S P D)\cdot f_{N}$ , for each natural frequency in the range F1 to F2.   
4.In theexampleabove therewillbe 21equallyspacedfrequenciesacrossafrequencybandof $0.7\cdot f_{N}$ to $1.3\cdot f_{N}$ for each natural frequency that occurs between 20 and 2000. See Figure 9-94 for the definition of frequency spread.

#### Figure 9-94 Frequency Spread Definition  

Excitation frequencies may be based on natural frequencies that are not within the range (F1 and F2) as long as the calculated excitation frequencies are within the range. Similarly, an excitation frequency calculated based on natural frequencies within the range (F1 through F2) may be excluded if it falls outside the range.  

5. The frequency spread can be used also to define the half-power bandwidth. The half-power bandwidth is given by $2\cdot\xi\cdot f_{N}$ ，where $\xi$ is the damping ratio. Therefore, if FSPD is specified equal to the damping ratio for the mode, NFM specifies the number of excitation frequency within the half-power bandwidth. See Figure 9-95 for the definition of half-power bandwidth.

$$
\left|f_{N}-f_{N-1}\right|<\mathrm{DFREQ}\cdot\left|f_{M A X}-f_{M I N}\right|
$$  

where DFREQisa userparameter withadefaultof ${10}^{-5}$ . The values $f_{M A X}$ and $f_{M I N}$ are the maximum and minimum excitation frequencies of the combined FREQi entries. 8.In design optimization (SOL 200), the excitation frequencies are derived from the natural frequencie computed at each design cycle. 9.In modal analysis, solutions for modal DOFs from rigid body modes at zero excitation frequencies may be discarded. Solutions for nonzero modes are retained. 10. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.

Remarks:  

1. FREQ5 applies only to modal frequency-response solutions (SOLs 11l, 146, and 200) and is ignored in direct frequency response solutions.  

2. FREQ5 entries must be selected with the Case Control command FREQUENCY $\mathbf{\tau}=\mathbf{\tau}$ SID.  

3. The frequencies defined by this entry are given by  

$$
f_{i}=F R i\cdot f_{N_{i}}

where $f_{N_{i}}$ are the natural frequencies in the range F1 through F2  

4.In the example above,the list of frequencies will be 0.6,0.8, 0.9,0.95,1.0, 1.05,1.l, and 1.2 times each natural frequency between 20 and 2000. If this computation results in excitation frequencies less then F1 and greater than F2, those computed excitation frequencies are ignored.  

Excitation frequencies may be based on natural frequencies that are not within the range (F1 and F2) as long as the calculated excitation frequencies are within the range. Similarly, an excitation frequency calculated based on natural frequencies within the range (F1 through F2) may be excluded if it falls outside the range.  

5. Since the forcing frequencies are near structural resonances,it is important that some amount of damping be specified.  

6.All FREQi entries with the same set identification numbers willbe used. Duplicate frequencies will be ignored. $f_{N}$ and $f_{N-1}$ are considered duplicated if  

$$
\left|f_{N}-f_{N-1}\right|<\mathrm{DFREQ}\cdot\left|f_{M A X}-f_{M I N}\right|
$$  

where DFREQisa user parameter withadefaultof ${{10}^{-5}}$ . The values $f_{M A X}$ and $f_{M I N}$ are the maximum and minimum excitation frequencies of the combined FREQi entries.  

7.In design optimization (SOL 200),the excitation frequencies are derived from the natural frequencie computed at each design cycle.  

8. In modal analysis, solutions for modal DOFs from rigid body modes at zero excitation frequencies may be discarded. Solutions for nonzero modes are retained.

Examples:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FRFCOMP</td><td>10</td><td>LEFTWING</td><td>OP2</td><td>25</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>FRFCOMP</td><td>20</td><td>FRAME</td><td>UF</td><td>30</td><td>1000.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>COMPID</td><td>ID of the component whose FRFs have been generated in a previous Nastran execution. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COMPNAME</td><td>Name of the COMPID FRF component. See Remark 1. (Up to 8 characters).</td></tr><tr><td>MEDIUM</td><td>Medium on which the FRF matrices and other related data are stored. Acceptable character values are DB (for database), OP2 (for OUTPUT2 file) or UF (for Universal file). See Remarks 2., 3. and 4.</td></tr><tr><td>UNITNO</td><td>Fortran unit number for the OP2 and UF options. (Integer > O). See Remarks 3. and 4.</td></tr><tr><td>LSCALFAC</td><td>Length scale factor for the UF option. (Real > 0.0; Default = 1.0). See Remarks 7., 8., 9.,10. and 11.</td></tr><tr><td>FSCALFAC</td><td>Force scale factor for the UF option. (Real > 0.0; Default = 1.0). See Remarks 7., 8.,9.,10., and 11.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. COMPNAME may be referenced by the ASMOUT keyword in the FRF Case Control command in order to request output for a specific FRF component in the FBA process Accordingly, COMPNAME may not have the values of CONNINFO,ALL, COMP or ASSEMBLY as these are all reserved words for use with the ASMOUT keyword in the FRF Case Control command.  

2.If the DB option is specified, then the following type of ASSIGN should be specified in the FMS section of the FBA job to access information on the database for the specified FRF component:  

ASSIGN dbname $\mathbf{\sigma}=\mathbf{\sigma}$ 'frfgen_job.MASTERDBLOCATE DATABLK $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ (FRFDB） LOGICAL $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ dbname  

3.If the OP2 option is specified, then the folowing type of ASSIGN should be specified in the FMS section of the FBA job to access information on the OUTPUT2 file for the specified FRF component: $\mathrm{ASSIGN\INPUTT2}=\mathrm{^{\prime}f r f g e n\_j o b\_o p2^{\prime}\ U N I T}=25\$   
4.If the UF option is specified, then thefollowing type of ASSIGN should be specified in the FMS section of the FBA job to access information on the Universal file for the specified FRF component: ASSIGN UNVFILE $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ 'frfgen_job_unv' UNIT = 26   
5. Component ID of O is assigned to the assembled FRF configuration resulting from the FBA process   
6. An FRF generation job using an FRF Case Control command with GEN/GENASM and COMPID and COMPNAME keywords specified in it willautomatically generate and save an FRFCOMP Bulk Data entry on the assembly punch (.asm) file for that FRF component for subsequent use in an FBA process.   
7. LSCALFAC and FSCALFAC are meaningful only for the UF option. They are ignored for the DB and OP2 options.   
8. The FRF and other information on the Universal File (UF) isgrouped by so-calld Universal Dataset Numbers (UDNs). The heart of the information on the UF for a test FRF component is in UDN 58 which contains FRF data for that component. Also of interest, if present, is UDN 15 which contains grid point coordinate data in single precision or UDN 241l which contains grid point coordinate data in double precision. Further, if UDN 15 or UDN 24ll is present, the data therein may reference definition or displacement coordinate systems.Such coordinate system data is resident in UDN 18. Details of the various UDNs and their formats can be obtained from the following websites: http://www.sdrl.uc.edu/universal-file-formats-for-modal-analysis-testing-1 http://www.sdrluc.edu/universal-file-formats-for-modal-analysis-testing-1/file-format-storehouse/file-formats   
9.The points of a test FRF component that are considered by the FBA processare those that are defined in UDN 58 either as response points or as excitation points. Any such point that appears both as a response point and as an excitation point is regarded as a potential connection point of the test FRF component.   
10. Connections between test FRF components and other FRF components are determined by what is supplied on the UF as indicated below. a. If UDN 15 or UDN 241l is supplied on the UF, then connections between the test FRF component grid points and those of other FRF components will be based on matching coordinates. b. If neither UDN 15 nor UDN 2411 is supplied, then normally, connections between the test FRF component grid points and those of other FRF components willbe based on matching grid point IDs. However, the user can override this by specifying FRFCONN entries, thereby causing connections between user specified grid points. In any case, when the connections are based on matching grid point IDs or based on FRFCONN entries, it is the user's responsibility to ensure that the connection grid points have the same physicallocations in space so that correct results are obtained from the FBA process. The program clearly cannot check for this condition since the coordinates of one or more of the points are not available.   
11. For the UF option, LSCALFAC and FSCALFAC are used as follows:  

For Universal Dataset No. (UDN) 15 or 2411 (if present) on the Universal File: The X, Y, and Z coordinate values in the UDN are multiplied by LSCALFAC before they are used in the FBA process.   
For Universal Dataset No. (UDN) 58 on the Universal File: The FRF response quantities in the UDN are multiplied by appropriate factors as shown in the following table before they are used in the FBA process.  

Table 9-16 Multiplication Factors for FRF Response Quantities in UDN 58 of the Universal File   


<html><body><table><tr><td>FRF Response Quantity</td><td>Type of Excitation</td><td>Factor by Which FRF Response Quantity isMultipliedBeforeIt is Used intheFBA Process</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Translational displacement, velocity or acceleration at a structural point</td><td>Unit force at an excitation point</td><td>LSCALFAC/FSCALFAC</td></tr><tr><td>Unit moment at an excitation point</td><td>1.0/FSCALFAC</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Rotational displacement, velocity or acceleration at a structural point</td><td>Unit force at an excitation point</td><td>1.0/FSCALFAC</td></tr><tr><td>Unit moment at an excitation1.0/(LSCALFAC*FSCALFAC) point</td><td></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Pressure at an acoustic point</td><td>Unit force at an excitation point</td><td>1.0/(LSCALFAC**2)</td></tr><tr><td>Unit moment at an excitation point</td><td>1.0/(LSCALFAC**3)</td></tr></table></body></html>

Examples:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FRFCONN</td><td>10</td><td>5</td><td>100</td><td>15</td><td>200</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>FRFCONN</td><td>20</td><td>STRUT</td><td>25</td><td>WING</td><td>35</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>CONNID</td><td>Unique identification number of the FRFCONN entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COMPIDi</td><td>Identification number of an FRF component whose FRFs have been generated in a previous Nastran execution. See Remark 1. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>COMPNAMi</td><td>Name of an FRF component whose FRFs have been generated in a previous Nastran execution. See Remark 1. (Up to 8 characters; no blank allowed)</td></tr><tr><td>POINTi</td><td>Grid or scalar point identification number. See Remarks 2. through 6. (Integer > 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. If neither of the FRF components COMPID1/COMPNAM1 and COMPID2/COMPNAM2 is part of the FBA process, then this entry is ignored. However,ifone of them is part of the FBA process but not the other, the program terminates the job with a user fatal message.   
2. POINTi must be among the connection points of the corresponding FRF component COMPIDi/COMPNAMi. If not, the program terminates the job with a user fatal message.   
3.It is, in general, not necessary to have FRFCONN entries when the connections in the FBA process involve only grid points. In the FBA process, allconnection grid points of FRF components that have the same basic coordinates are normally connected automatically without any user intervention or specification.   
4.If the connection points of an FRF component in the FBA process consist of coincident grid points, the program identifies such points via a user information messge. Allsuch coincident grid points must be referenced on FRFCONN or FRFRELS entries in order to ensure proper connections in the FBA process In the absence of such specifications for coincident connection grid points, the program terminates the job with a user fatal error.   
5.FRFCONN entries are required if the user wants to specify explicit connections between test FRF component grid points whose coordinates are not available and those of other FRF components. See Remark 10. under the description of the FRFCOMP entry for further details.  

6. FRFCONN entries are also required if the user wants to combine scalar points of FRF components in the FBA process.
