Remarks:  

1． GMNURB is recognized only in SOL 600.  

2. WARNING: For rigid contact, the right hand rule determines the interior side of the rigid surface. A deformable surface which contacts a rigid surface must be on the exterior side of the rigid surface (i.e.in the direction opposite to the right hand rule).Ifa rigid surface is described backwards, contact will not occur because the deformable body is already inside the rigid body at the start of the analysis. For 3D patches, if all need to be reversed, the parameter PARAM,MARCREVR,l may be entered to automatically reverse all 3D patches.   
3. For NURBS, enter either IDs of NPTU\*NPTV grid points as G1, G2, G3 etc. (set positive NPTU) or coordinates of abs(NPTU)\*NPTV grid point as (X1, Y1, Z1), (X2, Y2, Z2), etc.(set negative NPTU).  

Defines a rate of volumetric heat generation in a conduction element.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>５</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GMQVOL</td><td>LID</td><td>METHOD</td><td>FIELD1</td><td></td><td>EID1</td><td>EID2</td><td>EID3</td><td>EID4</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>EID5</td><td>etc.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>GMQVOL</td><td>100</td><td>TABLE</td><td>20</td><td></td><td>18</td><td>23</td><td>7</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer Meaning</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td>LID</td><td>Load set identification number.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>METHOD</td><td>Method used to specify the data (EQUATION, TABLE, CONSTANT). See Remark 2.</td><td>Character</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>FIELD1</td><td>Volumetric heat load data. See Remark 2</td><td>Integer or Real</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>EIDi</td><td>A list of heat conduction elements.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. For steady-state analysis, the load set is selected in the Case Control Section (LOAD $\mid=$ LID).  

2. METHOD specifies the data type of FIELD1 to be constants, equation IDs, or table IDs.Values in FIELD1 and FIELD2 are:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>METHOD</td><td>FIELD1</td></tr><tr><td>EQUATION</td><td>ID of a DEQATN entry defining the volumetric heat generation rate as a function of location (Integer > 0).</td></tr><tr><td>TABLE</td><td>ID of a TABLE3D entry defining the volumetric heat generation rate as a function of location (Integer > 0).</td></tr><tr><td>CONSTANT</td><td>Value of volumetric heat generation rate (Real).</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Note that the fifth field will be reserved for the future development of temperature dependent functions.  

Defines constraints for entities.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GMSPC</td><td>SID</td><td>C</td><td>ENTITY</td><td>ID</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>GMSPC</td><td>12</td><td>1</td><td>FEEDGE</td><td>109</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer Meaning</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td> SPC set identification number.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>C</td><td>Component number in the global coordinate system.</td><td>0≤Integer≤6</td><td>0</td></tr><tr><td>ENTITY</td><td>Entity that the enforced displacement is applied to (Specify GRID,FEEDGE, GMCURV, FEFACE,or GMSURF). See Remark 4.</td><td>Character</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>ID of the entity selected above.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1.The components of motion specified by C (field 3) ofalldegrees-of-freedom associated with an entity will be constrained.   
2.If $\mathrm{C}=0$ is specified then the degrees-of-freedom will be taken out of the constraint set.   
3. The component C has to be a single integer (1 or 2 or 3, etc.). Use multiple GMSPC entries for constraining multiple components.   
4.In general,the hierarchy set to resolve the conflicts arising in the enforced displacement input data i: the same as for the constraints. See Remark 10 under GMBC, 2072 for a description of the hierarchy   
5. Coordinate transformations should not be applied to grid points on FEEDGE, GMCURVE, FEFACE or GMSURF.  

Defines geometric information that willbe used in elements, surface definition, load definition, and boundary condition definition.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GMSURF</td><td>SURFID</td><td>GROUP</td><td>CIDIN</td><td>CIDBC</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td colspan="8">Evaluator Specific Data and Format</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>GMSURF</td><td>101</td><td>MSCGRPO</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>RPC,</td><td>POINT</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>0.0,2.0</td><td>1.0</td><td>1.0</td><td>2.0 3.0</td><td>4.0,1.0</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>0.0,2.0</td><td>1.0</td><td>1.0 1.0</td><td>2.0 3.0</td><td>4.0</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td colspan="3">Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SURFID</td><td>Surface Identification number. See Remark 2.</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>GROUP</td><td>Group of curves/surfaces that this surface belongs to. See Remarks 5. through 9.</td><td>Character</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>CIDIN</td><td>Coordinate system identification number used in defining the Integer ≥ 0 geometry of the curve. The coordinate system must be rectangular.</td><td></td><td>0</td></tr><tr><td>CIDBC</td><td>Identification number of the coordinate system in which constraints specified on GMBC and GMSPC entries are defined.</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>0</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. All SURFIDs must be unique.  

2. A GMSURF entry is required if:  

the geometry of the surface defined by this entry is to be used by an element. output (global) coordinate system is assigned to a GMSURF. permanent constraints are specified for a GMSURF.   
loads are applied to a GMSURF.   
enforced boundary conditions are applied to a GMSURF.  

3. GMSURF is used to calculate geometric information only. The edges of the finite elements that are connected to the surface willbe parametric cubic curves that are calculated from the more complex surface geometry.  

4.On the continuation entries, no commas can appear in columns 1 through 8 and the data in fields 2 through 9 must be specified in columns 9 through 72.   
5. The continuation entries are passed directly to the geometry evaluator indicated by the GROUP parameter.   
6. The GROUP value is initialized by an CONNECT GEOMEVAL command in the FMS section. This command specifies the evaluator that will be used for this surface.   
7. Two reserved names,MSCGRPO and MSCGRP1, are provided for the GROUP parameter. These need not be explicitly initialized in the FMS Section.   
8.If the GROUP parameter is specified as MSCGRPO, the MSC rational parametric cubic (MSCRPC) geometry evaluator is used for this surface. In this case the evaluator specific data in lines 2 through   
9 of this Bulk Data entry should be provided as given on the following page. Spaces or a comma character may be used to delimit each value. However, the comma character should not be used in the first field.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GMSURF</td><td>SURFID</td><td>MSCGRPO</td><td>CIDIN</td><td>CIDOUT</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>RPC</td><td>REPRES</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>XW(1)</td><td>XW(2)</td><td>XW(3)</td><td>XW(4)</td><td>XW(5)</td><td>XW(6)</td><td>XW(7)</td><td>XW(8)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>XW(9)</td><td>XW(10)</td><td>XW(11)</td><td>XW(12)</td><td>XW(13)</td><td>XW(14)</td><td>XW(15)</td><td>XW(16)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>YW(1)</td><td>YW(2)</td><td>YW(3)</td><td>YW(4)</td><td>YW(5)</td><td>YW(6)</td><td>YW(7)</td><td>YW(8)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>YW(9)</td><td>YW(10)</td><td>YW(11)</td><td>YW(12)</td><td>YW(13)</td><td>YW(14)</td><td>YW(15)</td><td>YW(16)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ZW(1)</td><td>ZW(2)</td><td>ZW(3)</td><td>ZW(4)</td><td>ZW(5)</td><td>ZW(6)</td><td>ZW(7)</td><td>ZW(8)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ZW(9)</td><td>ZW(10)</td><td>ZW(11)</td><td>ZW(12)</td><td>ZW(13)</td><td>ZW(14)</td><td>ZW(15)</td><td>ZW(16)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>W(1)</td><td>W(2)</td><td>W(3)</td><td>W(4)</td><td>W(5)</td><td>W(6)</td><td>W(7)</td><td>W(8)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>W(9)</td><td>W(10)</td><td>W(11)</td><td>W(12)</td><td>W(13)</td><td>W(14)</td><td>W(15)</td><td>W(16)</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td><td>Type</td><td>Default</td></tr><tr><td>RPC</td><td>Rational Parametric Cubic Surface.</td><td>Character</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>REPRES</td><td>Representation of the curve, (ALGEBRAIC, POINT, BEZIER).</td><td>Character</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>XW(1)</td><td>Data used to define the surface.</td><td>Real</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>through XW(16)</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr></table></body></html>  

A rational parametric surface is defined as  

$$
x(u,\nu)={\frac{x w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)}}
$$  

$$
y(u,\nu)={\frac{y w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)}}
$$  

$$
z(u,\nu)={\frac{z w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)}}
$$  

0.0≤u≤1.0  

$$
0.0\leq\nu\leq1.0
$$  

·For REPRES $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ "ALGEBRAIC", the rational parametric surface is defined by the algebraic coefficient for rational cubic equations.  

Expressed as a tensor product  

$$
P_{(u,\nu)}=\left[{\left[u^{3}\ u^{2}\ u\ 1\right]}[{\mathrm{algebraic~coefficients}}]{\left\{\begin{array}{l}{{\nu^{3}}}\\ {{\nu^{2}}}\\ {{\nu}}\\ {{\nu}}\\ {{1}}\end{array}\right\}}\right]
$$  

for the Bulk Data input in algebraic form  

$$
x w(u,\nu)=\left[{\left[{\begin{array}{l}{{{x}^{3}}}\\ {{{x}^{3}}}\end{array}}{\left[{\begin{array}{l l l}{{{x}^{2}}}\\ {{{x}^{3}}}\end{array}}{\left[{\begin{array}{l l l}{{{X}^{W}(1)}}&{{{X}^{W}(2)}}&{{{X}^{W}(3)}}\\ {{{X}^{W}(5)}}&{{{X}^{W}(6)}}&{{{X}^{W}(7)}}\end{array}\right]}{\left[\begin{array}{l}{{{\nu}^{3}}}\\ {{{\nu}^{2}}}\\ {{{{x}^{W}(1)}}}\end{array}\right]}}\\ {{{X}^{W}(13)~X^{W}(14)~X^{W}(11)~X^{W}(16){}{}^{\left[{\begin{array}{l}{{{\nu}^{3}}}\\ {{{\nu}}}\\ {{{1}}}\end{array}\right]}}}\end{array}\right]}^{2}}\right]
$$  

and similarly for $y w(u,\nu),z w(u,\nu)$ , and $w(u,\nu)$ ·  

and  

$$
x(u,\nu)=\frac{x w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)};y(u,\nu)=\frac{y w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)};z(u,\nu)=\frac{z w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)}
$$  

where $X W(i),Y W(i),Z W(i)$ ,and $W(i)$ are the algebraic coefficients for the independent equations $x w(u,\nu),y w(u,\nu),z w(u,\nu)$ ,and $w(u,\nu)$ ·  

For REPRES $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ "BEZIER", the surface is defined by 16 rational Bezier control points $V_{11}$ through $V_{44}$  

and  

$$
P(u,\nu)=\sum_{i=1}^{4}\sum_{i}^{4}V_{i j}~B_{i,4}u\cdot B_{j,4}\nu
$$  

where $B_{i,4}u$ and $B_{j,4}{}^{\nu}$ are the Bernstein polynomials for curves of degree 3. For Bulk Data input defined as Bezier control points  

$$
x w(u,\nu)=\sum_{i}^{4}\sum_{j=1}^{4}X W i,j B_{i,4}\cdot B_{j,4}\nu
$$  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/f0b6e89e21a5a7719ca79b6261f20a760252e1c38535388f0ce3965813a86795.jpg)  

where $X W(1)$ through $X W(16)$ are ordered to conform to the two-dimensional array for $V_{i j}$ ; that is, $X W(4\cdot(i-1)+j)$ corresponds to $x w(u,\nu)$ for $V_{i j}$ . For example, $X W(7)$ corresponds to $V_{23}$ $y w(u,\nu);z w(u,\nu)$ ; and $w(u,\nu)$ are solved in a similar fashion.  

and  

$$
x(u,\nu)=\frac{x w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)};y(u,\nu)=\frac{y w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)};z(u,\nu)=\frac{z w(u,\nu)}{w(u,\nu)}
$$  

When the point representation is used, the surface is defined by 16 uniformly spaced rational points lying on the surface.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/cca71c7f96f4545ed2e9d789a0ca88d2d4b4d691fac961d4b127256f4f52d9e0.jpg)  

where $X W(1)$ through $X W(16)$ are ordered to contain to the two-dimensional mapping above for $V_{i j}$ ; that is, $X W(4\cdot(i-1)+j)$ corresponds to $x w(u,\nu)$ for $V_{i j}$ . For example, $X W(7)$ corresponds to $V_{23}$  

9. If the GROUP parameter is specified as MSCGRP1, the MSC generic equation (MSCEQN) geometry evaluator is used for this surface. In this case the evaluator specific data should be on the continuation entries. Spaces or a comma character may be used to delimit each value. However, a comma must not be specified in the first field.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1 2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>EQUATION,MINU</td><td>MAXU</td><td>MINV</td><td>MAXV</td><td>IDX</td><td>IDY</td><td>IDZ</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IDDXU</td><td>IDDYU</td><td>IDDZU</td><td>IDDXV</td><td>IDDYV</td><td>IDDZV</td><td>IDDXU2</td><td>IDDYU2</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IDDZU2</td><td>IDDXV2</td><td>IDDYV2</td><td>IDDZV2</td><td>IDDXUV</td><td>IDDYUV</td><td>IDDZUV</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>

If MAXU is found less than MINU, the range for U is assumed to be [- 8,+8].</td><td>Real</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>MINV, MAXV</td><td>Range of the second parameter describing the surface. If MAXV is found less than MINV, the range is assumed to be [-oo,+0].</td><td>Real</td><td>0.0,1.0</td></tr><tr><td>IDX, IDY, IDZ</td><td>ID of DEQATN entries providing equations for the X,Y,Z coordinate of the surface in terms of two</td><td>Integer > 0</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>IDDXU, IDDYU, IDDZU</td><td>parameters u and v. ID of DEQATN entries providing equations for Integer ≥ 0 the first derivatives ofX,Y,Z functions with respect to the first surface parameter u. If a value of O is</td><td></td><td>0</td></tr><tr><td>IDDXV, IDDYV, IDDZV</td><td>used, the derivatives are computed numerically. ID of an DEQATN entry describing the first derivatives of X, Y, Z functions with respect to the first surface parameter v. If a value of O is used, the derivatives are computed</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>0</td></tr><tr><td>IDDXU2, IDDYU2, IDDZU2</td><td>numerically. ID of an DEQATN entry describing the second derivatives of X,Y,Z functions with respect to the first surface parameter u. Ifa value of O is used, the derivatives are computed numerically.</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>0</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td><td>Type</td><td>Default </td></tr><tr><td>IDDXV2, IDDYV2, IDDZV2</td><td>ID of an DEQATN entry describing the second derivatives of X,Y,Z functions with respect to the second surface parameter v. If a value of O is used, the derivatives are computed numerically.</td><td>Integer ≥ 0</td><td>0</td></tr><tr><td>IDDXUV, IDDYUV, IDDZUV</td><td>ID of an DEQATN entry describing the mixed second derivatives of X,Y,Z functions with respect to the surface parameters u, and v. If a value of O is used, the derivatives are computed numerically.</td><td>Integer ≥0</td><td>0</td></tr></table></body></html>  

10. When an external geometry evaluator clas is selected for this group (which is the case when the CONNECT GEOMEVAL statement selects an external geometry evaluator for the specified group), the data in Fields 1 to n willnot be interpreted. In this case an image of this entry is passed on to the evaluator modules provided by the user for the specific geometric package that being used. These modules are connected with Nastran during execution. If these modules are not provided, a User Fatal Message will be issued. For example, if in the FMS Section, the following command is given:  

CONNECT GEOMEVALFENDER,CATIA,'/u/kiz/data',Version $\scriptstyle\mathtt{.=}68$ as of 1/3/94 · then the GMSURF entry could use that geometry data base as follows:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GMSURF</td><td>765</td><td>FENDER</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Extrude</td><td>/u/kiz</td><td>2.5</td><td>arc</td><td>2.7</td><td>66</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

·In this case,“Extrude $\mathrm{u}/\mathrm{kiz}2.5$ arc $2.766"$ is passed to the geometry evaluator supplied by the user, and it is expected that the user-supplied routines interpret and use this record.  

Defines acceleration vectors for gravity or other acceleration loading.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GRAV</td><td>SID</td><td>CID</td><td>A</td><td>N1</td><td>N2</td><td>N3</td><td>MB</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>GRAV</td><td>1</td><td>3</td><td>32.2</td><td>0.0</td><td>0.0</td><td>-1.0</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td>Coordinate system identification number. (Integer ≥ 0; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>A</td><td>Acceleration vector scale factor. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>Ni</td><td>Acceleration vector components measured in coordinate system CID. (Real; at least one Ni ≠ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>MB</td><td>Indicates whether the CID coordinate system is defined in the main Bulk Data Section (MB = -1) or the partitioned superelement Bulk Data Section (MB = 0). Coordinate systems referenced in the main Bulk Data Section are considered stationary with respect to the assembly basic coordinate system. See Remark 10. (Integer; Default = 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The acceleration vector is defined by $\dot{\vec{a}}=\boldsymbol{A}\vec{N}$ ,where $\vec{N}$ is the vector defined by (N1, N2, N3). The magnitude of $\vec{a}$ is equal to A times the magnitude of $\vec{N}$ . The static loads generated by this entry are in the direction of $\vec{a}$ ，   
2. A CID of zero references the basic coordinate system.   
3. Acceleration or gravity loads may be combined with"simple loads" (e.g.,FORCE, MOMENT) only by specification on a LOAD entry. That is, the SID on a GRAV entry may not be the same as that on a simple load entry.   
4.In the static solution sequences, SID must be selected by the LOAD Case Control command. In the dynamic solution sequences, if there is a LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the LID field of a selected LSEQ entry. If there is no LOADSET Case Control command, then SID must be referenced in the EXCITEID field of an RLOADi or TLOADi entry.   
5. At most nine GRAV entries can be selected in a given run either by Case Control or the LOAD Bulk Data entry. Multiples or reflections of a given acceleration or gravity load can be economically accomplished by use of the LOAD Bulk Data entry.   
6.In cyclic symmetry solution sequences,the T3 axis of the coordinate system referenced in field 3 must be parallel to the axis of symmetry. In dihedral cyclic symmetry (where $\mathrm{STYPE}=^{\mathrm{\tiny~\mathfrak{c}}}\mathrm{DIH}^{\mathfrak{p}}$ on the CYSYM entry), the T1 axis must, in addition, be parallel to Side 1 of segment 1R of the model.   
7.For image superelements,the coordinate system must be rotated if the image is rotated relative to its primary superelement.   
8. Acceleration or gravity loads do not include effects due to mass on scalar points.   
9. The RFORCE entry may be used to specify rotational accelerations.   
10.The coordinate systems in the main Bulk Data Section are defined relative to the assembly basic coordinate system which is fixed. This feature is useful when a superelement defined bya partitioned Bulk Data Section is rotated or mirrored and the gravity load is more conveniently defined in terms of coordinates which are fixed.   
11. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.  

Defines default options for fields 3, 7, 8, and 9 of all GRID entries.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6 7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GRDSET</td><td></td><td>CP</td><td></td><td></td><td>CD</td><td>PS</td><td>SEID</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>GRDSET</td><td>16</td><td></td><td></td><td>32</td><td>3456</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>CP</td><td>Identification number of coordinate system in which the location of the grid points are defined. (Integer ≥ 0 or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>CD</td><td>Identification number of coordinate system in which the displacements, degrees-of- freedom, constraints, and solution vectors of the grid point are defined. (Integer ≥ -1 or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>PS</td><td>Permanent single-point constraints on the grid point. (Any combination of Integers 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks, or blank.)</td></tr><tr><td>SEID</td><td> Superelement identification number. (Integer ≥ O or blank)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1.The contents offields 3,7,8,or 9 of this entry are assumed for the corresponding fields ofany GRID entry whose field 3,7,8,and 9 are blank.Ifany of these fields on the GRID entry are blank, the default option defined by this entry occurs for that field. If no permanent single-point constraints are desired, one of the coordinate systems is basic,or the grid is assigned to theresidual structure then the default may be overridden on the GRID entry by making one of fields 3,7,8, or 9 zero (rather than blank). Only one GRDSET entry may appear in the Bulk Data Section.   
2. The primary purpose of this entry is to minimize the burden of preparing data for problems with a large amount of repetition (e.g., two-dimensional pinned-joint problems).   
3. At least one of the fields CP, CD, PS, or SEID must be specified  

Defines the location of a geometric grid point, the directions of its displacement, and its permanent single-point constraints.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>GRID</td><td>ID</td><td>CP</td><td>X1</td><td>X2</td><td>X3</td><td>CD</td><td>PS SEID</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>GRID</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>1.0</td><td>-2.0</td><td>3.0</td><td></td><td>316</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Free Field Large Format Example:   
GRID\*,2,,1.0, -2.0,   
\*,3.0,,136  

#### Translates to:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GRID*</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td>-2.0</td><td></td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>*+</td><td>3.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>136</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

The comma immediately following the $-2.0$ is required if NASTRAN IFPSTAR $\scriptstyle.=\mathrm{NO}$ is used. The comma is always recommended even if NASTRAN IFPSTAR $\c=$ YES (Default) is used.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Grid point identification number. (O < Integer < 100,0oo,000, see Remark 9.)</td></tr><tr><td>CP</td><td>Identification number of coordinate system in which the location of the grid point is defined. (Integer ≥ O or blank*)</td></tr><tr><td>X1,X2,X3</td><td> Location of the grid point in coordinate system CP. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>CD</td><td>Identification number of coordinate system in which the displacements, degrees-of- freedom, constraints, and solution vectors are defined at the grid point. (Integer ≥ -1 or blank, see Remark 3.)*</td></tr><tr><td>PS</td><td>Permanent single-point constraints associated with the grid point. (Any of the Integers 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks, or blank*.)</td></tr><tr><td>SEID</td><td>Superelement identification number. (Integer ≥ O; Default = 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

$^{*}S\mathrm{ee}$ the GRDSET entry for default options for the CP, CD, PS, and SEID fields.  

Remarks:  

1. All grid point identification numbers must be unique with respect to allother structural, scalar, fluid and extra (EPOINT) points.   
2. The meaning of X1, X2, and X3 depends on the type of coordinate system CP as follows (see the CORDij entry descriptions):  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Type</td><td>X1</td><td>X2</td><td>X3</td></tr><tr><td>Rectangular</td><td>X</td><td>Y</td><td>Z</td></tr><tr><td>Cylindrical</td><td>R</td><td>0(degrees)</td><td>Z</td></tr><tr><td> Spherical</td><td>R</td><td>0(degrees)</td><td>Φ(degrees)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

See Grid Point and Coordinate System Definition (Ch. 2) in the MSC Nastran Reference Guide, for a definition of coordinate system terminology.  

3. The collection of all CD coordinate systems defined on all GRID entries is called the global coordinate system. All degrees-of-freedom, constraints, and solution vectors are expressed in the global coordinate system. It is recommended that points on the $\textbf{\em z}$ -axis not have their displacement directions defined with cylindrical or spherical coordinates. (See further remarks on the CORD1S, CORD2S, CORD1C, and CORD2C.)  

4. The SEID field can be overridden by use of the SESET entry.  

5.If $\mathrm{CD}=-1$ , then this defines a fluid grid point in coupled fluid-structural analysis. This type of point may only connect the CAABSF, CHACBR, CHACAB, CHEXA, CPENTA, and CTETRA elements to define fluid elements.  

6. A zero(or blank if the GRDSET entry is not specified) in the CP and CD fields refers to the basic coordinate system.  

7.In p-version analysis,the hierarchy setto resolve the conflicts arising in the global system input data is described under Remark 10 of the GMBC entry description.  

8. CID can reference GMCORD type coordinate systems only when the GRID is connected to p-version elements.  

9.ForSOL 600, ID may range froto $2^{31}-1$ (2147483647)if there are noOUTRoptions specified on the SOL 600 entry. If any OUTR option is specified the limit is 100000000.  

10. For RC network solver in thermal analysis, the CD, PS and SEID are ignored.  

Defines an associative GRID point to be used in the COMBINE step of PAA.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GRIDA</td><td>GID</td><td>ORIG_GID</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td colspan="7">PARTNAME</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>GRIDA</td><td>1</td><td>1000</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td colspan="7">Left_outboard_wing_tank</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>GID</td><td>GRID ID to be used in the current run. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>ORIG_GID</td><td>GRID ID in Part being referenced. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PATNAMEi</td><td>Name of Part ORIG_GID is in. (Character, C64, no internal blank spaces)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. GRIDA entries are used only in the COMBINE step of PAA processing.They are used to allow the other entries in the current bulk data to reference GRID points or SPOINTs in Parts that are being combined to create the Assembly.   
2. ORIG_GID must exist in the referenced Part. If the Part has been reduced, it must bea boundary GRID for that Part (in the A-set of that Part).   
3.The GRIDA id may be treated the same as if it were defined using a GRID or SPOINT entry in the current run. The program will handle the connection to the referenced GRID/SPOINT in the Part   
4.Only dofwhich are in the Part A-set will be available for connection.Ifa GRIDA references a GRID in a Part, which has fewer than 6 dof in the Part A-set (dof available in the Part matrices), although the GRIDA will have 6 dof, only the dof which exist in the Part matrices willbe connected to the Part.  

Defines the location ofa geometric grid point on a fluid point (RINGFL entry)for an axisymmetric fluid model and/or axisymmetric structure. Also defines the boundary of the fluid.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4 5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GRIDB</td><td>ID</td><td></td><td></td><td>PHI</td><td>CD</td><td>PS</td><td>IDF</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>GRIDB 30</td><td></td><td>30.0</td><td></td><td>3</td><td>345</td><td>20</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td> Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Grid point identification number. (O < Integer < 1000000)</td></tr><tr><td>PHI</td><td>Azimuthal position of the fluid in degrees. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>CD</td><td>Identification number of the coordinate system in which the displacements are defined at the grid point. (Integer ≥ O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>PS</td><td>Permanent single-point constraints associated with grid point. (Any combination of the Integers 1 through 6 with no embedded blanks, or blank.)</td></tr><tr><td>IDF</td><td>Identification number of a RINGFL entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. GRIDB is allowed only if an AXIF entry is also present. The AXIF entry must define a fluid coordinate system.   
2. All GRIDB identification numbers must be unique with respect to other scalar,structural, fluid and extra (EPOINT) points.   
3.The referenced RINGFL entry must be present and be included in a boundary list (BDYLIST entry).   
4. If no harmonic numbers on the AXIF entry are specified, no fluid elements are necessary.   
5. The collection of all CD coordinate systems defined on all GRID and GRIDB entries is called the global coordinate system.   
6. Fields 3,4,and 6 are ignored, which facilitates the conversion of GRID entries to GRIDB entries. Note that the fields are the same except for fields 1 and 9 when a cylindrical coordinate system is used  

Defines a scalar degree-of-freedom for harmonic analysis of a fluid.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GRIDF</td><td>ID</td><td>R</td><td>Z</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>GRIDF</td><td>23</td><td>2.5</td><td>-7.3</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer </td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Identification number of axisymmetric fluid point. (0 < Integer < 1000000)</td></tr><tr><td>R</td><td>Radial location of point in basic coordinate system. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>Z</td><td>Axial location of point in basic coordinate system. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. This entry is allowed only if an AXSLOT entry is also present.   
2.ID must be unique with respect to all other scalar, structural, fluid and extra (EPOINT) points.   
3. Grid points on slot boundaries are defined on GRIDS entries. Do not also define them on GRIDF entries.   
4. For ploting purposes, the R location corresponds to the basic X coordinate. The Z location corresponds to the basic Y coordinate. Pressures will be plotted as displacements in the basic Z direction.   
5.Loadand constraint conditions are applied as if GRIDF were a scalar point.Positiveloads correspond to inward flow. A single-point constraint causes zero pressure at the point.  

Defines a scalar degree-of-freedom with a two-dimensional location. Used in defining pressure in slotted acoustic cavities.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GRIDS</td><td>ID</td><td>R</td><td>Z</td><td>W</td><td>IDF</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>GRIDS</td><td>25</td><td>2.5</td><td>-7.3</td><td>0.5</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Identification number of the slot point. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>R</td><td>Radial location of point in basic coordinate system. (Real ≠ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>Z</td><td>Axial location of point in basic coordinate system. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>W</td><td>Slot width or thickness at the GRIDS point. (Real ≥ 0.O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>IDF</td><td>Identification number to define a GRIDF point. (Integer > O or blank)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. This entry is allowed only if an AXSLOT entry is also present.   
2.ID (and IDF if present) must be unique with respect to allother scalar, structural, fluid and extra (EPOINT) points.   
3. If W is blank, the default value on the AXSLOT entry will be used.   
4. The IDF number is referenced on the CAXIFi entry for central cavity fluid elements next to the interface. The IDF number is entered only if the grid point is on an interface. In this case, the IDF should also be defined on a GRIDF entry.   
5. If IDF is nonzero, then R must be greater than zero.   
6. For plotting purposes, the R location corresponds to the basic X coordinate. The Z location corresponds to the basic Y coordinate. The slot width, W, corresponds to the basic $Z$ coordinate The pressure will be plotted in the basic Z direction.   
7. Load and constraint conditions are applied as if the GRIDS is a scalar point. Positive loads correspond to inward flow. A single-point constraint causes zero pressure at the point.  

Defines a stationary vertical gust for use in aeroelastic response analysis.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>GUST</td><td>SID</td><td>DLOAD</td><td>WG</td><td>X0</td><td>V</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>GUST</td><td>133</td><td>61</td><td>1.0</td><td>0.</td><td>1.+4</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Gust set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>DLOAD</td><td>Set identification number of a TLOADi or RLOADi entry that defines the time or frequency dependence. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>WG</td><td>Scale factor (gust velocity/forward velocity) for gust velocity. (Real ≠ 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>X0</td><td>Streamwise location in the aerodynamic coordinate system of the gust reference point. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>V</td><td>Velocity of vehicle. See Remark 5. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The GUST entry must be selected with the Case Control command $\mathrm{GUST}=\mathrm{SID}$ ·   
2. The gust angle is in the $+z$ direction of the aerodynamic coordinate system. The value is $W G\cdot T{\biggl(}t-{\frac{X-X0}{V}}{\biggr)}$ where $T$ is the tabular function.   
3. In random analysis, a unit gust velocity $(\mathbb{W}G=1/$ (velocity) is suggested. The actual rms value i entered on the TABRNDG entry.   
4. X0 and V may not change between subcases under one execution.   
5. V must be equal to VELOCITY on the AERO Bulk Data entry.  

Specifies Mesh refinement criterion for adaptive mesh refinement and corresponding parameters.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HADACRI</td><td>CRITID</td><td>TYPE</td><td>F1</td><td>F2</td><td>F3</td><td>F4</td><td>F5</td><td>F6</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:

(Integer ≥ 1 and ≤ 4; Default = 1)</td></tr><tr><td>F1 to F8</td><td>Criteria specific parameters. See Remark 2. (Real; no Default)</td></tr></table></body></html>

3.Each criteria must have a unique ID (specified by the CRITID field and referenced by the CRITID field of the Bulk Data entry, HADAPTL, 2126).

Specifies Local Adaptive Mesh Refinement control parameters.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HADAPTL</td><td>ID</td><td></td><td></td><td>REPEAT</td><td>CRITID</td><td>WHEREME T</td><td>WHEREID</td><td>SNAPMETH</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MAXLEVEL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>HADAPTL</td><td>１</td><td></td><td></td><td>10</td><td>1</td><td>PROP</td><td>5</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Identification number referenced by the Case Control HADAPT command. (Integer > 0; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>REPEAT</td><td>Maximum number of analysis performed before the adaptive mesh refinement process is stopped. See Remark 3. (Integer ≥ 0; Default = 6)</td></tr><tr><td>CRITID</td><td>Identification number of a mesh refinement criterion to be selected with the HADACRI Bulk Data entry. See Remarks 1. and 2. and the HADACRI Bulk Data entry. (Integer > O; no Default)</td></tr><tr><td>WHEREMET</td><td>Method to specify the mesh refinement region subjected to the refinement criterion referenced by the field CRITID. It can take the values: “ALL"or“SUPER”or“PROP". See Remark 4. (Character; Default = ALL)</td></tr><tr><td>WHEREID</td><td>ID of the mesh refinement region subjected to the refinement criterion referenced by the field CRITID. Must be specified if WHEREMET is“SUPER” or“PROP". If WHEREMET=ALL, this field willbe ignored. See Remark 4. (Integer ≥ 0; Default = 0)</td></tr><tr><td>SNAPMETH</td><td>Method to project, snap or relax new grid pints created on mid-edge or mid-faces on the mesh boundary during the refinement process onto the analysis domain boundary: No projection; New grids are placed in the mid-side of edges. New grid points are projected onto a smooth approximation of the analysis</td></tr><tr><td>MAXLEVEL</td><td>domain boundary interpolated from the initial mesh boundary. (Integer ≥ 0; Default = 0) Maximum refinement level allowed for each individual element in the mesh. No elements in the mesh will be refined to a level bigger then MAXLEVEL. (Integer > 0; Default =</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The adaptive mesh refinement occurs when a particular refinement criterion is satisfied. Data for the refinement criterion is specified by the Bulk Data entry HADACRI referenced by the CRITID field  

2.Multiple mesh refinement criteria can be selected in diffrent subsets of the model. To this end, the user needs to define multiple HADAPTL entries with the same ID. Each entry might specify a different criteria (referenced in the CRITID field and defined on the corresponding HADACRI Bulk Data entry) on different subsets of the mesh (defined in the WHEREMET and WHEREID fields).  

3. When multiple HADAPTL entries with the same ID are specified, NASTRAN will chose for the REPEAT, SNAPMETH, and MAXLEVEL field the maximum among all multiple instances.   
4. The fields WHEREMET and WHEREID refer respectively to the Method to specify the mesh refinement region (subjected to the refinement criterion referenced by the field CRITID and defined with the Bulk Data entry, HADACRl, 2123) and its corresponding ID. For example, WHEREMET $\dot{\bf\Phi}={\bf\Phi}$ SUPER,WHEREID $\scriptstyle\left.=3\right.$ means that local adaptive mesh refinement (with the criteria referenced by the CRITID field) should be effected only in superelement 3. Likewise, WHEREMET $\mathbf{\bar{\Psi}}=\mathbf{\Psi}$ PROP,WHEREID $\scriptstyle1=5$ (see the previous Example) means that local adaptive mesh refinement (with the criteria referenced by the CRITID field) should be efected only in those element with Property ID equal to 5. Finaly, WHEREMET $\dot{\bf\Phi}={\bf\Phi}$ ALL imply mesh refinement in all elements.   
5.In partitioned superelements, the HADAPT entry must be specified in the main bulk data section. Entries specified in the Bulk Data Section corresponding to individual parts (sections beginning with BEGIN SUPER) will be ignored.   
6. When using regular superelements, the Bulk Data Section must begin with BEGIN SUPER as opposed to BEGIN BULK, in order for the refinement to be appropriately propagated across superelement boundaries. If BEGIN BULK is used, grid points on the superelement boundaries wil be duplicated and not shared by the joining superelements.   
7. The user should avoid the use of MPC sets 90000000 to 999999 which are reserved for hanging nodes constraints generated during the adaptive mesh refinement process.   
8. The user might need to adjust the VARPHI parameter to ensure proper singular geometric feature detection (such as sharp edges or corners) (See the Parameter, VARPHl, 1005).   
9. When SNAPMETH $_{=0}$ , all mid-edge nodes belonging to straight edges are placed on the mid-side of its edge. By contrast, when SNAPMETH $_{.=1}$ , mid-edge nodes belonging to the boundary of the mesh are projected to a smooth approximation of the analysis domain boundary interpolated from the mesh boundary.  

10.Mid-face nodes belonging to bilinear quadrilateral faces are placed at the baricenter of its face.  

Defines the heat-transfer model to be used with GBAG or COUPLE. Used in SOL 700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HEATLOS</td><td>HID</td><td>HTRID</td><td>SUBID</td><td>HTRTYPE</td><td>HTRTYPID</td><td>COEFF</td><td>COEFFV</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>HEATLOS</td><td>101</td><td>83</td><td>HTRCONV</td><td>2</td><td>TABLE</td><td>14</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td></td><td> Meaning</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Describer</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>HID HTRID</td><td rowspan="3"></td><td>Unique number of a HEATLOS entry. (Integer > 0; Required) Number of a set of HEATLOS entries HTRID must be referenced from a GBAG or</td></tr><tr><td>SUBID</td><td>COUPLE entry. (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>(Integer ≥ 0, 0) v0</td><td>Number of a BSURF, BCBOX, BCPROP, BCMATL or BCSEG, which must be a part of the surface as defined on the GBAG or COUPLE</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3">HTRTYPE</td><td>=0</td><td>entries. HEATLOS definitions are used for the entire surface as defined on the</td></tr><tr><td>GBAG or COUPLE entries. Defines the type of heat transfer. (Character; Required)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>HTRCONV</td><td>The HTRCONV logic is used to model heat transfer through convectionion in an air bag. The area of convection through which the</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>HTRRAD</td><td>energy is transported is equal to the area of the subsurface multiplied by COEFFV. A value of COEFFV = 1.0 will expose the complete subsurface area, while a value of COEFFV = 0.O will result in no heat transfer through the subsurface. The HTRRAD logic is used to model heat transfer through radiation in an air bag. The area of convection through which the energy is transported is equal to the area of the subsurface multiplied by COEFFV. A value of COEFFV = 1.0 will expose the complete subsurface area, while a value of COEFFV = 0.0 will result in no heat transfer through</td></tr><tr><td>HTRTYPID</td><td colspan="2">the subsurface. Heat transfer ID. References existing HTRTYPE entry. (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>COEFF</td><td colspan="2">Method of defining the area coefficient. (Character, CONSTANT) CONSTANT The area coefficient is constant and specified on COEFFV.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TABLE</td><td>The area coefficient varies with time. COEFFV is the number of a TABLEDl entry giving the variation with time.</td></tr><tr><td>COEFFV</td><td colspan="2">The area coefficient or the number of a TABLED1 entry depending on the COEFF entry.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td colspan="2">(0.0 ≤R≤1.0 or 1 > 0,1.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks  

1. A combination of multiple HEATLOS with different HTRTYPEs is allowed.  

2. It allows for setting up the exact same model for either a uniform pressure model (GBAG to HEATLOS) or an Eulerian model (COUPLE to HEATLOS). It is then possible to set up the model using the switch from full gas dynamics to uniform pressure (GBAGCOU).  

3. For the same BSURF multiple, different types of heat transfer may be defined.  

4. A more detailed description can be found in Porosity in Air Bag for more details.  

Defines the hourglass suppresson method and the corresponding hourglass damping coefficients. Used in SOL 700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HGSUPPR</td><td>HID</td><td>PROP</td><td>PID</td><td>HGTYPE</td><td>HGCMEM</td><td>HGCWRP</td><td>HGCTWS</td><td>HGCSOL</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>RBRCOR</td><td>VALUE</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>HGSUPPR</td><td>1</td><td>SHELL</td><td>100</td><td>FBV</td><td>0.1 0.1</td><td>0.1</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>+</td><td>YES</td><td>10000</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>HID</td><td>Hourglass suppression definition number. (Integer > O; Required.)</td></tr><tr><td>PROP</td><td>Property type. (Character; See Remark 1.)</td></tr><tr><td>PID</td><td>Property number. (Integer > O; See Remark 1.)</td></tr><tr><td>HGTYPE</td><td>Hourglass suppression method: (Character; See Remark 2.)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4"></td><td>FBV For shells only (default for shells)</td></tr><tr><td>FBS For shells and solids (default for solids)</td></tr><tr><td>Dyna For solids only</td></tr><tr><td>Membrane damping coefficient. (0.0 ≤ Real ≤ 0.15; default=0.1)</td></tr><tr><td>HGCMEM</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>HGCWRP</td><td>Warping damping coefficient. (0.0 ≤ Real ≤ 0.15; default=0.1)</td></tr><tr><td>HGCTWS</td><td>Twisting damping coefficient. (0.0 ≤ Real ≤ 0.15; default=0.1)</td></tr><tr><td>HGCSOL</td><td>Solid damping coefficient. (0.0 ≤ Real ≤ 0.15; default=0.1)</td></tr><tr><td>RBRCOR NO</td><td>Rigid body rotation correction: (Character; default=NO)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td>No rigid-body rotation correction is applied to hourglass resisting forces.</td></tr><tr><td>YES Rigid-body rotation correction is applied to hourglass resisting forces.</td></tr><tr><td>VALUE</td><td>Number of steps. (Integer > 0; See Remark 3.)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The property type definition and the property number are required. Since property numbers are unique within a certain class of element types, the property type and the property number uniquely define to what elements the hourglassuppression method and coefficients apply. The following property types are valid entries:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>BAR</td><td>For bar elements</td></tr><tr><td>BEAM</td><td>For beam elements</td></tr><tr><td>BELT</td><td>For belt elements</td></tr><tr><td>COMP</td><td>For composite shell elements</td></tr><tr><td>DAMP</td><td>For damper elements</td></tr><tr><td>ELAS</td><td>For spring elements</td></tr><tr><td>EULER</td><td>For Eulerian elements</td></tr><tr><td>ROD</td><td>For rod elements</td></tr><tr><td>SHELL</td><td>For shell elements</td></tr><tr><td>SOLID</td><td>For solid Lagrangian elements</td></tr></table></body></html>  

It must be noted however, that only shell CQUAD4 and Lagrangian CHEXA and CPENTA elements can suffer from undesired hourglass modes. All HGSUPPR entries referring to other types of elements are ignored.  

2. There are three types of hourglass suppression methods available in Nastran. These are standard DYNA viscous (DYNA) hourglass damping, the Flanagan-Belytschko Stiffness (FBS) hourglass damping, and the Flanagan-Belytschko Viscous (FBV) hourglass damping.  

Lagrangian solid elements can address DYNA and FBS suppression; shell elements can address DYNA and FBV suppression. The default for the Lagrangian solid elements is FBS. The default for the shell elements is FBV.  

3. The rigid-body rotation correction on the hourglassforces is only necessary in cases where shell elements undergo a large rigid-body rotation.If the RBRCOR field is set to YES, and the VALUE field is left blank, the correction is applied during each time step. If the VALUE field is set to a number, the rotation correction is applied only when the rigid-body rotation would result in a rotation of the element over $90^{\circ}$ in less than VALUE time steps. Usually, if the rigid-body rotation correction is necessary; 10o00 is a good value. This option saves some CPU time.  

The RBRCOR option applies to the Key-Hoff shellformulation only; for all other element types anc formulations, the option is ignored.  

4.The membrane, warping and twisting coefficients apply to shell elements only; for all other element types, the data is ignored. The solid damping coefficient applies to solid Lagrangian elements only; for all other element types, the data is ignored.  

Defines the heat transfer through convection for a COUPLE and/or GBAG surface.  

Convection is heat transferfrom the air bag to the environment through the air bag surface. Used in SOL 700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>７</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HTRCONV</td><td>HTRID</td><td>HTRCFC</td><td>HTRCFT</td><td>TENV</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>HTRCONV</td><td>8</td><td></td><td>14</td><td>293.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>HTRID</td><td>Unique number of a HTRCONV entry. Referenced from HEATLOS. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>HTRCFC</td><td>Constant heat transfer convection coefficient. See Remark 3. (Real ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>HTRCFT</td><td>The heat transfer convection coefficient is a tabular function of time. The number given here is the number of a TABLED1 entry. See Remark 3. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TENV</td><td>Environmental temperature. (Real > 0; Required)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The HTRCONV entry can be referenced from a HEATLOS entry.   
2. When used with Euler,theentry can only be used with the single materialhydrodynamic Euler solver using an EOSGAM (ideal gas) equation of state.Two of the four gas constants $(\upgamma,R,{c_{\mathrm{v}}}$ and/or $c_{p}$ ） have to be defined on the EOSGAM entry.   
3. Either HTRCF-C or HTRCF-T must be specified.   
4.Energy willonly transfer out of the air bag if the temperature inside the air bag is higher than the environmental temperature.  

# Air Bag Radiation  

Defines the heat transfer through radiation for a COUPLE and/or GBAG surface.  

Radiation is heat transfer from the air bag to the environment through the air bag surface. Used in SOL 70C only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>HTRRAD</td><td>HTRID</td><td>GASBMI-C</td><td>GASEMI-T</td><td>TENV</td><td>SBOLTZ</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>HTRRAD</td><td>2</td><td>0.15</td><td>293.0</td><td>5.676E-8</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>HTRID</td><td>Unique number of a HTRRAD entry. Referenced from HEATLOS. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>GASEMI-C</td><td>Constant gas emissivity. See Remark 3. (Real ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>GASEMI-T</td><td>The gas emissivity is a tabular function of time. The number given here is the number of a TABLED1 entry. See Remark 3. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>TENV</td><td>Environmental temperature. (Real > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>SBOLTZ</td><td>Stephan-Boltzman constant. (Real > O; Required)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. The HTRRAD entry can be referenced from a HEATLOS entry.   
2.When used with Euler, the entry can only be used with the single material hydrodynamic Euler solver using an EOSGAM (ideal gas) equation of state. Two of the four gasconstants $(\boldsymbol{\upgamma},R,\boldsymbol{c_{\mathrm{v}}}$ and/or $c_{p}$ ） have to be defined on the EOSGAM entry.   
3. Either GASEMI-C or GASEMI-T must be specified.   
4.Energy will only transfer out of the air bag if the temperature inside the air bag is higher than the environmental temperature.  

Specifies hybrid damping parameters.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HYBDAMP</td><td>ID</td><td>METHOD</td><td>SDAMP</td><td>KDAMP</td><td>PRTEIG</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>HYBDAMP</td><td>101</td><td>2000</td><td>2001</td><td>NO</td><td>YES</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>ID</td><td>Identification number of HYBDAMP entry (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>METHOD</td><td>Identification number of METHOD entry for modes calculation. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>SDAMP</td><td>Identification number of TABDMP1 entry for modal damping specification. (Integer > O; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>KDAMP</td><td>Selects modal“structural" damping. See Remark 1. (Character: “Yes" or“NO"; Default = “NO")</td></tr><tr><td>PRTEIG</td><td>Print eigenvalue summary from hybrid damping calculation (Character: “Yes" or “NO”; Default = “NO")</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. For $\mathrm{KDAMP}=^{\mathrm{{e}}}\mathrm{YES^{\mathrm{{,}}}}$ , the viscous modal damping is entered into the complex stiffness matrix as structural damping.  

2. Hybrid damping is generated using modal damping specified by the user on TABDMP entries.  

$$
{\cal B}H=[M]\biggl[\Phi_{1}~\Phi_{2}~\cdots~\Phi_{n}^{~}\biggr]\left[\begin{array}{c}{{b(\upomega_{1})}}\\ {{{}}}\\ {{b(\upomega_{2})}}\\ {{{}}}\\ {{{}\ddots}}\\ {{{}}}\\ {{{}}}\end{array}\ddots\underbrace{\mathrm{\boldmath~\Omega~}}_{b(\upomega_{n})}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}{{{}}}\\ {{{}\Phi_{1}^{T}}}\\ {{{}\Phi_{2}^{T}}}\\ {{{}_{1}^{T}}}\\ {{{}}}\\ {{{}\Phi_{n}^{T}}}\end{array}\right]\left[{\cal M}\right]
$$  

For KDAMP $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ “YES”  

$$
K H=[M]\Big[\Phi_{1}\Phi_{2}\cdots\Phi_{n}\Big]\left[\begin{array}{c}{{g(\upomega_{1})}}\\ {{g(\upomega_{2})}}\\ {{\ddots}}\\ {{\qquad\ddots}}\\ {{\qquadg(\upomega_{n})\Bigg]\left[\begin{array}{c}{{T}}\\ {{T}}\\ {{T}}\\ {{T}}\\ {{T}}\end{array}\right][M]}}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}{{T}}\\ {{0}}\\ {{T}}\\ {{T}}\\ {{M}}\end{array}\right].
$$  

where  

中i = modes of the structure [M] = structural mass matrix   
b(@;) = modal damping values, $b(\upomega_{i})=g(\upomega_{i})\upomega_{i}m_{i}$   
g(;) = twice the critical damping ratio determined from user specified TABDMP entry Qi = natural frequency of mode $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{i}$ $\begin{array}{r l}{m_{i}}&{{}=}\end{array}$ generalized mass of mode $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{i}$  

3.Hybrid damping is based on a modal solution and the mass matrix. Even if user requested all the modes and specified a flat value of G the result is still dependent on the Rank of the Mass matrix. Also note that Hybrid damping does not include residual vectors to compensate for high frequency contribution and other possible massless degrees of freedom effects in the Rank of the mass matrix. PARAM, COUPMASS, 1 may improve the mass rank.  

4. HYBDAMP is referenced by the DAMPING and ROTHYBD Bulk Data entries.  

5. When hybrid damping is used during FRF component generation, it is recommended to set the KDAMP field to YES on the HYBDAMP entry. See remarks under SDAMPING Case Control description for further details.  

6. If Modules are present then this entry may only be specified in the main Bulk Data section.  

Hydrostatic Pressure Loading on Surface and Faces of Shell or Solid Elements using fluid cavities.  

Defines a hydrostatic pressure load on a face of a CHEXA, CPENTA, CPYRAM, CTETRA, CTRIA3, CTRIA6, CTRIAR, CQUAD4, CQUAD8, or CQUADR element using fluid cavity data. The HYDROC entry is NOT supported in SOL101 because SOL 101 does not support the Fluid Structure Interface.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HYDROC</td><td>SID</td><td>PSOLID</td><td>PNOM</td><td>G</td><td>PCH</td><td>PLD4</td><td>OVRD</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>CID/GRD</td><td>HGHTB</td><td>HABOV</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>HYDROC</td><td>66 99</td><td>33 0.</td><td>42. 10.</td><td>980.</td><td>1</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PSOLID</td><td>PSOLID ID of the cavity. Fluid density will be obtained from the associated MAT10 entry. (Integer > 0); HYDROC requires ACMODL,DIFF (the default value).</td></tr><tr><td>PNOM</td><td>Nominal or atmosphere pressure. If G=0.0, PNOM only is applied. (Real; default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>G</td><td>Acceleration (e.g. of gravity) in the direction from HABOV toward the origin defined by the CID/GRD field. (Real; Default = 1.0)</td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">PCH</td><td>O - default (no punch);</td></tr><tr><td>1 - Punch Set of structural grids.</td></tr><tr><td>2 - Punch Set of structural elements.</td></tr><tr><td>3 - Punch both structural grids and structural elements. (Integer ≥0)</td></tr><tr><td>PLD4</td><td>0 - default (no punch); 1 - Punch the resulting PLOAD4 entries. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>OVRD</td><td>O-default. If PARAM, INREL, is present and G not equal to 1.0, then a fatal error message will be issued. 1 - Allow non unit value of G.</td></tr><tr><td>CID/GRD</td><td>Coordinate ID of a reference coordinate system to measure the coordinate z-direction. If Integer ≥ O; a coordinate system ID is used. If Integer < O; a GRID ID is used with the z-direction of the GRID, CD field. Note: A spherical coordinate system will result in a fatal error. See Remark 1.; (Integer - default O -basic).</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>HGHTB</td><td>The z-distance to the lowest fluid point measured from reference origin. See Remark 1.. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>HABOV</td><td>The height of the fluid above the lowest point measured in the z-direction from reference origin. See Remark 1. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. On the HYDROC entry, HGHTB along with the z-coordinate direction, are used to determine the location of the"bottom"of the fluid body in the case where the fluid cavity is fulland there is no free surface.  

In the case where a free fluid surface has been modeled in the cavity, CID/GID and HGHTB are for reference only. The lowest fluid level is determined as the lowest wetted grid in the FSI coupling measure in the direction defined by CID/GID. From the FSI coupling, free surface formed by examining wetted grids may not be perpendicular to the $\mathbf{z}$ -direction of CID/GID. Hence, HABOV will be considered as average free surface and hydrostatic pressure willbe computed with respect to HABOV. However, a fatal message will occur if the average free surface specified by HABOV is significantly above the free surface of wetted grids. Also note that some wetted grids/elements may not get loaded if HABOV is too low.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/15f9289965f12ef8791a5b45009097401c792c69aec1d2f082627df4667766db.jpg)  

2. The HYDROC entry willinternally be converted to an equivalent set of PLOAD4 entries with the same load SID   
3. Each fluid cavity should have a unique PSOLID entry as HYDROC uses the PSOLID to identify the cavity.   
4. The PNOM is applied only from fluid surface to bottom of fluid.   
5. HYDROC interaction with the Fluid Structure Interface (FSI) algorithm is shown in the two figures below.The top figure shows a column of fluid over some structural elements.The column of fluid is 30 units high, however, only its bottom surface is in contact with structural elements. Therefore, the FSI will only see a fluid that is 10 units high. A HYDROC entry for this model, with a HABOV $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ 50 units would fail to compute any hydrostatic loading, because 50 units is welloutside the tolerance of the FSI interface, which is at 30 units.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/00b0020cdfcfe7fddbde6ed0240b4c2f1d653242cbe976585f5aeb7ae54410c5.jpg)  

The second figure shows the same fluid column,but a layer of shell elements has been laid on top of the fluid column.  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/ee667ee680320f0c39441c09745ef6a17287eb7e9adca5f9c7ab4a10423e3754.jpg)  

In this case, the FSI sees a column of fluid 50 units high. Thus a ${\mathrm{HABOV}}=50$ units will generate PLOAD4 entries using a height of 30 units for the fluid. For this model, any HABOV with values (30 units $\leq\mathrm{HABOV}\leq50$ units) will yield valid PLOAD4 entries on the fluid structure interface of the structural solid elements with the height used depending on the value of HABOV.  

6. The figures below show additional HYDROC PNOM rules associated with the FSI interface. Alsc note how fluid cavities are defined by PSOLID ID.  

-YDROS (1) applies a hydrostatic loading of $55.+0.\star h^{\star}0$ interior to the cylinder with POINT 17  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/8cf1c1e08040790d4b48d538a56fa6eaed237ab29ae5d1f29748ce0f95715efe.jpg)  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/c7a675769edc3ff007a3a208722513e711fdc1f866bd75a4eaa18e87d144c03b.jpg)

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HYDROS</td><td>SID</td><td>PNOM</td><td>RHO</td><td>G</td><td>SETE</td><td>SETG</td><td>PLD4</td><td>OVRD</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>CID/GRD</td><td>HGHTB</td><td>HABOV</td><td>CNTL</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>

<html><body><table><tr><td>HYDROS</td><td>77</td><td>55.</td><td>0.08</td><td>17.</td><td>300</td><td></td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>200</td><td></td><td>97.</td><td>83</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td> Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Load set identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>PNOM</td><td>Nominal or atmosphere pressure. If G=0.0, PNOM only is applied. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>RHO</td><td>Mass density. (Real; Default = 1.0)</td></tr><tr><td>SETE</td><td>The ID of a SET3 entry using (DES= ELEM) or SET1 to identify the element IDs of structure elements at fluid-structure interface used for hydrostatic loading. (Integer ≥0)</td></tr><tr><td>SETG</td><td>The ID ofa SET3 entry using (DES= GRID) or SET1 to identify the element grid IDs of structure elements at fluid-structure interface used for hydrostatic loading. (Integer ≥0)</td></tr><tr><td>PLD4</td><td>O - default (no punch); 1 - Punch the resulting PLOAD4 entries. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>OVRD</td><td>O-default. Coordinate ID of a reference coordinate system to measure the coordinate z-direction. If Integer ≥ 0; a coordinate system is used. If Integer < O; a GRID ID is used with the z-direction of the GRID, CD field. Note: A spherical coordinate system will result in a fatal. See Remark 1.; (Integer - default 0 -basic).</td></tr><tr><td>HGHTB</td><td>Note: A spherical coordinate system will result in a fatal error. The z-distance to the lowest fluid point measured from reference origin. (Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr></table></body></html>

(Real; Default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>CNTL</td><td>SET3 ID of control grids to select wetted surface(s). For an immersed physical body, at least one grid per quadrant. (h is constant 97. units for this set) HYDROs (4) applies a hydrostatic loading $55.+.08\times h^{\star}17$ . for all elements on exterior cylinder side.

#### SOLIDModel  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/d6de93221916a7c35d14ca978793f246a8cfb1fedaece62d7b97ab3a3808d29a.jpg)  

Initializes the Euler element densities in accordance to a hydrostatic pressure profile.Used in SOL 700 only.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>HYDSTAT</td><td>HID</td><td>MID</td><td>GID</td><td>CID</td><td>XCG</td><td>YCG</td><td>ZCG</td><td>PATM</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>HYDSTAT</td><td>101</td><td>4</td><td></td><td></td><td>0.0</td><td>0.0</td><td>0.0</td><td>100000.</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>HID</td><td>Identification number of the HYDSTAT entry referenced from the COUPLE entry. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material MATDEUL id to which the hydrodynamic pressure profile will be applied. (Integer > 0; Required)</td></tr><tr><td>GID</td><td> Number of a grid point at the free surface. See Remark 4. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CID</td><td>Local coordinate system. See Remark 4. (Integer ≥ 0)</td></tr><tr><td>XCG,YCG, ZCG</td><td>Coordinates of a point at the free surface. See Remark 4. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>PATM</td><td>Pressure at free surface. (Real; Required)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1.It is assumed that each Euler domain contains at most two Eulerian materials and includes the GRAV entry. One material has to be a fluid using EOSPOL the other a gas or void. This EOSPOL material is given by the MID entry. The interface between gas and fluid is the free surface and is assumed to be normal to the gravity vector as specified on the GRAV entry. For example if the gravity vector points in the $z$ -direction then the interface between the gas and the fluid has to be horizontal.   
2. The hydrostatic preset changes the density of the fluid like material in order to conform to the hydrostatic preset.It overrules the material densities as specified on the TICEL and TICVAL entries. Densities of the gas like material are not changed.   
3.Thefree surface has to match with material fractions as defined in the initialization of Euler elements by the TICEL and TICEUL entries. The hydrostatic preset only changes densities, it does not change material fractions.   
4.There are two options to enter thelocation of the free surface.The first option is to enter agrid point number. In that case the fields CID and XCG-ZCG have to be left blank. The GRIDPOINT entry already has the option of using a local coordinate system. When coordinates are used then the field GID has to be left blank.  

5.If there is no structural grid point indicating the freesurface thena new grid point can be defined that will only be used for determining the free surface level. If the Gravity vector points in the $z$ -direction, only the z-coordinate of the grid point willbe used. The x and y ordinate can be chosen arbitrarily. Similar remarks hold when the gravity vector is in one of the other coordinate directions. The same holds when using coordinates instead of a grid point.  

6. PATM should be equal to the pressure in the air.  

7. When coupling surfaces are present then the HYDSTAT ID needs to be referenced by at least one coupling surface. For each coupling surface a different HYDSTAT entry can be defined. Several COUPLE entries can refer to the same HYDSTAT ID. If no HYDSTAT ID is specified on a COUPLE entry then Euler elements associated to this coupling surface willnot be initialized with a hydrostatic preset.  

Defines a collection of imperfection cases by listing of identification numbers of IMPGEOM entries. Used in SOL 400.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>IMPCASE</td><td>ID</td><td>IMPFID1</td><td>IMPFID2</td><td>…</td><td>IMPFIDi</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>IMPCASE</td><td>5</td><td>1</td><td>2</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Describer Meaning ID Identification number (integer $>0$ , required) IPMFIDi Identification number of imperfection case (integer ${>}0$ , required)  

Remarks:  

1. When the ID is referenced by case control IMPERFECT command, the list of IMPGEOM entries are used to apply geometric imperfections.   
2.“THRU" can be used to specify IMPFIDi.  

Defines geometric imperfection byselecting subcases, steps, mode numbers or increments from imperfection input files. Used in SOL 400.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>IMPGEOM</td><td>IMPFID</td><td></td><td></td><td>SETID</td><td>SCALE</td><td></td><td>UNIT</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>SUBCASE1</td><td>STEP1</td><td>MODEINC1</td><td>SETID1</td><td>SCALE1</td><td></td><td>UNIT1</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>SUBCASE2</td><td>STEP2</td><td>MODEINC2</td><td>SETID2</td><td>SCALE2</td><td></td><td>UNIT2</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>etc.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>IMPGEOM</td><td>1</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1</td><td>3</td><td>1</td><td></td><td>0.011</td><td></td><td>34</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1</td><td>3</td><td>2</td><td></td><td>0.002</td><td></td><td>34</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>IPMFID</td><td>Identification number of imperfection case (integer >0, required)</td></tr><tr><td>SETID</td><td>Default of SETIDi (integer ≥ 0, default=0)</td></tr><tr><td>SCALE</td><td>Default of SCALEi (real, default=0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>UNIT</td><td>Default of UNITi (integer ≥ 0, default=0)</td></tr><tr><td>SUBCASEi</td><td>Identification number of a subcase (integer ≥ 0, default=0)</td></tr><tr><td>STEPi</td><td>Identification number of a step (integer ≥ 0, default=0)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>MODEINCi Mode number if the selected step by SUBCASEi and STEPi or subcase by SUBCASEi is a result of buckling analysis or modal analysis, increment number if the selected result is from a static analysis. (integer ≥ O, default=0)</td></tr><tr><td>SETIDi</td><td>Identification number of a SET1 or SET3 bulk entry (integer ≥ 0, default = 0). When it is defined, only the grid points with the id listed in SET1 or SET3 have geometric imperfection effect. If a SET3 is used, it must be GRID type.</td></tr><tr><td>SCALEi</td><td>Scale factor (real, default = 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>UNITi</td><td>Imperfection file unit number specified by ASSIGN HDF5IN, INPUTT2 or IMPFIN FMS command.</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. All IMPGEOM identification numbers must be unique. An IMPGEOM entry is referenced by IMPERFECT case control directly or by an IMPCASE bulk entry.  

2. Geometric imperfection effect is applied to grid points as coordinates variation, the variation is superposed by eigenvectors of multiple modes or displacement of increments defined in multiple continuation lines.  

3.An imperfection input file can bean MSC Nastran HDF5 result file, a Nastranop2 file or a text based file called IMPF. To use it, an ASSIGN HDF5IN, INPUTT2 or IMPFIN FMS command is required.  

4. The imperfection input file of HDF5 or op2 can be a result file of SOL 101,103,105 or a SOL 400 with ANALYSIS type of BUCK, MODES, STATIC, NLSTATIC or NLTRAN, and must contain eigenvectors or displacement results.  

5. IMPF file format is described in remark 11. It can be DISP format or GEOM format. If an IMPF file is used in an IMPGEOM entry, only one continuation line of IMPGEOM is allowed, and SUBCASEi, STEPi and MODEINCi are ignored. If format is GEOM, SCALE and SCALEi are ignored too.  

6. SUBCASEi must be specified if the imperfection input file is an op2 or hdf5 file.  

7. STEPi is ignored when the imperfection input file is a result of SOL 101, 103 or 105. It must be specified for a SOL 400 result file.  

8.MODEINCi is ignored when the file is a result of SOL 10l or a linear static step of SOL 400. It is required for other cases if the imperfection file is an hdf5 or op2 file.  

9. UNITi must be specified if UNIT is O or not specified.  

10. Geometric imperfection is applied to residual structure for superelement models. In the case of part superelement, it is advised to adjust boundary grid point searching tolerance due to geometry changing. This can be done by adding or modifying SEBULK or SECONCT entries.  

11. Format of IMPF file  

The IMPF file is a csv-like file, delimiters of a line can be spaces,a comma or a tab space. A line starting with a $^{\mathfrak{s}}{\mathfrak{f}}^{\mathfrak{n}}$ or $\"\#\vartriangle$ is a comment line. If the first line is a comment line and contains string “GEOM" or“GRID", then it is a GEOM file, i.e., the grid coordinates provided here will replace the grid coordinates in the FE model; otherwise it is a DISP file, i.e., the displacements provided in the file will be superimposed to the coordinates of the corresponding grids.  

For each line, the first column is grid point id,followed by x,y and z.For DISP format, x,y and z are coordinate variations from the original coordinates, and coordinate system is MSC Nastran global system, this means that x,y,z are in the coordinate system indicated by CD field of GRID entries in the original input file.For GEOM format, x,y and z are“imperfect" coordinates of the grid points, coordinate system is MSC Nastran input system, this means the values of x,y,z respect CP field of the GRID entries in the original input file.
