(Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Gij </td><td>Identification number of a TABLEDi entry for the material property matrix. (Integer > O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>GE</td><td>Identification number of a TABLEDi entry for the element structural damping coefficient. (Integer > O or blank)</td></tr><tr><td>GEij</td><td>Identification number of a TABLEDi entry for the element structural damping coefficients. (Integer > O or blank)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Fields 3, 4,etc.of this entry correspond,field-by-field,to fields 3,4,etc.,of the MAT9 entry referenced in field 2. The value in a particular field of the MAT9 entry is replaced by the table referenced in the corresponding field of this entry. Blank or zero entries mean that there is no frequency dependence of the fields on the MAT9 entry. 2. Table references must be present for each item that is frequency dependent. 3.IF $\mathrm{GE}{=}0.0$ on corresponding MAT9 then GE table must be blank or 0. For any GEij $_{=0.0}$ on corresponding MAT9, the corresponding GEij table must be blank or 0.  

Defines material properties for fluid elements in coupled fluid-structural analysis.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8 9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>MAT10</td><td>MID</td><td>BULK</td><td>RHO</td><td>C</td><td>GE</td><td>ALPHA</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>MAT10</td><td>103</td><td>0.656</td><td>0.011</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>MID</td><td>Material identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>BULK</td><td>Bulk modulus. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>RHO</td><td>Mass density. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>C</td><td>Speed of sound. (Real > 0.0)</td></tr><tr><td>GE</td><td>Fluid element damping coefficient. (Real)</td></tr><tr><td>ALPHA</td><td>Normalized admittance coeffcient for porous material. See Remark 7. (Real or blank)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. MAT10 is referenced, with MID, by the PSOLID entry only.   
2. The material identification numbers must be unique for all MAT1, MAT2, MAT3, MAT9, and MAT10 entries.   
3. The mass density RHO will be used to compute the mass automatically.   
4. BULK, RHO, and C are related by $\mathbf{BULK}=C^{2}\cdot\mathbf{RHO}$ Two out of the three must be specified, and the other will be calculated according to this equation.If all three are specified and are inconsistent in values, the supplied values of BULK and RHO are used in the computations.   
5. To obtain the damping coefficient GE, multiply the critical damping ratio $C/C_{0}$ , by 2.0.   
6.If PARAM,W4FL is not specified, GE is ignored in transient analysis. See Parameters, 783.   
7. If a value of ALPHA is entered, BULK RHO and GE may have negative values.   
8. The value defined in the ALPHA field always defines the normalized admittance coefficient for porous material but it is differently interpreted depending on the value defined in the FCNT field of the referencing PSOLID entry.  

a. If the MAT10 entry is referenced in a PSOLID entry where FFLUID option is selected, the value defined for ALPHA is considered as the normalized admittance coefficient calculated at unit circular excitation frequency ( ${\bf\Pi}(\mathfrak{o}\ =\ 1)$ . Its value will be automatically calculated by the program, at each excitation frequency, considering the current circular excitation frequency as scaling factor. b. If the MAT10 entry is referenced in a PSOLID entry where PFLUID option is selected, the value defined for ALPHA has no special meaning but it is only the normalized admittance coefficient calculated by the user at the most appropriate excitation frequency (defined in order to have good results in the frequency range of interest). 9.For Poro-Elastic Material, PEM, user is expected to provide adiabatic BULK modulus for fluid-phase of PEM which is equal to GAMMA,fluid ratio of specific heats (see MATPE1 for detailed), times isothermal BULK modulus. Isothermal BULK modulus is BULK modulus at constant temperature for fluid itself. ). When used in conjunction with PSLDN1,only pyramid elements can be associated with the MAT10 fluid property. CHEXA, CPENTA, CTETRA elements using MAT10 are not supported with PSLDN1. 1. The terms of the fluid mass matrix are not multiplied by the value of PARAM and WTMASS.

Remarks:  

1. The material identification number must be unique for all COHESIV, MAT1, MAT2, MAT3, MAT8,MATDIGI, MATG,MATHE,MATHP, MATNLE, MATORT,MATPE1,MATSMA, MATUSR, MCOHE, MIXTURE, and MATD\* entries.   
2. SOL400 uses only the MID, UDID and RHO entries. Allother entries are ignored by SOL400.   
3.The entry UDSESV is required input to define the number of state variables which willbe used by MATDIGI. The number of state variables (NSTATS) must be larger than 1.   
4. License feature NASTRAN_DIGIMAT must be present to use this feature. For parallel computations, NASTRAN_DIGIMAT_DMP must be present.   
5. The use of MATDIGI is limited to shell and solid elements.   
6. MATDIGI should not be used in SOL 40O perturbation steps.

Remarks:  

1. Unless continuation entry is present specifying various material models, von Mises yield criterion is used as default.   
2.If $\mathrm{FORM}=\mathrm{SLOPE}$ , the one defines the initial yield stress with ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ and a single workhardening slope is entered as H. H = $\mathrm{~H~.~H~}=\~\frac{\hat{\sigma}\bar{\upsigma}}{\hat{\sigma}\bar{\upsigma}^{\uprho}}$ Iehdi often considered the $0.2\%$ offset strength. If FORM $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ TABLE, then the table ID is entered using FID field, ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ is not used. The table can be entered as TABLES1 or TABL3D. When $\mathrm{{TYPE}=1}$ on the TABLES1 option, one is defining $\overline{{{\upsigma}}}=\overline{{{\upsigma}}}(\overline{{{\upvarepsilon}}})$ as shown in Figure 9-107. When $\mathrm{TYPE}=2$ on the TABLES1 or TABL3D option, one is defining $\bar{\bf\Phi}_{\overline{{\bf\Phi}}}=\bar{\bf\Phi}_{\overline{{\bf\Phi}}}^{-}(\bar{\bf\Phi}_{\bar{\bf\Phi}}^{-}{\bf p})$ as shown in Figure 9-108.

Figure 9-108 Stress vs Plastic Strain TABLES1(TYPE2) or TABL3D  

If $\mathrm{FORM}=\mathrm{PERFECT}$ ， ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ is the yield stress and H and FID should be blank. This is known as elastic-perfectly plastic behavior. If temperature-dependent yield is present. then FORM $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ TABLE should be used and the temperature-dependent yield entered through TABL3D.  

3. For temperature-dependent materials, one can either define the temperature variation through the TABL3D option or include the MATTEP option. The first procedure is recommended.  

4.In a large displacement analysis $(\mathrm{LGDISP}=1,2,11,12)$ , the Cauchy stress and logarithmic strain are used.  

5. The plastic deformation starts when the effective stress $(\overline{{\upsigma}})$ exceeds the yield stress.  

The yield stress is initially defined by the initial yield point, which is subsequently modified by the hardening rule to account for strain hardening. Under the isotropic hardening rule, the size of the yield surface expands as a function of effective plastic strain $(\bar{\mathfrak{E}}^{\mathfrak{p}})$ . Under the kinematic hardening rule, the center of the yield surface moves in stress space while keeping the same size and shape. Ziegler's law is used to define the translation of the yield surface. Under the combined hardening, the initial hardening is assumed to be entirely isotropic, but the elastic range attains a constant value (i.e., behaving like kinematic hardening) after some plastic straining.The effective stressfor von Mises is expressed as  

$$
\overline{{\mathbb{O}}}~=~\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}[\left(\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{x}}-\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{y}}\right)^{2}+\left(\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{y}}-\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{z}}\right)^{2}+\left(\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{z}}-\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{2}]+3(\tau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}+\tau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}+\tau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2})}}
$$  

where the stress components are measured from the center of yield surface.  

6. The Cowper and Symonds model scales the initial yield stress as a function of strain-rate, i.e.,  

$$
\Upsilon(\stackrel{\cdot}{\varepsilon})=\Upsilon_{0}\biggl[1+\biggl(\frac{\stackrel{\cdot}{\varepsilon}}{\bf C}\biggr)^{1/\mathrm{P}}\biggr]
$$  

7. Hills anisotropic model introduces orthotropic plastic material.The plastic anisotropy proposed by Hill introduces six parameters to the von Mises yield function, from which an effective stress may be derived as  

$$
\overline{{\overline{{\mathbf{\Lambda}}}}}=\sqrt{\mathbf{F}(\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathrm{y}}-\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathrm{{z}}})^{2}+\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathrm{z}}-\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathrm{x}})^{2}+\mathbf{H}(\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathrm{x}}-\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathrm{y}})^{2}+2\mathbf{L}\tau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}+2\mathbf{M}\tau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}+2\mathbf{N}\tau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}
$$  

in which the material parameters can be related to the yield stress ratios by  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}{\mathrm{~F~=~}\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{22}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{33}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{11}^{2}}\bigg)}&{}\\ {\mathrm{~G~=~}\displaystyle\frac{1}{2\bigg(\mathrm{R}_{33}^{2}+}\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{11}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{22}^{2}}\bigg)}&{}\\ {\mathrm{~H~=~}\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{11}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{22}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{33}^{2}}\bigg)}&{}\\ {\mathrm{~L~=~}\displaystyle\frac{3}{2\mathrm{R}_{23}^{2}},\mathrm{~M~=~}\frac{3}{2\mathrm{R}_{31}^{2}},\mathrm{~N~=~}\frac{3}{2\mathrm{R}_{12}^{2}}}\end{array}
$$  

with  

$$
\mathrm{R}_{11}~=~{\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{1}}{\mathrm{Y}_{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{22}={\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{2}}{\mathrm{Y}_{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{33}={\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{3}}{\mathrm{Y}_{a}}}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{R_{12}}~=~\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathrm{T_{12}}}{\mathrm{Y_{a}}},\mathrm{R_{23}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathrm{T_{23}}}{\mathrm{Y_{a}}},\mathrm{R_{31}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathrm{T_{31}}}{\mathrm{Y_{a}}}
$$  

where $\mathrm{Y}_{1},\mathrm{Y}_{2}$ ,and ${\mathrm{Y}}_{3}$ are the tensile yield stresses measured in material directions x, y and $\mathbf{z}$ respectively; $\mathrm{T}_{12},\mathrm{T}_{23}$ ,and $\mathrm{T}_{31}$ are the shear yield stresses in pure shear; and $\mathrm{Y_{a}}$ is the reference yield stress which should be an average yield stress in all directions.  

In practical applications, however, the initial yield stress cannot be measured in all directions. The plastic anisotropy is pronounced in the sheet metal due to prior rolling process,for which the plastic anisotropy is customarily characterized by r-values defined by strain ratio measured in the uniaxial tension, i.e.,  

$$
\mathrm{\Deltar_{a}~=~}\mathrm{\frac{\varepsilon_{w}}{\varepsilon_{t}}~=~}\mathrm{\frac{ln(w_{0}/w)}{\ l n(t_{0}/t)}~=~}\mathrm{\frac{H+(2N-F-G-4H){sin}^{2}\theta~{c o s}^{2}\theta}{F~{s i n}^{2}\theta+G~{c o s}^{2}\theta}}
$$  

where t and w denote thickness and width, respectively; and 0 denotes the angle of orientation (usualy measured from the rolling direction). Assuming that the anisotropy parameters stay constant throughout the deformation, F, G, H and N can be determined by r-values from tensile specimen cut at 0, 45 and 90 degrees to the rolling direction:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle{\frac{\ H}{\mathbf{G}}}\ =\ \mathbf{r}_{0}\quad,\quad\displaystyle{\frac{\ H}{\ F}}=\mathbf{r}_{90}}}\\ {{\displaystyle{\frac{\ N}{\mathbf{G}}}\ =\ \biggl(\mathbf{r}_{45}+\displaystyle{\frac{1}{2}}\biggr)\biggl(1+\displaystyle{\frac{\mathbf{r}_{0}}{\mathbf{r}_{90}}}\biggr)}}\end{array}
$$  

The orthotropic plasticity parameters should be calculated from the r-values and the initial yield stress either in 0 or 90 degree direction ( $\mathrm{\DeltaY_{0}}$ or $\mathrm{Y}_{90}$ ) from the experiment. The yield stress in the thickness direction can be written as  

$$
\mathrm{Y_{th}~=~\mathrm{Y}_{0}\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}_{90}(1+\mathrm{r}_{0})}{\mathrm{r}_{0}+\mathrm{r}_{90}}}~=~\mathrm{Y}_{90}\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}_{0}(1+\mathrm{r}_{90})}{\mathrm{r}_{0}+\mathrm{r}_{90}}}}
$$  

Similarly, yield stresses in shear may be evaluated by  

$$
\mathrm{T}_{12}=\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{th}}\sqrt{\frac{1}{2{\bf r}_{45}+1}} 
$$  

and  

$$
{\mathrm{T}}_{23}={\mathrm{T}}_{31}={\frac{{\mathrm{Y}}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\sqrt{3}}}
$$  

in which the transverse direction is assumed isotropic.  

8.The pressure-dependent yielding, based on Drucker-Prager yield criterion,contains threeoptions for frictional materials such as rocks and concrete. The generalized Mohr-Coulomb criterion introduces linear and parabolic models, developed by Drucker and Prager. The linear Mohr-Coulomb model assumes a linear function of hydrostatic stress for a yield function, i.e.,  

$$
\mathrm{aI}_{1}+\sqrt{\mathrm{J}_{2}}-\frac{\mathrm{\Lambda}_{\overline{{\mathbb{O}}}}^{-}}{\sqrt{3}}=0\mathrm{or}\mathrm{\Lambda}_{\overline{{\mathbb{O}}}}^{-}=\sqrt{3}\upalpha\mathrm{I}_{1}+\sqrt{3\mathrm{J}_{2}}
$$  

where  

$$
\mathrm{~I_{1}~}=\mathrm{~\mathbb{{O}}_{x}+\mathbb{{O}}_{y}+\mathbb{{O}}_{z}~}
$$  

and  

$$
{\bf J}_{2}=\frac{1}{6}[\left({\upsigma_{1}}-{\upsigma_{2}}\right)^{2}+\left({\upsigma_{2}}-{\upsigma_{3}}\right)^{2}+\left({\upsigma_{3}}-{\upsigma_{1}}\right)^{2}]
$$  

The parameters $\upalpha$ and $\bar{\mathsf{\Pi}}_{\bar{\mathsf{{O}}}}^{-}$ (effective stress coinciding with the yield stress) can be related to material constants c (cohesion) and $\phi$ (frictional angle) by  

$$
\mathrm{~c~}=\frac{\overset{-}{\sigma}}{3\sqrt{(1-12\overset{\leftarrow}{\alpha}^{2})}}
$$  

and  

$$
s i n\Phi=\frac{3\alpha}{\sqrt{1-3\alpha^{2}}} 
$$  

The parabolic Mohr-Coulomb model allows a yield envelope to be parabolic in the plane strain case, for which the yield function is expressed as  

$$
{\sqrt{3\mathbf{J}_{2}+{\sqrt{3}}\mathbf{\upbeta}{\overline{{\mathbf{\upsigma}}}}\mathbf{I}_{1}}}-{\overline{{\mathbf{\upsigma}}}}=0
$$  

in which parameters are related to the material constants by  

$$
\overline{{{\bf{C}}}}^{2}=3\bigg({\bf c}^{2}-\frac{{\bf a}^{2}}{3}\bigg)
$$  

and  

$$
\beta=\frac{\alpha}{\sqrt{3(3\mathrm{c}^{2}-\mathrm{a}^{2})}}
$$  

9. The keywords may appear in any order.However, aniso and press, are mutualy exclusive, and cannot coexist.  

10. All the alphanumeric fields are recognizable by the first four letters  

11. In SOL 400, MATEP is only supported for nonlinear elements with property extensions. This implies that for such elements, PBARL, PBEAML, PCOMP / PCOMPG, PROD, PSHEAR, PSHELL, PLPLANE and PSOLID should be associated with PBARN1, PBEMN1, PSHLN1, PRODN1, PSHEARN, PSHLN1, PSHLN2 and PSLDN1 respectively. Also, linear 2D triangular elements specified on PSHLN2 and 3D tetrahedral elements specified on PSLDN1 should be associated with an incompressible formulation (IPS for 2D plane strain, IAX for 2D axisymmetric and ISOL for 3D tetrahedral).If the property extensions are missing, they are automatically added with appropriate setings by the program unless the user has set NLMOPTS,SPROPMAP,-1 in the bulk data. See remark 9. under the NLMOPTS  

12.RYIELD $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ LINMOHR, PBLMOHR and WKHARD $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ CHABOCHE and JHCOOK are only applicable to isotropic materials (MAT1).

Remarks:  

1. Unless continuation entry is present specifying various material models, von Mises yield criterion is used as default.   
2.If ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ is not specified, FID field referring to a stress-plastic strain curve must be provided. If ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ is specified without FID field, the material is assumed perfectly plastic or has one slope, H. If both ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ and FID fields are specified, FID supersedes the YO field and the first data point in TABLES1 represents ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ ， The initial yield point corresponds to the first data point in the function specified on the FID field. $\Upsilon(\overline{{\mathfrak{\textbf{\mathfrak{E}}}}}^{\mathfrak{p}})=\Upsilon_{0}(1+{\mathfrak{b}}\overline{{\mathfrak{\textbf{\mathfrak{E}}}}}^{\mathfrak{p}})^{\mathfrak{n}}$ where ${\mathrm{Y}}_{0}$ is an initial yield stress, b and n are parameters characterizing the stress-strain relationship. In case of an anisotropic material, the initial yield point corresponds to the reference yield stress $\mathrm{\langleY_{a}}$ in Remark 7.)   
3. For SOL 600, the form of the stress-strain curve is determined by parameters MRTABLSl and MRTABLS2.  

4. The plastic deformation starts when the effective stress $({\bar{\boldsymbol{\upsigma}}})$ exceeds the yield stress  

The yield stress is initially defined by the initial yield point, which is subsequently modified by the hardening rule to account for strain hardening. Under the isotropic hardening rule, the size of the yield surface expands as a function of efective plastic strain $(\bar{\mathfrak{E}}^{\mathfrak{p}})$ . Under the kinematic hardening rule, the center of the yield surface moves in stress space while keeping the same size and shape. Ziegler's law is used to define the translation of the yield surface. Under the combined hardening, the initial hardening is assumed to be entirely isotropic, but the elastic range attains a constant value (i.e., behaving like kinematic hardening) after some plastic straining.The efective stressfor von Mises is expressed as  

with  

$$
\overline{{\mathbb{O}}}~=~\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}[\left(\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{x}}-\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{y}}\right)^{2}+\left(\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{y}}-\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{z}}\right)^{2}+\left(\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{z}}-\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{x}}\right)^{2}]+3(\tau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}+\tau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}+\tau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2})}}
$$  

where the stress components are measured from the center of yield surface.  

$$
\mathrm{R}_{11}\ =\ \mathrm{\frac{Y}{Y_{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{22}=\mathrm{\frac{Y}{Y_{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{33}=\mathrm{\frac{Y}{Y_{a}}}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{R}_{12}\ =\ \frac{\sqrt{3}\mathrm{T}_{12}}{\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{23}=\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathrm{T}_{23}}{\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{31}=\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathrm{T}_{31}}{\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{a}}}
$$  

where $\mathrm{Y}_{1},\mathrm{Y}_{2}$ ,and ${\mathrm{Y}}_{3}$ are the initial tensile yield stresses measured in material directions 1, 2 and 3,respectively; $\mathrm{T}_{12},\mathrm{T}_{23}$ ,and $\mathrm{T}_{31}$ are the shear yield stresses in pure shear; and $\mathrm{Y_{a}}$ is the reference yield stress which should be an average yield stress in all directions.  

In practical applications, however, the initial yield stress cannot be measured in all directions. The plastic anisotropy is pronounced in the sheet metal due to prior rolling process,for which the plastic anisotropy is customarily characterized by r-values defined by strain ratio measured in the uniaxial tension, i.e.,  

$$
\mathrm{\boldmath~r_{a}~}=\mathrm{\boldmath~\frac{\varepsilon_{w}}{\varepsilon_{t}}}\ =\ \mathrm{\boldmath~\frac{l_{n}(w_{o}/w)}{l_{n}(t_{o}/t)}}\ =\ \mathrm{\frac{\partialH\+\(2N-F-G-4H)\sin^{2}\alpha\ \cos^{2}\alpha}{F\ \sin^{2}\alpha+G\cos^{2}\alpha}}
$$  

where t and w denote thickness and width, respectively; and $\upalpha$ denotes the angle of orientation (usually measured from the rolling direction). Assuming that the anisotropy parameters stay constant throughout the deformation, F, G, H and $_\mathrm{N}$ can be determined by r-values from tensile specimen cut at 0, 45 and 90 degrees to the rolling direction:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle{\frac{\mathrm{H}}{\mathrm{G}}}=\mathrm{r}_{0}\quad,\quad\displaystyle{\frac{\mathrm{H}}{\mathrm{F}}}=\mathrm{r}_{90}}}\\ {{\displaystyle{\frac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{G}}}=\biggl(\mathrm{r}_{45}+\frac{1}{2}\biggr)\biggl(1+\frac{\mathrm{r}_{0}}{\mathrm{r}_{90}}\biggr)}}\end{array}
$$  

The orthotropic plasticity parameters should be calculated from ther-values and the initial yield stress either in O or 90 degree direction ( $\mathrm{\cdotY_{0}}$ or $\mathrm{Y}_{90}$ )from the experiment. The yield stress in the thickness direction can be written as  

$$
\mathrm{Y_{th}~=~\mathrm{Y}_{0}}{\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}_{90}(1+\mathrm{r}_{0})}{\mathrm{r}_{0}+\mathrm{r}_{90}}}}=\mathrm{Y}_{90}{\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}_{0}(1+\mathrm{r}_{90})}{\mathrm{r}_{0}+\mathrm{r}_{90}}}}
$$  

Similarly, yield stresses in shear may be evaluated by  

$$
\mathrm{T}_{12}=\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{th}}\sqrt{\frac{1}{2\mathrm{r}_{45}+1}} 
$$  

and  

$$
\mathrm{T}_{23}=\mathrm{T}_{31}=\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\sqrt{3}\ }
$$  

in which the transverse direction is assumed isotropic.  

5. The Cowper and Symonds model scales the initial yield stress as a function of strain-rate, i.e.,  

$$
\Upsilon(\stackrel{\cdot}{\varepsilon})=\Upsilon_{0}\biggl[1+\biggl(\frac{\stackrel{\cdot}{\varepsilon}}{\bf C}\biggr)^{1/\mathrm{P}}\biggr]
$$  

6. Hillsanisotropic model introduces orthotropic plastic material. This option can only be combined with orthotropic or anisotropic elastic material (i.e., with MAT2, MATORT or MAT9). The plastic anisotropy proposed by Hillintroduces six parameters to the von Mises yield function, from which an effective stress may be derived as  

$$
{\overline{{\mathbb{O}}}}=\ {\sqrt{\operatorname{F}(\upsigma_{2}-\upsigma_{3})^{2}+\operatorname{G}(\upsigma_{3}-\upsigma_{1})^{2}+\operatorname{H}(\upsigma_{1}-\upsigma_{2})^{2}+2\operatorname{L}\uptau_{23}^{2}+2\mathbf{M}\uptau_{31}^{2}+2\mathbf{N}\uptau_{12}^{2}}}
$$  

in which the material parameters can be related to the yield stress ratios by  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}{\mathrm{~F~=~}\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{22}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{33}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{11}^{2}}\bigg)}&{}\\ {\mathrm{~G~=~}\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{33}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{11}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{22}^{2}}\bigg)}&{}\\ {\mathrm{~H~=~}\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{11}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{22}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{33}^{2}}\bigg)}&{}\\ {\mathrm{~L~=~}\frac{3}{2\mathrm{R}_{23}^{2}},\mathrm{~M~=~}\frac{3}{2\mathrm{R}_{31}^{2}},\mathrm{~N~}=\frac{3}{2\mathrm{R}_{12}^{2}}}\end{array}
$$  

with  

$$
\mathrm{R}_{11}~=~{\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{1}}{\mathrm{Y}_{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{22}={\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{2}}{\mathrm{Y}_{a}}},\mathrm{R}_{33}={\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{3}}{\mathrm{Y}_{a}}}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{R_{12}}~=~\mathrm{\frac{\sqrt{3}T_{12}}{Y_{a}}},\mathrm{R_{23}}=\mathrm{\frac{\sqrt{3}T_{23}}{Y_{a}}},\mathrm{R_{31}}=\mathrm{\frac{\sqrt{3}T_{31}}{Y_{a}}}
$$  

where $\mathrm{Y}_{1},\mathrm{Y}_{2}$ , and ${\mathrm{Y}}_{3}$ are the initial tensile yield stresses measured in material directions 1, 2 and 3, respectively; $\mathrm{T}_{12}$ ， $\mathrm{T}_{23}$ ,and $\mathrm{T}_{31}$ are the shear yield stresses in pure shear; and $\mathrm{Y_{a}}$ is the reference yield stress which should be an average yield stress in all directions.  

In practical applications, however, the initial yield stress cannot be measured in all directions. The plastic anisotropy is pronounced in the sheet metal due to prior rolling process,for which the plastic anisotropy is customarily characterized by r-values defined by strain ratio measured in the uniaxial tension, i.e.,  

$$
\mathrm{\boldmath~r_{a}~}=\mathrm{\boldmath~\frac{\varepsilon~}{}}_{\mathrm{\bf{E}}_{t}}\ =\ \mathrm{\boldmath~\frac{~l~}{~l~}}(\mathrm{w}_{\mathrm{o}}/\mathrm{w})\ =\ \mathrm{\boldmath~\frac{H~}{~\Gamma~}}(2\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{F}-\mathrm{G}-4\mathrm{H})\sin^{2}\alpha\ \cos^{2}\alpha
$$  

where t and w denote thickness and width, respectively; and $\upalpha$ denotes the angle of orientation (usualy measured from the rolling direction). Assuming that the anisotropy parameters stay constant throughout the deformation,F, G, H and N can be determined by r-values from tensile specimen cut at 0, 45 and 90 degrees to the rolling direction:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle{\frac{\ H}{\mathbf{G}}}\ =\ \mathbf{r}_{0}\quad,\quad\displaystyle{\frac{\ H}{\mathbf{F}}}=\mathbf{r}_{90}}}\\ {{\displaystyle{\frac{\ N}{\mathbf{G}}}\ =\ \biggl(\mathbf{r}_{45}+\displaystyle{\frac{1}{2}}\biggr)\biggl(1+\displaystyle{\frac{\mathbf{r}_{0}}{\mathbf{r}_{90}}}\biggr)}}\end{array}
$$  

The orthotropic plasticity parameters should be calculated from the r-values and the initial yield stress either in O or 90 degree direction ( $\mathrm{\cdotY_{0}}$ or $\mathrm{Y}_{90}$ ) from the experiment. The yield stress in the thickness direction can be written as  

$$
\mathrm{Y_{th}~=~\mathrm{Y}_{0}\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}_{90}(1+\mathrm{r}_{0})}{\mathrm{r}_{0}+\mathrm{r}_{90}}}~=~\mathrm{Y}_{90}\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}_{0}(1+\mathrm{r}_{90})}{\mathrm{r}_{0}+\mathrm{r}_{90}}}}
$$  

Similarly, yield stresses in shear may be evaluated by  

$$
\mathrm{T}_{12}=\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{th}}\sqrt{\frac{1}{2{\bf r}_{45}+1}} 
$$  

and  

$$
\mathrm{T}_{23}~=~\mathrm{T}_{31}~=~\frac{\mathrm{Y}_{a}}{\sqrt{3}\ }
$$  

in which the transverse direction is assumed isotropic  

7. The elasticity constants must be isotropic for ORNL plasticity except for normal ORNL model for stainless steel. The 10th cycle stressplastic strain curve in TID field should bea normalized function so that the yield stress at zero plastic strain is unity.  

8.The pressure-dependent yielding, based on Drucker-Prager yield criterion, contains threeoptions for frictional materials such as rocks and concrete. The generalized Mohr-Coulomb criterion introduces linear and parabolic models, developed by Drucker and Prager. The linear Mohr-Coulomb model assumes a linear function of hydrostatic stress for a yield function, i.e.,  

$$
\mathrm{aI}_{1}+\sqrt{\mathrm{J}_{2}}-\frac{\mathrm{\Lambda}_{\overline{{\Omega}}}^{-}}{\sqrt{3}}=0\mathrm{or}\mathrm{\Lambda}_{\overline{{\Omega}}}^{-}=\sqrt{3}\upalpha\mathrm{\LambdaI}_{1}+\sqrt{3\mathrm{J}_{2}}
$$  

where  

$$
\mathrm{I}_{1}=\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}
$$  

and  

$$
{\bf J}_{2}=\frac{1}{6}[{(\upsigma_{1}-\upsigma_{2})}^{2}+{(\upsigma_{2}-\upsigma_{3})}^{2}+{(\upsigma_{3}-\upsigma_{1})}^{2}]
$$  

The parameters $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\bar{\mathsf{\Pi}}_{\bar{\mathsf{{\Phi}}}}^{-}$ (effective stress coinciding with the yield stress) can be related to material constants c (cohesion) and $\upphi$ (frictional angle) by  

$$
\mathrm{~c~}=\frac{\frac{-}{\sigma}}{3\sqrt{(1-12\alpha^{2})}}
$$  

and  

$$
s i n\Phi=\frac{3\alpha}{\sqrt{1-3\alpha^{2}}}
$$  

The parabolic Mohr-Coulomb model allows a yield envelope to be parabolic in the plane strain case, for which the yield function is expressed as  

$$
{\sqrt{3\mathbf{J}_{2}+{\sqrt{3}}\upbeta{\overline{{\mathbf{\sigma}}}}\mathbf{I}_{1}}}-{\overline{{\mathbf{\sigma}}}}=0
$$  

in which parameters are related to the material constants by  

$$
\overline{a}^{2}=3(c^{2}-\frac{a^{2}}{3})
$$  

and  

$$
\beta=\frac{\alpha}{\sqrt{3(3\mathrm{c}^{2}-\mathrm{a}^{2})}}
$$  

9. The Drucker-Prager plasticity models can only be combined with isotropic elasticity. The Buyukozturk concrete plasticity model is a particular form of the generalized Drucker-Prager plasticity model, which is developed specifically for plane stress cases by Buyukozturk. The Buyukozturk yield function is expressed as  

$$
{\upbeta}\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{Y}}{\mathrm{I}}_{1}+{\upgamma}{\mathrm{I}}_{1}^{2}+3{\mathrm{J}}_{2}-{\mathrm{Y}}^{2}=0
$$  

where $\upbeta$ is a user-specified constant, $\gamma$ is an internal parameter (set to 0.2) with no user's access, and $\mathrm{\DeltaY}$ is the yield stress.  

The Buyukozturk concrete plasticity model is coupled with crack and crush capability, which is designed for a low-tension material. The low-tension material develops a crack in the perpendicular direction to the maximum principal stress when it exceeds a critical value. The tension softening modulus can be specified (in absolute value) by the user to process the cracking process gradually. The default value (O.)is intended for a sudden cracking with a complete loss of the stiffness upon cracking. After the initial crack, a second crack can initiate in the perpendicular direction to the first crack. Likewise, the third crack can be formed in 3D solid elements. The loading may reverse the direction after the crack is formed.In this case, the crack will close and someload carrying capacity is resumed. The compression capability is fully resumed and the shear stresses may be transmitted over the crack surface with a reduced stiffnessby a factor specified as shear retention factor. The material may fail in compression by crushing. The input value for the crush strain is positive, which implies an absolute value of a compressive strain. The material loses its integrity for good upon crushing. The reinforcement bars may be simulated by adding REBAR elements.  

10. The Gurson model for porous metal plasticity may be used only with isotropic hardening rule. All other hardening rules will be ignored if Gurson model is selected. The Gurson model modified by Tvergaard and Needleman is designed for porous metal plasticity with damage effects in the ductile material.The material is assume to form voids under loading, which grow, coalesce, then leads to crack formation and eventually failure. This process is a function of hydrostatic stress and the void volume fraction $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}$ . The yield function is established as follows:  

$$
\frac{3\mathrm{J}_{2}}{\mathrm{Y}^{2}}+2\mathrm{q}_{1}\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\ast}c o s h\bigg(\frac{\mathrm{q}_{2}\mathrm{I}_{1}}{2\mathrm{Y}}\bigg)-[1-\big(\mathrm{q}_{1}\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\ast}\big)^{2}]=0
$$  

in which $\mathrm{Y}$ denotes a yield stress of the fully dense matrix material, $\mathrm{I}_{1}$ denotes the first invariant of stresses, and the modified void volume fraction $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\ast}$ is computed by  

$$
\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\ast}=\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{if~f_{v}\leq f_{v}^{c}}
$$  

$$
\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{*}}=\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{c}}+\biggl(\frac{\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{u}}-\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{c}}}{\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{f}}-\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{c}}}\biggr)(\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}-\bf f_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{c}}) 
$$  

$$
\mathrm{if\f_{v}>f_{v}^{c}}
$$  

where $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{c}}$ is the critical void volume fraction, $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{f}}$ is the void volume at failure and $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{u}}=1/\mathbf{q}_{1}$ . The solid loses all stress carrying capability when the void volume fraction reaches $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{f}}$ ·  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/41783b014e6a368e3745179cee4ace67345b228ddba72486f9ecf4d6d3c93e38.jpg)  

11. The evolution of damage as measured by void volume fraction is due to void nucleation and void growth.Void nucleation occurs by debonding of the second phase particles. The strain for nucleation depends on the particle sizes. Assuming a normal distribution of particle sizes, the void nucleation itself is modeled as a normal distribution in strains if nucleation is strain-controlled. If the void nucleation is assumed to be stress controlled in the matrix, a normal distribution is assumed in stresses.The void volume fraction changes due to the growth of existing voids and nucleation of new voids, i.e.,  

$$
\dot{\mathrm{f_{v}}}=\dot{\mathrm{f}}_{\mathrm{growth}}+\dot{\mathrm{f}}_{\mathrm{nucleation}}
$$  

in which the void growth can be determined based on the compressbility of the material  

$$
\dot{\mathrm{f_{growth}}}\ =\ (1-\mathrm{f_{v}})\dot{\varepsilon}_{\mathrm{kk}}^{\mathfrak{p}}
$$  

and the nucleation can be defined either as strain or stress-controlled with a normal distribution about the mean value. In case of strain-controlled nucleation, the rate is expressed as  

$$
\dot{\mathrm{f}}_{\mathrm{nucleation}}=\frac{\mathrm{\bf~f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{n}}}{\sqrt[\mathrm{2}\pi]}\mathrm{Exp}\Bigg[{-}\frac{1}{2}\Bigg(\frac{\varepsilon_{\mathrm{m}}^{\mathrm{p}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{n}}}{\mathrm{S}}\Bigg)^{2}\Bigg]\dot{\varepsilon}_{\mathrm{m}}
$$  

where $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{n}}$ is the volume fraction of void forming particles, $\bar{\mathfrak{E}}_{\mathrm{m}}^{\mathfrak{p}}$ denotes the effective plastic strain in the matrix material, and the void nucleation strain is assumed normally distributed with a mean value of $\textstyle\mathbf{\E_{n}}$ and a standard deviation of S . In case of stress-controlled nucleation, the rate is expressed as  

$$
\dot{\bf f}_{\mathrm{nucleation}}=\frac{{\bf f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{n}}}{{\bf S}\sqrt{2\pi}}\mathrm{Exp}\left[-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\overline{{{\sigma}}}+\frac{1}{3}\upsigma_{\mathrm{kk}}-\upsigma_{\mathrm{n}}}{\mathrm{S}}\right)^{2}\right]\left(\dot{\overline{{\sigma}}}+\frac{1}{3}\dot{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{kk}}\right)
$$  

If the size of the second phase particles are widely dispersed,the standard deviation would be larger than more uniform cases. A typical values for an engineering alloy as suggested by numerical experiments are set as default values for $\pmb{\varepsilon}_{\mathrm{n}}$ ,S,and $\mathbf{f}_{\mathrm{v}}^{\mathrm{n}}$ ，

Remarks:  

1. A bilinear stress-strain characteristic is used by specifying FORM $\dot{.}=\dot{}$ SLOPE, YO and H:  

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/extract/456bb405-2a22-403a-8e2b-4f7add2e1f33/7196d4f6ee3541f4cbc029358679c7dc952337fa2cd29ae1060d9a0566ef5ff0.jpg)  

where the equivalent stress is given by $\upsigma=\upsigma_{o}+\frac{E\cdot E_{h}}{E-E_{h}}\varepsilon_{p}$ where  

<html><body><table><tr><td>00</td><td>= yield stress specified in the YO field</td></tr><tr><td>E</td><td>= Young's modulus</td></tr><tr><td>Eb</td><td>= hardening modulus specified in the H field</td></tr><tr><td>&p</td><td>= equivalent plastic strain</td></tr><tr><td>9</td><td>= equivalent stress</td></tr></table></body></html>  

2.A piecewise linear,stressstrain characteristic is used by specifying FID and TYPE (beams and shells only)  

$$
\sigma=[(\sigma_{i}-\sigma_{i-l})(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{i-l})/(\varepsilon_{i}-\varepsilon_{i-l})]+\sigma_{i-l}
$$  

The stress-strain characteristic used internally in Nastran SOL700 is in terms of true stress and equivalent plastic strain. However, for convenience, the stress-strain characteristic can be input in any of the following ways:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>True stress/true strain</td><td>(TYPE = TRUE)</td></tr><tr><td>Engineering stress/engineering strain</td><td>(TYPE=ENG)</td></tr><tr><td>True stress/plastic strain</td><td>(TYPE = PLAST)</td></tr><tr><td>Plastic modulus/true stress</td><td>(TYPE = PMOD)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

3.With solid elements,only an elastic perfectly plastic yield model is currently used. Only the Yo field is used.  

4.If FID is blank or zero,a bilinear stress-strain curve is assumed. If FID has a value, it refers to a TABLED1 entry giving the stress-strain curve for the material.  

5.IfFID is defined,the value of YIELD isleft blank, since it is determined from the stress-strain curve.  

6.If RTID is blank or zero and C and P are blank or zero, the yield stressdoes not vary with strain rate. If RTID has a value, then it referencesa TABLED1 entry, which gives the variation of the scale factor applied to the yield stress with strain rate. (C and P must be blank or zero.)  

If RTID is blank or zero and $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{\DeltaP}$ are defined, the enhancement of the yield stress with strain rate is calculated as  

$$
\frac{\sigma_{d}}{\sigma_{y}}~=~I+\left(\frac{\dot{\varepsilon}_{p}}{C}\right)^{I/p}
$$  

where $\mathrm{\mathit{?}d}$ is the dynamic stress, $\vdots_{\mathrm{y}}$ is the static yield stress, and $\mathbf{\delta}\varepsilon_{p}$ is the equivalent plastic strain rate  

7. If TYPE is PLAST or PMOD, Young's modulus must be defined. If TYPE is ENG or TRUE and Young's modulus is defined, it overrides the value calculated from the stress-strain curve.  

8.Note that for values exceeding the maximum x-value of either of the TABLEDl entries (see FID and RTID fields), linear extrapolation is used based upon the last two points specified in the TABLED1.  

9. The Johnson Cook yield stress is computed from  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}=(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B}\upvarepsilon_{\mathrm{p}}^{\mathrm{~N~}})\Bigg[1+\mathrm{C}l n\Bigg(\frac{\dot{\upvarepsilon}}{\dot{\upvarepsilon}_{0}}\Bigg)\Bigg](1-\mathrm{T}^{\ast\mathrm{M}})}\end{array}
$$  

where  

<html><body><table><tr><td>&p</td><td>= effective plastic strain</td></tr><tr><td>T*</td><td>T-TROOM</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TMELT-TROOM</td></tr><tr><td>·ε</td><td>： reference strain rate</td></tr><tr><td>： &0</td><td>= reference strain rate</td></tr><tr><td>T TROOM</td><td>= temperature</td></tr><tr><td>TMELT</td><td>= room temperature</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>= melt temperature</td></tr></table></body></html>  

A, B, N, C, and $\mathbf{M}$ are input constants.  

10. The reference strain rate for Johnson Cook yield model is per unit time.  

11. The rate power law yield stress is computed from  

<html><body><table><tr><td>&p</td><td>= effective plastic strain</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>= reference strain rate</td></tr></table></body></html>  

A, B, M,N and C are constants.  

12. The polynomial yield stress is computed from  

$\sigma_{y}=\mathrm{MIN}(\mathrm{YMAX},A+B\varepsilon_{p}+C{\varepsilon_{p}}^{2}+D{\varepsilon_{p}}^{3}+E{\varepsilon_{p}}^{4}+F{\varepsilon_{p}}^{5})$ where  

<html><body><table><tr><td>&p</td><td>= effective plastic strain</td></tr><tr><td>YMAX</td><td>= maximum yield stress</td></tr></table></body></html>  

A, B, C,D,E and F are constants.  

13. The Tanimura-Mimura yield stress is computed from  

$$
\sigma_{y}=\Bigg[A+B\varepsilon_{p}+(C+D\varepsilon_{p})\Big(1-\frac{A+B\varepsilon_{p}}{\sigma_{c r}}\Big)\mathrm{In}\Bigg(\frac{\dot{\varepsilon}}{\dot{\varepsilon}_{s}}\Bigg)\Bigg](1-T^{*M})+E\Bigg(\frac{\dot{\varepsilon}}{\dot{\varepsilon}_{o}}\Bigg)^{K}
$$  

where  

<html><body><table><tr><td>&p</td><td>= effective plastic strain</td></tr><tr><td>Ocr</td><td>= critical yield stress</td></tr><tr><td>.ε</td><td>= effective strain rate</td></tr><tr><td>&s</td><td>= quasi-static strain rate</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>= reference strain rate</td></tr><tr><td>T*</td><td>T-TROOM</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>TMELT－TROOM</td></tr><tr><td>T</td><td>= temperature</td></tr><tr><td>TROOM</td><td>= room temperature</td></tr><tr><td>TMELT</td><td>= melt temperature</td></tr></table></body></html>  

A, B, D, M, E and K are constants  

14. The Zerilli-Armstrong yield stress is computed from  

$$
\sigma_{y}~=~\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{\displaystyle{\left(A+B{\varepsilon_{p}}^{N}\right)}\mathrm{e}^{\left[-M T+C T l n\left(\frac{\dot{\varepsilon}}{\varepsilon_{0}}\right)\right]}}&{\quad\mathrm{for~Fcc~metals}}\\ {\displaystyle{\left[\left(A+B{\varepsilon_{p}}^{N}\right)+\mathrm{De}^{\left[-M T+C T l n\left(\frac{\dot{\varepsilon}}{\varepsilon_{0}}\right)\right]}\right]}}&{\quad\mathrm{for~Bcc~metals}}\end{array}\right.
$$  

where   


<html><body><table><tr><td>&p</td><td>= effective plastic strain</td></tr><tr><td>.ε</td><td>= effective strain rate</td></tr><tr><td>：</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>0</td><td>= reference strain rate</td></tr><tr><td>T</td><td>= temperature</td></tr></table></body></html>  

A, B, N,C,M and D are constants.  

15.If the initial Poisson's ratios in MATORTare not supplied, the default is set to zero.Therefore, the behavior of the material during compaction is uncoupled.This means that straining in the(local) xdirection produces stresses only in the (local) $\mathbf{x}$ -direction, and not in the (local) y- or z-direction. The tables define the variation of the stressin a particular direction with the relative volume or the crush. The relative volume is defined as (current volume)/(initial volume) and varies from 1.0 (uncompressed) to 0.O (zero volume). Crush is defined as one minus the relative volume and varies from 0.0 to 1.0. Since the tables should be defined with increasing x-values, it is convenient to use the default value for type, which is CRUSH. When defining the curves, care should be taken that the extrapolated values do not lead to negative yield stresses.   
16. The elastic moduli (and the initial Poisson's ratios only if they are supplied) in MATORT vary linearly with the relative volume from their initial uncompacted values to the fully compacted one:   
17.When the material is fully compacted, its behavior becomes isotropic with an elastic perfectly plastic material characteristic.   
18.If the TIDSR option is used,you can supplya table including strain-rate effects.Strain rate is defined here as the Euclidean norm of the deviatoric strain-rate tensor; i.e.,  

$$
\dot{\textbf{\mathfrak{E}}}=\sqrt{\mathcal{E}_{i j}^{\dot{d}e\nu}\cdot\mathcal{E}_{i j}^{\dot{d}e\nu}}
$$  

The y values in this table are factors with which the stresses in the other tables are multiplied to incorporate strain-rate effects.  

19.The pressure-volume characteristic can either be defined in terms of the amount of crush,which is minus the engineering strain and is defined as $\left(1-{\frac{V}{V_{0}}}\right)$ , with $\frac{V}{V_{0}}$ as the relative volume; or in terms of the volumetric (true) strain which is defined as:  

$$
\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\mathrm{dV}}{\mathrm{V}}
$$  

or  

$$
l n\Big(\frac{\mathrm{v}}{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{0}}}\Big)
$$  

The crush factor must be between O and 1. The volumetric strain must always be negative.  

20.If the field for the value ofCUTOFF is left blank, then this value is calculated from the yield function defined by the constants A0, Al, and A2. In case of a Mohr-Coulomb yield model, the cut-off pressure is calculated as the root of the pressure-yield stress curve. If the YIELD $\mathord{\left.\vert}=1.0\right\vert$ is used, the cutoffpressure is calculated as the intersection point of the yield surface with the hydrostat (if only AO is nonzero, then the cut-off pressure is set to -10oK, where K is the bulk modulus).The cut-offpressure must be negative.  

21. Either a minimum pressure $(\mathrm{CUTOFF}{=}3.0),$ or a failure pressure $(\mathrm{CUTOFF}{=}1.0\$ or 2.0) can be specified. In the first case, this corresponds to a tensile cutof, where the pressure cannot fall below the minimum value.In the second case, if the pressure falls below the failure pressure the element fails and cannot carry tensile loading for the remainder of the analysis. Thus, the pressure can never become negative again. If CUTOFF $\overset{\cdot}{\underset{\r{\r}}{=}}1.0$ is used, the elements can physically fail, which means that the stresses are set to zero, but also the failure flag is used as in normal MATF models. If CUTOFF $\cdot=2.0$ is used, only the stresses are set to zero.  

22.IfYIELD $=1.0$ is used, the yield stress is determined by a Mohr-Coulomb model:  

$$
\sigma_{y}=\mathrm{MIN}(A_{0}+A_{I}p,A_{2})
$$  

If YIELD $\scriptstyle\mathbf{\bar{\alpha}}=2.0$ is used, the yield surface in three-dimensional space is defined by $\scriptstyle{\?_{s}=0}$ here  

$$
\Phi_{\mathrm{{s}}}={\frac{1}{2}}S_{i j}S_{i j}-(B_{0}+B_{1}p+B_{2}p^{2})={\mathrm{J}_{2}}\mathrm{{-}}(B_{0}+B_{1}p+B_{2}p^{2})
$$  

where $s_{\mathrm{ij}}$ are the deviatoric stresses and $\mathrm{J}_{2}$ is the second invariant of the stress deviation. The coefficients $\mathtt{B}_{0},\mathtt{B}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{B}_{2}$ can be related to the coefficients $\mathrm{A}_{0},\mathrm{A}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{A}_{2}$ . The relation between the coefficients depends on the YSTYP field as shown below.  

If $\mathrm{YSTYP}{=}2.0$ then  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\mathrm B_{0}=\mathrm A_{0}}\\ {\mathrm B_{1}=\mathrm A_{1}}\\ {\mathrm B_{2}=\mathrm A_{2}}\end{array}
$$  

Thus, the yield stress is defined as $\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}\ =\ \sqrt{3(A_{o}+A_{1}p+A_{2}{\bf p}^{2})}$ If $\mathrm{YSTYP=}1.0$ ，then  

$$
B_{0}\ =\ {\frac{1}{3}}{A_{0}}^{2}
$$  

$$
B_{1}\ =\ \frac{2}{3}A_{0}A_{1}
$$  

$$
B_{2}\ =\ {\frac{1}{3}}{A_{1}}^{2}
$$  

and A2 is ignored.   
Thus, the yield stress is defined as $\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}=\mathbf{A}_{0}+\mathbf{A}_{1}\mathbf{p}$

The value in a particular field of the MATl entry is replaced by the table referenced in the corresponding field of this entry. Blank or zero entries mean that there is no frequency dependence of the fields on the MAT1 entry.   
2. The user is reminded that on the MATl entry, if any one of the entries E,G,or, NU is left blank, they are connected by the relationship $\mathrm{G}{=}\mathrm{E}/(2(1{+}\mathrm{NU}))$ . Therefore, the user is cautioned that leaving one of these entries blank or only making one of these entries spatially,frequency, or temperature dependent may lead to unexpected results.   
3. Table references must be present for each item that is frequency dependent   
4. Where applicable, secondary material entries such as the MATVE are supported through their MID field being associated with a primary material entry such as a MAT1 entry.

Remarks:  

1. The MATF Bulk Data entry contains supplementary data for failure index calculation and failure prediction of the elastic materials with the same MID.If this capability is used in nonlinear analysis, MATF can activate a progressive failure process.  

2. Progressive failure behavior for various materials can be simulated using the MATF Bulk Data entry. Failure occurs when any one of the specified failure criterion is satisfied; thatis, the calculated failure index exceeds 1.0. Upon failure, the elastic moduli are reduced. This is done differently depending on failure criterion. The behavior up to the failure point is linear elastic.After failure the behavior is still elastic but with a different stiffness. The option should not be combined with other material nonlinearities like plasticity.  

3. According to the Maximum Stress Criterion, six failure indices $\mathrm{F_{i}}$ are calculated as follows:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}{\displaystyle\frac{\mathfrak{o}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{V}_{1}}\qquad}&{\mathrm{for~}\mathfrak{o}_{\mathrm{x}}>0}\\ {\displaystyle\mathrm{F}_{1}=\frac{-\mathfrak{o}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{V}_{2}}\qquad}&{}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}{\mathrm{\Delta}}&{\underset{\mathrm{{V}_{3}}}{\overset{\mathtt{O}_{\mathtt{y}}}{\operatorname{m}}}}&{\quad\mathrm{for~}\mathrm{\Delta}\sigma_{\mathrm{y}}>0}\\ &{\mathrm{\Delta}}&{\frac{-\sigma_{\mathrm{y}}}{\mathrm{V_{4}}}}&{\quad\mathrm{for~}\mathrm{\Delta}\sigma_{\mathrm{y}}<0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}{\mathrm{F}_{3}~=~\displaystyle\frac{\mathfrak{O}_{z}}{\mathrm{V}_{5}}~}&{{}}&{\mathrm{for~}\mathfrak{O}_{z}>0}\\ {\displaystyle\frac{-\mathfrak{O}_{z}}{\mathrm{V}_{6}}~}&{{}}&{\mathrm{for~}\mathfrak{O}_{z}<0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{4}=\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\mathrm{V}_{7}}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{5}=\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}}{\mathrm{V}_{8}}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{6}~=~\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{zx}}}{\mathrm{V}_{9}}
$$  

where the indices $(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z})$ denote material coordinate direction.   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{x}$ -direction in tension. Real $>0.0$ , no Default.  

$\mathrm{~V}_{2}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{x}$ -direction in compression. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$ $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ : maximum allowable stress in the y-direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default. $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{4}}$ : maximum allowable stress in the y-direction in compression. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ $\mathrm{v}_{5}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{z}$ -direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ ; no Default $\mathrm{v}_{6}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{z}$ direction in compression. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{5}$ $\mathrm{v}_{7}$ : maximum allowable in-plane shear stress. Real $>0.0$ no Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{8}}$ : maximum allowable yz shear stress. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{7}$ $\mathrm{V}_{9}{\mathrm{:}}$ maximum allowable zx shear stress. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{v}_{7}$  

4. According to the Maximum Strain Criterion, 6 failure indices $\mathrm{F_{i}}$ are calculated as follows:  

$\begin{array}{r l}{\displaystyle\frac{\mathfrak{E}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathbf{W}_{1}}}&{\qquad\mathrm{for~}\mathfrak{e}_{\mathrm{x}}>0}\\ {\displaystyle\mathrm{F}_{1}}&{=\begin{array}{r l}{\displaystyle-\mathfrak{E}_{\mathrm{x}}}&{\qquad}\\ {\displaystyle\overline{{\mathbf{W}_{2}}}}&{\qquad\mathrm{for~}\mathfrak{e}_{\mathrm{x}}<0}\end{array}}\end{array}$ $\begin{array}{r}{\mathrm{F_{2}}~{=}~\frac{\displaystyle\frac{\partial\varepsilon_{y}}{\partial W_{3}}}{\displaystyle\frac{-\varepsilon_{y}}{W_{4}}}}\end{array}$ for $\mathtt{g_{y}}>0$ for $\mathrm{\varepsilon_{y}}<0$ $\begin{array}{r l r}{\mathbf{F}_{3}}&{=\begin{array}{l}{\displaystyle\frac{\mathbf{\deltaE}_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathbf{W}_{5}}\qquad}&{\mathrm{for~}\varepsilon_{\mathrm{z}}>0}\\ {\displaystyle\frac{-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathbf{W}_{6}}\qquad}&{\mathrm{for~}\varepsilon_{\mathrm{z}}<0}\end{array}}\end{array}$ $\mathrm{F}_{4}=\frac{\varepsilon_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\mathrm{W}_{7}}$   
$\mathrm{F}_{5}=\frac{\varepsilon_{\mathrm{yz}}}{\mathrm{W}_{8}}$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{6}=\frac{\varepsilon_{_{Z X}}}{\mathrm{W}_{9}}
$$  

where the indices $(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z})$ denote material coordinate direction. $\mathrm{W}_{1}$ : maximum allowable strain in the $\mathbf{x}\mathbf{\cdot}$ -direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default. $\mathrm{W}_{2}$ : maximum allowable strain in the $\mathbf{x}\mathbf{\cdot}$ -direction in compression. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathbf{W}_{1}$ ${\bf W}_{3}$ : maximum allowable strain in the y-direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default. $\mathrm{W}_{4}$ : maximum allowable strain in the y-direction in compression. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default ${\bf W}_{3}$ $\mathrm{w}_{\mathfrak{s}}$ : maximum allowable strain in the $z$ -direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ ; no Default $\mathrm{w}_{6}$ : maximum allowable strain in the $z$ direction in compression. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{w}_{\mathfrak{s}}$ $\mathrm{w}_{7}$ : maximum allowable shear strain in the xy plane. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ no Default ${\mathrm{W}}_{8}$ : maximum allowable shear strain in the yz plane. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{W}_{7}$ ${\sf W}_{9}$ : maximum allowable shear strain in the zx plane. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{w}_{7}$  

5. According to the Hill Failure Criterion, there is no distinction between tensile and compressive behavior. A single failure index is calculated as:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\mathrm{F}=[\frac{\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{x}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}}+\frac{\mathbb{O}_{\mathrm{y}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{3}^{2}}+\frac{\mathbb{O}_{z}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{5}^{2}}-\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}^{2}}\right)\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}\sigma_{\mathrm{y}}-\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}^{2}}\right)\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}\sigma_{\mathrm{z}}}\\ &{\quad\quad\quad-\biggl(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}}\biggr)\sigma_{\mathrm{y}}\sigma_{\mathrm{z}}+\frac{\mathbb{T}_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{7}^{2}}+\frac{\mathbb{T}_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{8}^{2}}+\frac{\mathbb{T}_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{9}^{2}}\biggr]/\mathrm{Find}}\end{array}
$$  

where the indices $(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z})$ denote material coordinate direction.  

$\mathrm{v}_{1}\colon$ maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{x}$ -direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default. $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ : maximum allowable stress in the y-direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default. $\mathrm{v}_{5}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{z}$ -direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ ; no Default $\mathrm{v}_{7}$ : maximum allowable in-plane shear stress. Real $>0.0$ no Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{8}}$ : maximum allowable yz shear stress. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{7}$ $\mathrm{V}_{9}\colon$ maximum allowable zx shear stress. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{v}_{7}$  

6. The Hoffman Failure Criterion introduces distinction between tensile and compressive stresses to generalize the Hill Failure Criterion. A single failure index F is calculated as:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{\displaystyle\mathrm{F=(C_{x}(\upsigma_{x}-\upsigma_{y})^{2}+C_{y}(\upsigma_{y}-\upsigma_{z})^{2}+C_{z}(\upsigma_{z}-\upsigma_{x})^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{1}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{2}}\right)\upsigma_{x}}}\\ {\displaystyle\quad\quad+\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{4}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{6}}\right)\upsigma_{z}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{7}^{2}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{8}^{2}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{9}^{2}}\right]/\mathrm{Find}}}\end{array}
$$  

with  

$$
\mathrm{C_{\mathrm{x}}\ =\ \frac{1}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V_{1}V_{2}}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{V_{3}V_{4}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}\mathrm{V}_{6}}\bigg)}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{C_{y}\ =\ \frac{1}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{V_{3}V_{4}}+\frac{1}{V_{5}V_{6}}-\frac{1}{V_{1}V_{2}}\bigg)}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{C_{z}}~=~{\frac{1}{2}}\bigg({\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}\mathrm{V_{6}}}}+{\frac{1}{\mathrm{V_{1}V_{2}}}}-{\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}\mathrm{V_{4}}}}\bigg)
$$  

where the indices $(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z})$ denote material coordinate direction.  

$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$ :maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{x}$ -direction in tension $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ , no Default).   
$\mathrm{~V}_{2}$ : maximum alowable stress in the $\mathbf{x}$ -direction in compression $\mathrm{|Real>0.0}$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$ ） $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ : maximum allowable stress in the y-direction in tension ( $\mathrm{\'Real}>0.0$ , no Default).   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{4}}$ :maximum allowable stressin the y-direction in compression $\mathrm{\Real>0.0}$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ ） $\mathrm{v}_{5}$ :maximum alowable stress in the z-direction in tension $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ , no Default).   
$\mathrm{v}_{6}$ :maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{z}$ -direction in compression $(\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{v}_{5}$ ） $\mathrm{v}_{7}$ :maximum allowable in-plane shear stress $\mathrm{\langleReal>0.0}$ , no Default).   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{8}}$ : maximum allowable yz shear stress $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ , no Default $\mathrm{v}_{7}$ ）   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{9}}$ : maximum alowable zx shear stress $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ , no Default $\mathrm{v}_{7}$ ）  

7.The Tsai-Wu Failure Criterion is another generalization of the HillFailure Criterion.A single failure index $\mathrm{~F~}$ is calculated as:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}{\mathrm{\boldmath~{\cal~F}=}}&{\Big[\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{1}}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{2}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{4}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}}-\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{6}}\right)\upsigma_{z}+\displaystyle\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{1}\mathrm{V}_{2}}+\displaystyle\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{3}\mathrm{V}_{4}}+\displaystyle\frac{\upsigma_{z}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{5}\mathrm{V}_{6}}}}\\ &{\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad+\displaystyle\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{7}^{2}}+\displaystyle\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{8}^{2}}+\displaystyle\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{9}^{2}}+2\mathrm{V}_{10}\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+2\mathrm{V}_{11}\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}\upsigma_{z}+2\mathrm{V}_{12}\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}\bigg]/\mathrm{Find}^{3}}}\end{array}
$$  

where the indices $(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z})$ denote material coordinate direction.   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{x}$ -direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default.   
$\mathrm{~V}_{2}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{x}$ -direction in compression. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$ $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ : maximum allowable stress in the y-direction in tension. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default.   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{4}}$ : maximum allowable stress in the y-direction in compression. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ $\mathrm{v}_{5}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{z}$ -direction in tension. Real $>0.0$ ; no Default   
$\mathrm{v}_{6}$ : maximum allowable stress in the $\mathbf{z}$ -direction in compression. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{v}_{5}$ $\mathrm{v}_{7}$ : maximum allowable in-plane shear stress. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ no Default   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{8}}$ : maximum allowable yz shear stress. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{7}$   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{9}}$ : maximum allowable zx shear stress. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{7}$   
$\mathrm{V}_{10}:$ interactive strength constant for the xy plane. Real; no Default   
$\mathrm{v}_{11}$ : interactive strength constant for the yz plane. Real; no Default   
$\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{12}$ : interactive strength constant for the zx plane. Real; no Default   
The following restrictions apply to $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{10},V_{11}}$ and $\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{12}$ ：  

$$
\mathrm{V}_{10}^{2}<\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{1}\mathrm{V}_{2}}\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}\mathrm{V}_{4}}{}\mathrm{V}_{11}^{2}<\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{3}\mathrm{V}_{4}}\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}\mathrm{V}_{6}}{}\mathrm{V}_{12}^{2}<\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{1}\mathrm{V}_{2}}\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{5}\mathrm{V}_{6}}
$$  

8. For the Hashin criterion four failure indices are calculated:  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\mathrm{\boldmath~F~}_{1}=\displaystyle\sideset{}{'}\left(\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{\boldmath~V~}_{1}}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{\boldmath~V~}_{10}^{2}}(\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}+\uptau_{\mathrm{xz}}^{2})\qquad\mathrm{\boldmath~\upsigma~}_{\mathrm{x}}>0}\\ {0\qquad\quad0\quad\qquad}&{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\leq0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{2}\ =\begin{array}{l l l}{\displaystyle\frac{\left|\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathrm{x}}\right|}{\mathbf{V}_{2}}}&{\qquad\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathrm{x}}<0}\\ {0}&{\qquad}&{\qquad\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathrm{x}}\geq0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}{\mathbf{F}_{3}}&{=}&{\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathbf{V}_{3}^{2}}(\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{y}}+\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{z}})^{2}+\frac{1}{\mathbf{V}_{11}^{2}}(\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}-\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{y}}\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{z}})+\frac{1}{\mathbf{V}_{10}^{2}}(\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}+\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{xz}}^{2})\quad\quad\quad\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{y}}+\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{z}}>0}\\ &{\quad\displaystyle0\quad\quad\quad}&{\quad\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{y}}+\boldsymbol{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{z}}\leq0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{\displaystyle\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{4}}\Big(\Big(\frac{\mathrm{V}_{4}}{2\mathrm{V}_{11}}\Big)^{2}-1\right)(\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\upsigma_{z})+\displaystyle\frac{1}{4\mathrm{V}_{11}^{2}}(\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}})^{2}+}}\\ {{\mathrm{F}_{4}~=~\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{11}^{2}}(\upsigma_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}-\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}})+\displaystyle\frac{1}{\mathrm{V}_{10}^{2}}(\upsigma_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{xz}}^{2})\Bigg)}}\end{array}
$$  

$$
(\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}>0)
$$  

$$
\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}\geq0
$$  

where the indices $(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{z})$ denote material coordinate direction.  

$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$ : maximum fiber tensile stress. $\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ , no Default.  

$\mathrm{~V}_{2}$ : maximum fiber compressive stress. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{1}}$  

$\mathrm{~V}_{3}$ : maximum matrix tensile stress. Real $>0.0$ , no Default.  

$\mathrm{\DeltaV_{4}}$ : maximum matrix compressive stress. Real $>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{~V~}_{3}$ ，  

$\mathrm{V}_{10}:$ maximum in plane shear stress. Real $>0.0$ no Default  

$\mathrm{V}_{11}:$ maximum transverse shear stress; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{10}}$  

9.For the Puck failure criterion fivefailure indices are calculated for the plane stresscase and four for the general 3-D case. The first two failure indices are related to fiber failure and apply to both plane stress and 3-D case:  

Tensile fiber mode, for $\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}>0$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{1}~=~\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{V}_{1}}
$$  

Compressive fiber mode, for $\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}<0$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{2}\ =\ {\frac{\left|\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\right|}{\mathrm{V}_{1}}}
$$  

For plane stress case, the next three failure indices are related to the matrix failure and are given as follows:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\mathbf{F}_{3}=\sqrt{\displaystyle(\frac{\mathbb{S}_{\mathbf{xy}}}{\mathbb{V}_{10}})^{2}+\left(1-\mathbb{W}_{2}\frac{\mathbf{V}_{3}}{\mathbb{V}_{10}}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{\mathbb{G}_{\mathbf{y}}}{\mathbb{V}_{3}}\right)^{2}}+\mathbb{W}_{2}\frac{\mathbb{G}_{\mathbf{y}}}{\mathbb{V}_{10}}\qquad\mathrm{for~}\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{y}}>0}\\ &{\mathbf{F}_{4}=\frac{1}{\mathbb{V}_{10}}(\sqrt{\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{xy}}^{2}+(\mathbb{W}_{1}\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{y}})^{2}}+\mathbb{W}_{1}\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{y}})\qquad\mathrm{for~}\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{y}}<0\mathrm{~and~}\left(0\leq\left|\frac{\mathbb{G}_{\mathbf{y}}}{\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{xy}}}\right|\leq\frac{\mathbb{R}_{1}}{\mathbb{R}_{2}}\right)}\\ &{\mathbf{F}_{5}=\left(\frac{\mathbb{G}_{\mathbf{xy}}}{2(1+\mathbb{W}_{3}\mathbb{V}_{10})}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\mathbb{G}_{\mathbf{y}}}{\mathbb{V}_{4}}\right)^{2}\frac{\mathbb{V}_{4}}{\left|\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{y}}\right|}\qquad\mathrm{for~}\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{y}}<0\mathrm{~and~}\left(0\leq\left|\frac{\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{xy}}}{\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathbf{y}}}\right|\leq\frac{\mathbb{R}_{2}}{\mathbb{R}_{1}}\right)}\end{array}
$$  

where the parameters, $\mathrm{R}_{1}$ and ${\mathrm{R}}_{2}$ are as follows:  

$$
\begin{array}{l}{\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{1}~=~\frac{\mathrm{V}_{10}}{2(1+\mathrm{W}_{1})}\Biggl(\sqrt{1+2\mathrm{W}_{1}\frac{\mathrm{V}_{4}}{\mathrm{V}_{10}}}-1\Biggr)}\\ {\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{2}~=~\mathrm{V}_{10}\sqrt{1+2\mathrm{W}_{3}}}\end{array}
$$  

Failure index for 3-D case is calculated based on stress, $\upsigma_{\mathrm{n}}(\uptheta),\upsigma_{\mathrm{n{t}}}(\uptheta)$ and $\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}(\uptheta)$ on an arbitrary plane with inclination angle 0 . The stresses are given by:  

$$
{\begin{array}{r l}&{\upsigma_{\mathrm{n}}=\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}{\cos^{2}}\uptheta+\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}{\sin^{2}}\uptheta+2\upsigma_{\mathrm{yz}}{\sin}\uptheta{\cos}\uptheta}\\ &{}\\ &{\upsigma_{\mathrm{nt}}=(\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}-\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}){\sin}\uptheta{\cos}\theta+\upsigma_{\mathrm{yz}}({\cos^{2}}\uptheta-{\sin^{2}}\uptheta)}\\ &{\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}=\upsigma_{\mathrm{zx}}{\sin}\theta+\upsigma_{\mathrm{xy}}{\cos}\theta}\end{array}}
$$  

For 3-D case, the next two failure indices related to matrix failure are given by  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\mathrm{\boldmath~F}_{3}\ =\ \sqrt{\displaystyle\left(\frac{1}{{\bf V}_{3}}-{\bf P}_{1}\right)^{2}{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{n}}^{2}+\left(\frac{{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{nt}}}{{\bf R}_{1}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{n}1}}{{\upsigma}_{10}}\right)^{2}}+{\bf P}_{1}\upsigma_{\mathrm{n}}\qquad\mathrm{\for~}{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{n}}\ge0}\\ &{\mathrm{\boldmath~F}_{4}\ =\ \sqrt{\displaystyle\left(\frac{{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{nt}}}{{\upbar{\mathrm{R}}_{1}}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{n1}}}{{\upsigma}_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left({\bf P}_{2}{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{n}}\right)^{2}}+{\bf P}_{2}\upsigma_{\mathrm{n}}\qquad\mathrm{\for~}{\upsigma}_{\mathrm{n}}\ge0}\end{array}
$$  

where ${\mathrm{P}}_{1}$ and ${\mathrm{P}}_{2}$ are given as:  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\mathrm{P}_{1}\ =\ \bigg(\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{W}_{4}}{\mathrm{R}_{1}}\bigg)\displaystyle\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{nt}}^{2}}{\upsigma_{\mathrm{nt}}^{2}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}^{2}}+\bigg(\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{W}_{2}}{\mathrm{V}_{10}}\bigg)\displaystyle\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}^{2}}{\upsigma_{\mathrm{nt}}^{2}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}^{2}}}\\ &{\mathrm{P}_{2}\ =\ \bigg(\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{W}_{3}}{\mathrm{R}_{1}}\bigg)\displaystyle\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{nt}}^{2}}{\upsigma_{\mathrm{nt}}^{2}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}^{2}}+\bigg(\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{W}_{1}}{\mathrm{V}_{10}}\bigg)\displaystyle\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}^{2}}{\upsigma_{\mathrm{nt}}^{2}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{n1}}^{2}}}\end{array}
$$  

The following material parameters are used:  

${\bf V}_{1}={\bf\Gamma}$ Maximum fiber tensile stress $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ ; no Default) ${\bf V}_{2}\ =$ Maximum fiber compressive stress $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{\mathrm{~l~}}}$ ） ${\mathrm{\boldmath~V~}}_{3}{\mathrm{\boldmath~\Gamma~}}={\mathrm{\boldmath~\Gamma~}}$ Maximum matrix tensile stress $\mathrm{\langleReal>0.0}$ ; no Default) $\mathrm{{V}_{4}~=~}$ Maximum matrix compressive stress $(\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ or blank; Default $\mathrm{\DeltaV}_{3}$ ） $\mathrm{\DeltaV_{10}~=~}$ Maximum in-plane shear stress. $(\mathrm{Real}>0.0$ ; no Default)  

$\mathsf{W}_{1}=\mathsf{p}12\mathsf{c}$ , slope 1 of failure envelope $\mathrm{\Real>0.0}$ ; no Default)   
$\mathsf{W}_{2}\ =\mathsf{p}12\mathrm{t}$ , slope 2 of failure envelope $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ ; Default $\mathrm{W}_{1}$ ）   
$\mathsf{W}_{3}\ =\mathsf{p}23\mathsf{c}$ , slope 3 of failure envelope $\mathrm{(Real>0.0}$ or blank; Default; calculated internally; this is   
recommended for plane stress)

10.The Hashin-Tape criterion is a variant of the Hashin criterion adapted for tape typeofmaterials.Four failure indices are calculated:  

$$
\mathrm{F_{1\rho}}=\begin{array}{c c}{\displaystyle\left(\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}}{\upsigma_{1}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\upsigma_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xz}}}{\upsigma_{12}}\right)^{2}}&{\qquad\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}>0}\\ {0}&{\qquad\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\leq0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F_{2}}~=~\mathrm{\displaystyle\left(\frac{\upsigma_{_X}}{\upsigma_{_Z}}\right)^{2}}+\mathrm{\left(\frac{\uptau_{_\mathrm{Xy}}}{\upsigma_{_10}}\right)^{2}}+\mathrm{\left(\frac{\uptau_{_\mathrm{XZ}}}{\upsigma_{_12}}\right)^{2}}~\mathrm{\qquad~\upsigma_{x}<0~}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{\boldmath~\cal~F~}_{3}=\mathrm{\boldmath~\frac{1}{{V}_{3}^{2}}}({\tt o}_{y}+{\tt o}_{z})^{2}-\frac{\displaystyle\mathbb{\sigma}_{y}\mathbb{\sigma}_{z}}{\displaystyle\mathrm{V}_{11}^{2}}+\left(\frac{\displaystyle\tau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\displaystyle\mathrm{V}_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\displaystyle\tau_{\mathrm{xz}}}{\displaystyle\mathrm{V}_{12}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\displaystyle\tau_{\mathrm{yz}}}{\displaystyle\mathrm{V}_{11}}\right)^{2}\quad\quad\quad{\tt o}_{y}+{\tt o}_{z}>0
$$  

$$
\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}\geq0
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}{\lefteqn{\operatorname{\Big(}\Big(\frac{\mathrm{V}_{4}}{2\mathrm{V}_{11}}\Big)^{2}-1\Big)\frac{(\mathrm{\overline{{v}}}_{\mathrm{y}}+\mathtt{\sigma}_{z})}{\mathrm{V}_{4}}+\frac{1}{4\mathrm{V}_{11}^{2}}(\mathtt{\sigma}_{\mathrm{y}}+\mathtt{\sigma}_{z})^{2}-\frac{\mathfrak{O}_{\mathrm{y}}\mathfrak{O}_{z}}{\mathrm{V}_{11}^{2}}+}}\\ {\mathbb{F}_{4}=}\ }&{+\left(\Big(\frac{\tau_{_{\mathrm{xy}}}}{\mathrm{V}_{10}}\Big)^{2}+\Big(\frac{\tau_{_{\mathrm{xz}}}}{\mathrm{V}_{12}}\Big)^{2}+\Big(\frac{\tau_{_{\mathrm{yz}}}}{\mathrm{V}_{11}}\Big)^{2}+\mathrm{V}_{5}\Big(\frac{\mathfrak{O}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{V}_{6}}\Big)^{2}\right)}&{\ (\mathtt{\sigma}_{\mathrm{y}}+\mathtt{\sigma}_{z}<0)}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}\geq0
$$

11. The Hashin-Fabric criterion is a variant ofthe Hashin criterion adapted for fabric type of materials Six failure indices are calculated:  

$$
\mathrm{F_{1\rho}}=\begin{array}{c c}{\displaystyle\left(\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}}{\upsigma_{1}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\upsigma_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xz}}}{\upsigma_{12}}\right)^{2}}&{\qquad\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}>0}\\ {0}&{\qquad\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\leq0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F}_{2}~=~\left(\frac{\mathrm{\bf~\sigma}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{\bfV}_{2}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\mathrm{\bf~\tau}_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\mathrm{\bfV}_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\mathrm{\bf~\tau}_{\mathrm{xz}}}{\mathrm{\bfV}_{12}}\right)^{2}\qquad\mathrm{\bf~\sigma}_{\mathrm{x}}<0
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F_{3}~}=\begin{array}{c c}{\displaystyle\left(\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}}{\mathrm{V}_{3}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\mathrm{V}_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}}{\mathrm{V}_{11}}\right)^{2}}&{\qquad\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}<0}\\ {0}&{\qquad\upsigma_{\mathrm{v}}\geq0}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l r}{\mathrm{\boldmath~F_{4}~}=\begin{array}{l}{\left(\displaystyle\frac{\mathbb{\sigma}_{\mathrm{y}}}{\mathrm{\boldmath~V~}_{4}}\right)^{2}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\mathrm{\boldmath~V~}_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left(\displaystyle\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}}{\mathrm{\boldmath~V~}_{12}}\right)^{2}}&{}&{\mathrm{\sigma}_{\mathrm{y}}<0}\\ {0}&{}&{\mathrm{\sigma}_{\mathrm{y}}\ge0}\end{array}}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{F_{5}}\ =\begin{array}{c c}{\displaystyle\left(\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}}{\mathrm{V}_{5}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\mathrm{V_{10}}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xz}}}{\mathrm{V_{12}}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}}{\mathrm{V_{11}}}\right)^{2}\quad}&{\mathrm{~\upsigma_{z}<0~}}\\ {0\quad}&{\mathrm{~\upsigma_{z}\geq0~}}\end{array}

$$
\mathrm{~F_{6}~}=\begin{array}{c c}{\displaystyle\left(\frac{\upsigma_{z}}{\mathrm{V}_{6}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}}{\mathrm{V}_{10}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xz}}}{\mathrm{V}_{12}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}}{\mathrm{V}_{11}}\right)^{2}}&{\qquad\upsigma_{z}<0}\\ {0}&{\qquad\upsigma_{z}\geq0}\end{array}

12. A MATTF entry with the same MID as MATF may be used to specify the temperature variation of the failure criterion values.  

13. User subroutine UFAIL is used along with option MATUDS.  

14..In SOL 400, MATF is only supported for elements with property extensions.This implies that for such elements, PBAR / PBARL, PBEAM / PBEAML, PCOMP / PCOMPG, PROD, PSHEAR, PSHELL, PLPLANE and PSOLID should be associated with PBARN1, PBEMN1, PSHLN1, PRODN1, PSHEARN, PSHLN1, PSHLN2 and PSLDN1 respectively. Note that, prior to MD Nastran 2010,if the property extensions were missing, then the MATF data was not considered in the element's formulation. If the property extensions are missing, they are automatically added with default settings by the program unless the user has set NLMOPTS,SPROPMAP,-1 in the bulk data. For non-composite material with MATF,only the first failure criteria is calculated and its failure index is outputted in NLOUT.   
15.For the primary format,ifonly one criterion is needed and no data is required on the 3rdline, it can be omitted.If more than one criterion is needed, all3 lines are required except for the last one. If the third line of the last one is not required, it may be omitted.   
16. Stress limits such as ST, SC, SS, $X_{\mathrm{t}}$ ， $X_{\mathrm{c}}$ ， $\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{\Omegat}}$ ， $\mathrm{Y_{c}}$ in the MAT1, MAT2 and MAT8 entries are not used in SOL 400.   
17.Stressand/or strain allowables in all directions should be defined if the default is not appropriate.Be sure not to set some of these values to low numbers.   
18.If MAT8 with Hashin is used in SOL 400 run with PSLDN1 then Hashin FT willbe ignored with an appropriate warning message to include MATF instead.  

Specifies failure model properties forlinear elastic materials to be used for static,quasi static or transient dynamic analysis in SOL 600.Up to three criterion may be specified for each material if failure indices are desired $(\mathrm{ITYPE{=}}0)_{\ \cdot}$ ). For progressive failure $(\mathrm{ITYPE}=2)$ ） only one criterion should normally be specified. Even if failure indices (no progressive failure) is the objective of the analysis, it is recommended that only one criterion per material be specified to simplify post processing.

Remarks:  

1. The MATF Bulk Data entry contains supplementary data forfailure prediction ofthe elastic materials with the same MID.If this capability is used in nonlinear analysis, MATF can activate progressive failure process.   
2. Progressve failure behavior for various materials can be simulated using the MATF Bulk Data entry. Failure occurs when any one of the specified failure criterion is satisfied. Upon failure, the elastic modulus reduces to $10\%$ of the original modulus if there is only one value of modulus as in isotropic material or in a beam or truss element. If it pertains to an orthotropic material, allof the material moduli at the integration point are reduced to the lowest modulus specified. The behavior up to the failure point is linear elastic even if an elasto-plastic material is specified, which is folowed by a nonlinear behavior for the post-failure analysis. If the initial yield stress is less than the allowable maximum stress, the failure criterion will be ignored.   
3. According to the Maximum Stress Criterion,the material fails when any of the stress components (9 components including 6 normal stress components in tension and compression, and three shear stress components) exceeds the maximum allowable stress: $\left\vert\upsigma_{\mathrm{ij}}\right\vert>\mathrm{Xt}$ , Xc, Yt, .... $\mathrm{S_{xy}}$ ....etc. where the indices (x, y, z or i, j) denote material coordinate direction.   
4.According to the Maximum Strain Criterion, the material fails when any of the strain components (9 components including 6 normal strain components in tension and compression, and three shear strain components) exceeds the maximum allowable strain: $\lvert\mathfrak{c}_{\mathrm{ij}}\rvert>\mathrm{Ext}$ , Exc, Ext, ..., Gxy, ...etc. where the indices (x,y, z or i, j) denote material coordinate direction.   
5.According to the Hill Failure Criterion, there is no distinction between tensile and compressive behavior. The failure is determined based on  

$$
\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}^{2}}{\mathrm{X}^{2}}+\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}^{2}}{\mathrm{Y}^{2}}+\frac{\upsigma_{z}^{2}}{\mathrm{Z}^{2}}-\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{X}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Z}^{2}}\bigg)\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}-\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Z}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{X}^{2}}\bigg)\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}
$$  

$$
-\biggl(\frac{1}{\mathrm{Z}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{X}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}^{2}}\biggr)\upsigma_{z}\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}>\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{ind}}
$$  

in which X, Y, Z, $\mathrm{S_{xy}},$ $\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{yz}},\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{zx}}$ are maximum allowable stresses and $\mathrm{F_{ind}}$ is the failure index prescribed by the user.  

a.The Hoffman Failure Criterion introduces distinction between tensile and compressive stresses to generalize the Hill Failure Criterion, i.e.,  

$$
\mathrm{{C_{x}}(\upsigma_{x}-\upsigma_{y})^{2}+\mathrm{{C_{y}}(\upsigma_{y}-\upsigma_{z})^{2}+\mathrm{{C_{z}}(\upsigma_{z}-\upsigma_{x})^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{X_{t}}-\frac{1}{X_{c}}\right)\upsigma_{x}}}}
$$  

$$
+\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{t}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{c}}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\left(\frac{1}{Z_{\mathrm{t}}}-\frac{1}{Z_{\mathrm{c}}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}+\frac{\uptau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}>\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{ind}}
$$  

with  

$$
\mathrm{C_{\mathrm{x}}~=~}\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{t}}\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{c}}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{t}}\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{c}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Z}_{\mathrm{t}}\mathrm{Z}_{\mathrm{c}}}\bigg)
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\mathrm{\boldmath~C_{y}~}=\ \displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y_{t}}\mathrm{Y_{c}}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Z_{t}}\mathrm{Z_{c}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{X_{t}}\mathrm{X_{c}}}\bigg)}\\ &{\mathrm{\boldmath~C_{z}~}=\ \displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{\mathrm{Z_{t}}\mathrm{Z_{c}}}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{X_{t}}\mathrm{X_{c}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y_{t}}\mathrm{Y_{c}}}\bigg)}\end{array}
$$  

in which $\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{t}},\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{c}},\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{t}},\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{c}},\mathrm{Z}_{\mathrm{t}},\mathrm{Z}_{\mathrm{c}},\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{xy}},\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{yz}},\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{zx}}$ are maximum allowable stresses and $\mathrm{F_{ind}}$ is the failure index, prescribed by the user.  

b. The Tsai-Wu Failure Criterion is another generalization of the Hill Failure Criterion:  

$$
\left(\frac{1}{X_{\mathrm{t}}}-\frac{1}{X_{c}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}+\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y_{t}}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Y_{c}}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+\left(\frac{1}{Z_{\mathrm{t}}}-\frac{1}{Z_{\mathrm{c}}}\right)\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}+\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}^{2}}{\mathrm{X_{t}X_{\mathrm{c}}}}+\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}^{2}}{\mathrm{Y_{t}Y_{\mathrm{c}}}}+\frac{\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}^{2}}{Z_{\mathrm{t}}Z_{\mathrm{c}}}
$$  

$$
+\frac{\tau_{\mathrm{xy}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S_{xy}^{2}}}+\frac{\tau_{\mathrm{yz}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S_{yz}^{2}}}+\frac{\tau_{\mathrm{zx}}^{2}}{\mathrm{S_{zx}^{2}}}+2\mathrm{F_{xy}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}+2\mathrm{F_{yz}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{y}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}+2\mathrm{F_{zx}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{x}}\upsigma_{\mathrm{z}}>\mathrm{F_{ind}}
$$  

in which $\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{t}},\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{c}},\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{t}},\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{c}},\mathrm{Z}_{\mathrm{t}},\mathrm{Z}_{\mathrm{c}},\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{xy}},\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{yz}},\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{zx}}$ are maximum allowable stresses, $\mathrm{F_{xy},F_{y z},F_{z x}}$ are interactive strength constants, and $\mathrm{F_{ind}}$ is the failure index, prescribed by the user.
